gab.explanation: To talk idly or incessantly, as about trivial matters.

gabbro.explanation: A usually coarse-grained igneous rock composed chiefly of pyroxene and calcic plagioclase feldspar.

A rock of varied lithological character, essentially, according to the present general acceptation of the name among lithologists, a crystalline-granular aggregate of plagioclase and diallage, with which often occur magnetite (or menachanite) and apatite.

It is proposed, in the field classification of igneous rocks in connection with the quantitative system of classification (1902), to use the term gabbro for all granular igneous rocks with dominant pyroxene and subordinate feldspar of any kind, with or without hornblende and mica. Such rocks would include the less feldspathic gabbros and norites, and some diorites. See rock.

A name originally given by the Italians to a kind of serpentine, later to the rock called euphotide , and now generally used for a coarsely crystalline, igneous rock consisting of lamellar pyroxene (diallage) and labradorite, with sometimes chrysolite (olivine gabbro).
A name originally given to a kind of serpentine , and now generally used for a coarsely crystalline , igneous rock consisting of lamellar pyroxene and labradorite .
one of a family of granular intrusive rocks

gabbroic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or containing gabbro

gabbroid.explanation: petrography , resembling or somewhat like gabbro; also suggested by Chamberlin and Salisbury (1904) as a general term applicable to any crystalline rock in which the ferromagnesian minerals predominate: thus, many diorites, gabbros, and dolerites, and all peridotites would be gabbroids.

gabby.explanation: Inclined to talk too much, especially about trivia .

gabeler.explanation: A collector of the gabel or of taxes.
A collector of gabels or taxes.
A collector of gabels or taxes .

gabelle.explanation: A tax, especially the salt tax imposed in France before 1790.

gaberdine.explanation: A long, coarse cloak or frock worn especially by Jews during the Middle Ages.

gabert.explanation: A lighter, or vessel for inland navigation.

gabfest.explanation: An informal gathering or session for the exchange of news, opinions, and gossip.

an occasion (such as a meeting) where people talk at length.
light informal conversation for social occasions

gabgab.explanation: On the island of Guam, the coral-tree, Erythrina Indica , the appearance of the bright scarlet blossoms of which announces the beginning of the rainy season. Its wood is soft and is used for making troughs.
The South Sea arrow-root. See gaogao .

gabion.explanation: A cylindrical wicker basket filled with earth and stones, formerly used in building fortifications.
A hollow metal cylinder used especially in constructing dams and foundations.

In fortification , a large basket of wickerwork constructed with stakes and osiers, or green twigs, in a cylindrical form, but without a bottom, varying in diameter from 20 to 70 inches, and in height from 33 inches to 5 or 6 feet, filled with earth, and serving to shelter men from an enemy's fire.
A hollow cylinder of wickerwork, like a basket without a bottom. Gabions are made of various sizes, and filled with earth in building fieldworks to shelter men from an enemy's fire.
An openwork frame, as of poles, filled with stones and sunk, to assist in forming a bar dyke, etc., as in harbor improvement.
A cylindrical basket or cage of wicker which was filled with earth or stones and used in fortifications and other engineering work (a precursor to the sandbag ).
A woven wire mesh unit, sometimes rectangular, made from a continuous mesh panel and filled with stones sometimes coated with polyvinyl chloride .

A porous metal cylinder filled with stones and used in a variety of civil engineering contexts, especially in the construction of retaining walls , the reinforcing of steep slopes, or in the prevention of erosion in river banks.
A knickknack , objet d'art , curiosity , collectable .

gabionade.explanation: In fortification , a work formed chiefly of gabions, especially the gabions placed to cover guns from an enfilading fire.
Any hydraulic structure composed in whole or part of gabions sunk in a stream to control the current.
A traverse made with gabions between guns or on their flanks, protecting them from enfilading fire.
A structure of gabions sunk in lines, as a core for a sand bar in harbor improvements.

gabionage.explanation: The supply or disposition of gabions in a fortification.
The part of a fortification built of gabions.

gabioned.explanation: fortification , furnished with, formed of, or protected by gabions.

gable.explanation: The generally triangular section of wall at the end of a pitched roof, occupying the space between the two slopes of the roof.
The whole end wall of a building or wing having a pitched roof.
A triangular, usually ornamental architectural section, as one above an arched door or window.

In architecture , the end of a ridged roof which at its extremity is not hipped or returned on itself, but cut off in a vertical plane, together with the triangular expanse of wall from the level of the eaves to the apex: distinguished from a pediment in that the cornice is not carried across the base of the triangle.
Any architectural member having the form of a gable, as a triangular canopy over a window or a doorway.
The end-wall of a house; a gable-end.
In mech. , the outer end or tip of the crank in a cranked axle or shaft. The finishing of this is termed cutting the gable.

The vertical triangular portion of the end of a building, from the level of the cornice or eaves to the ridge of the roof. Also, a similar end when not triangular in shape, as of a gambrel roof and the like.
The end wall of a building, as distinguished from the front or rear side.
A decorative member having the shape of a triangular gable, such as that above a Gothic arch in a doorway.
a double sloping roof which forms a gable at each end.

A stick, or rod of wood, sharpened to a point, or provided with a metal point, used to drive cattle with; a goad; hence, a slender stick or rod of any kind, especially one used for whipping.

A mineral of a nearly black color and vitreous luster, and consisting principally of the silicates of yttrium, cerium, and iron.

a mineral that is a source of rare earths; consists of silicates of iron and beryllium and cerium and yttrium and erbium

gadolinium.explanation: A silvery-white, malleable, ductile, metallic rare-earth element, with unusual magnetic properties including a Curie point at room temperature, obtained from monazite and bastnaesite and used in improving high-temperature characteristics of iron, chromium, and related alloys, and as a contrast medium for magnetic resonance imaging. Atomic number 64; atomic weight 157.25; melting point 1,313°C; boiling point approximately 3,273°C; specific gravity from 7.901; valence 3. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
A supposed new element found with yttrium in gadolinite.
It belongs to the same family as yttrium. Its oxid is white, and its salts are colorless: atomic weight about 156. It perhaps represents a mixture of more than a single element.

A rare earth metallic element of the Lanthanide series, with a characteristic spectrum, found associated with yttrium and other rare earth elements. Symbol, Gd; it has an atomic number of 64, an atomic weight of 157.25 (C=12.011), and a valence of +3.
A metallic chemical element (symbol Gd) with an atomic number of 64.
a ductile silvery-white ductile ferromagnetic trivalent metallic element of the rare earth group

To equip (a gamecock) with a gaff.
To take in or defraud; swindle.
To rig or fix in order to cheat.
In Great, Britain, a theater of the lowest class, the admission to which is generally a penny; a cheap and loosely conducted place of amusement, where singing and dancing take place.
Short for gaffer .

Nautical , a spar used to extend the upper edge of fore-and-aft sails which are not set on stays, as the mainsail of a sloop or the spanker of a ship.
The metal spur bound to the shanks of fighting-cocks; a gaffle.—

gaff for an angler.

gaffed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gaff .

gaffer.explanation: An electrician in charge of lighting on a movie or television set.
An old man or a rustic.

Gaffling is a planning technique for orienteering relay courses whereby individual routes are planned so as to vary slightly and to make following difficult. This means that the competition depends more on navigational skills rather than just physical ability. See British Orienteering Federation's Event Guideline F for Relay Events, Section 3.

gag.explanation: Something forced into or put over the mouth to prevent speaking or crying out.

To prevent from speaking or crying out by using a gag.

To cause to choke, retch, or undergo a regurgitative spasm.

gag a part.

Gag, Muzzle, Muffle ; stifle. To gag is to silence by thrusting something into the mouth and securing it in place. To muzzle a dog, or other creature having a projecting mouth, is to incase the mouth and nose (muzzle) in a framework called a muzzle, in order to prevent him from biting or eating. Both gag and muzzle are sometimes used figuratively for the act of silencing effectively by moral compulsion, gag implying also roughness or severity in the performance: as, a muzzled press; to gag a public speaker by threats of violence. To muffle is primarily to conceal by wrapping up, but the word has a secondary use to express the deadening of sound, by wrapping (as an oar) or otherwise (as a drum).
Something thrust into the mouth or throat to prevent speech or outcry; hence, any violent or authoritative suppression of freedom of speech.
A mouthful which produces nausea and retching, or threatens with choking.
An apparatus or device for distending the jaws, such as is used in various surgical operations; hence, anything used to pry or keep open the jaws.
In coal-mining , a chip of wood in a sinking pit-bottom or sump.

A very large collection of stars comparable in size to the Milky Way system, held together by gravitational force and separated from other such star systems by large distances of mostly empty space. Galaxies vary widely in shape and size, the most common nearby galaxies being over 70,000 light years in diameter and separated from each other by even larger distances. The number of stars in one galaxy varies, and may extend into the hundreds of billions.
A splendid or impressive assemblage of persons or things.
a splendid assemblage (especially of famous people)
tufted evergreen perennial herb having spikes of tiny white flowers and glossy green round to heart-shaped leaves that become coppery to maroon or purplish in fall
(astronomy) a collection of star systems; any of the billions of systems each having many stars and nebulae and dust

galban.explanation: A gum resin exuding from the stems of certain Asiatic umbelliferous plants, mostly species of Ferula. The Bubon Galbanum of South Africa furnishes an inferior kind of galbanum. It has an acrid, bitter taste, a strong, unpleasant smell, and is used for medical purposes, also in the arts, as in the manufacture of varnish.

galbanum.explanation: A bitter, aromatic gum resin extracted from a southwest Asian plant (Ferula gummosa syn. F. galbaniflua) in the parsley family, used in incense and in traditional medicine.

A gum resin obtained from species of Ferula , especially F. galbaniflua and F. rubricaulis , of the desert regions of Persia. It occurs in the form of translucent tears, and has a peculiar aromatic odor and a disagreeable alliaceous taste. It is used in medicine as a stimulating expectorant and as an ingredient in plasters.
A bitter , aromatic resin or gum , extracted from plants of the genus Ferula , that resembles assafoetida and has been used in incense and in aromatherapy
a bitter aromatic gum resin that resembles asafetida

galbe.explanation: In art , the general outline or form of any rounded object, as a head or vase; especially, in architecture, the curved form of a column, a Doric capital, or other similar feature.
The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column or a vase.
The contour or outline of something.

galbula.explanation: The classical name of some yellow bird of Europe, supposed to be the golden oriole, and the technical specific name of this oriole, Oriolus galbula. The name was also applied by Mohring in 1752 to a South American jacamar, and by Linnæus in 1758 to the Baltimore oriole, Icterus galbula. See cut under oriole .

[ capitalized ] A genus of jacamars, established by Brisson in 1760, typical of the family Galbulidæ. There are nine South American species, of which G. viridis is a characteristic example. See cut under jacamar .

galbulidae.explanation: A natural family of tropical American birds comprising the jacamars.

galbulus.explanation: In botany , a spherical cone formed of thickened peltate scales with a narrow base, as in the cypress, or berry-like with fleshy coherent scales, as in the juniper. See cut under Cupressus .
A fleshy seed-producing cone of junipers and cypresses
the seed-producing cone of a cypress tree

gale.explanation: The sweet gale.
A wind with a speed of from 34 to 40 knots (39 to 46 miles per hour; 63 to 74 kilometers per hour), according to the Beaufort scale.
A storm at sea.
A forceful outburst.
A song.
Speech; discourse.
The Myrica Gale , a shrub growing in marshy places in northern Europe and Asia and in North America: more usually called sweet-gale , from its pleasant aromatic odor.

A strong natural current of air; a wind; a breeze; more specifically, in nautical use, a wind between a stiff breeze and a storm or tempest: generally with some qualifying epithet: as, a gentle, moderate, brisk, fresh, stiff, strong, or hard gale.
Figuratively, a state of noisy excitement, as of hilarity or of passion.
By extension, an odor-laden current of air.
A periodical payment of rent, interest, duty, or custom; an instalment of money.
The right of a free miner to have possession of a plot of land within the Forest of Dean and hundred of St. Briavels, in England, and to work the coal and iron thereunder.
Gales are classified as moderate, fresh, strong, and whole gales. See Beaufort scale .
away.
To sale, or sail fast.
A song or story.
A strong current of air; a wind between a stiff breeze and a hurricane. The most violent gales are called tempests .
A moderate current of air; a breeze.
A state of excitement, passion, or hilarity.
one in which a ship may carry her topgallant sails.
To sing.
A plant of the genus Myrica, growing in wet places, and strongly resembling the bayberry. The sweet gale ( Myrica Gale ) is found both in Europe and in America.
The payment of a rent or annuity.
the day on which rent or interest is due.
To sing ; charm ; enchant .
To cry ; groan ; croak .
To talk .
To call .
To sing; utter with musical modulations.
A very strong wind , more than a breeze , less than a storm ; number 7 through 9 winds on the 12-step Beaufort scale .
An outburst , especially of laughter .
A light breeze.
A shrub , sweet gale ( Myrica gale ) growing on moors and fens .
A periodic payment, such as is made of a rent or annuity .
a strong wind moving 45-90 knots; force 7 to 10 on Beaufort scale

galea.explanation: A helmet-shaped part, such as the upper petal of certain plants or part of the maxilla of an insect.
A helmet, or something resembling a helmet in shape or position.
[ capitalized ] In zoology , a genus of fossil sea-urchins or echini of galeate form.

In entomology , an appendage of the stipes of the maxilla of some insects, as distinguished from the lacinia, another appendage of the same gnathite. Thus, in the cockroach the galea is soft, rounded, and possibly sensory in function, while the lacinia is a hard curved blade, serrate and spinose. See lacinia . The extremity of the maxillæ is often terminated by two divisions or lobes, of which the outer, in the Orthoptera, is termed the galea. In Cuvier's Règne Anim. (tr. of 1849), p. 474.

In ornithology , a frontal shield, as that of a coot or gallinule; a horny casque upon the head, as that of the cassowary (see cut under cassowary ); a great helmet-like boss upon the bill, as in the hornbill. See cut under hornbill .
In anatomy : The amnion; especially, the part of the amnion which may cover the head of a new-born infant like a cowl. Also called caul . The galea capitis (which see, below).
In botany , a name given to the parts of the calyx or corolla when they assume the form of a helmet, as the upper lip of a ringent corolla.
In pathology , headache extending all over the head.
In surgery , a bandage for the head.
The upper lip or helmet-shaped part of a labiate flower.
A kind of bandage for the head.
Headache extending all over the head.
A genus of fossil echini, having a vaulted, helmet-shaped shell.
The anterior, outer process of the second joint of the maxillae in certain insects.
a Roman helmet
an organ or a part of a plant that is shaped like a galea (helmet)
a mouthpart found in some species of chewing insect, which is shaped like a galea (helmet)
A kind of bandage for the head .
A headache extending all over the head.
an organ shaped like a helmet; usually a vaulted and enlarged petal as in Aconitum

galeage.explanation: Ground-rent paid for a grant of land.

galeate.explanation: entomology , provided with a galea, as the maxillæ of certain insects.
ornithology , having on the head a crest of feathers resembling a helmet; or, and oftener, having a horny casque upon the head, as the cassowary, or a frontal shield, as a coot or gallinule.
ichthyology , having a casque-like induration of the skin of the head, as many siluroid fishes.
galeate echinus; the galeate upper sepal of the monk's-hood.
Wearing a helmet; protected by a helmet; covered, as with a helmet.
Helmeted; having a helmetlike part, as a crest, a flower, etc.; helmet-shaped.
Of or relating to a galea .

galeated.explanation: galeate : as, the galeated curassow ( Pauxis galeata ).
of or relating to a galea

galee.explanation: In coal-mining , the person to whom a gale has been granted.

galega.explanation: A genus of tall perennial leguminous herbs, with racemes of blue or white flowers and linear cylindrical pods.
small genus of Eurasian herbs: goat's rue

galei.explanation: That division of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sharks.

galeid.explanation: A shark of the family Galeidæ. Also galeidan .

galeiform.explanation: having the shape of a galea

galempong.explanation: A Javanese musical instrument of the zither class, with from ten to twenty-five strings.

galena.explanation: A gray mineral, essentially PbS, the principal ore of lead.
A remedy or antidote for poison; theriaca. See theriac .
A remedy or antidote for poison; theriaca.
Lead sulphide; the principal ore of lead. It is of a bluish gray color and metallic luster, and is cubic in crystallization and cleavage.
A mineral , lead sulphide (PbS), used as an ore for lead.
soft blue-grey mineral; lead sulfide; a major source of lead

galenic.explanation: a. d. 130), or to his principles and method of treating diseases.
Relating to Galen or to his principles and method of treating diseases.
that branch of pharmacy which relates to the preparation of medicines by infusion, decoction, etc., as distinguished from those which are chemically prepared.

galenical.explanation: A medicinal preparation composed mainly of herbal or vegetable matter.
Any preparation made from vegetable substances by simple physical means, as by infusion, decoction, and percolation, as opposed to chemical methods.
a medicinal preparation concocted mostly out of herbs or vegetable matter, after Galen, the Greek physician and writer of the second century.

galenist.explanation: In medicine , a follower of Galen.
A member of a Mennonite sect founded in 1664 by Galen Abraham de Haan, a physician and preacher of Amsterdam, constituting the Arminian division of the Waterlanders.

galenite.explanation: A mineral, lead ore, lead sulphide , galena .

galenobismutite.explanation: A sulphid of bismuth and lead, occurring in compact masses, having a tin-white color and brilliant metallic luster.
An orthorhombic-dipyramidal mineral containing bismuth , lead , and sulfur .

galeodes.explanation: A genus of arachnidans, typical of the family Galeodidæ , or Solpugidæ.

galeoid.explanation: entomology , to the arachnidans of the family Galeodidæ ; to the sharks or selachians of the family Galeidæ or its equivalent.

galeopithecus.explanation: The typical and only genus of the family Galeopithecidæ.
A genus of flying Insectivora, formerly called flying lemurs . See colugo .

galeopsis.explanation: A small genus of annual labiate weeds of Europe. The common hempnettle, G. Tetrahit , is widely naturalized in the United States.

galeorhinus.explanation: A genus of small sharks, typical of the family Galeorhinidæ : the topes and oil-sharks. G. galeus or Galeus canis is the tope, and G. zyopterus is the oil-shark of California. Also called Galeus (which see).

galera.explanation: A plantigrade carnivorous quadruped, Galera barbara , of the subfamily Mustelinæ , inhabiting South America; the taira.
[ capitalized ] A genus of which the galera is the type, or a subgenus of Galictis , contrasted with Grisonia .

galere.explanation: A group of people with some common characteristic, especially a coterie of undesirable people.

galericulate.explanation: Covered as with a hat or cap.

galerite.explanation: An echinite or fossil sea-urchin of the genus Galerites or family Galeritidæ .
A cretaceous fossil sea urchin of the genus Galerites.
A cretaceous fossil sea urchin of the genus Galerites.

galerum.explanation: A peruke or periwig worn by both men and women. The frequent changes in the style of hair-dressing were imitated by these perukes. They were also worn for disguise, etc.
A round or helmet-like hat of leather; a hat or head-dress worn by some priests, especially the flamen Dialis; any close-fitting cap, whether of cloth or of leather.

galet.explanation: A book-name of the foussa, Cryptoprocta ferox , a feline quadruped of Madagascar. Cuvier. See Cryptoprocta .

galette.explanation: Any of various round flat pastries with a sugar glaze or a sweet filling, such as fruit.
A buckwheat crepe having a savory filling, such as meat or cheese.
A flat round pancake -like pastry from France, usually made with buckwheat

galeus.explanation: A genus of sharks, giving name to the family Galeidæ , and variously defined by different authors.

galictis.explanation: A genus of South American plantigrade Mustelinæ , including the grison and the galera, related to the martens.

galidia.explanation: A genus of viverrine carnivorous quadrupeds, type of a subfamily Galidiinæ , of the family Viverridæ. There are several species peculiar to Madagascar, as G. elegans.

galidictis.explanation: A genus of herpestine carnivorous quadrupeds, of the family Viverridæ and subfamily Herpestinæ , found in Madagascar. G. vittata and G. striata are two longitudinally striped species.

galilee.explanation: A small chapel or porch at the western end of a medieval English church.
A narthex , particularly in the United Kingdom and the Church of England ; a vestibule , a fully-enclosed yet porch -like structure, leading to the main body of an English ecclesiastical building.
In certain Syriac Christian churches , the baptistry .

galileo.explanation: The CGS unit of acceleration , equal to 1 centimetre per second per second. Symbol: Gal

galimatias.explanation: Confused talk; gibberish; nonsense of any kind.
Any confused or nonsensical mixture of incongruous things.
Nonsense; gibberish; confused and unmeaning talk; confused mixture.

galingale.explanation: Any of various sedges of the genus Cyperus, especially C. longus of Europe, having rough-edged leaves, reddish spikelets, and aromatic roots.
A plant of the Sedge family ( Cyperus longus ) having aromatic roots; also, any plant of the same genus.
One of several species of Cyperus sedges with aromatic rhizomes .
European sedge having rough-edged leaves and spikelets of reddish flowers and aromatic roots

galiongee.explanation: A historical term for a Turkish sailor .

galiot.explanation: A light, swift galley formerly used in the Mediterranean.
A light, single-masted, flatbottom Dutch merchant ship.
A small galley or a sort of brigantine formerly in use, built for pursuit, and propelled by both sails and oars, having one mast and sixteen or twenty seats for rowers.

An old Dutch or Flemish vessel for cargoes, with very much rounded ribs and a flattish bottom, a mizzenmast placed near the stern carrying a square mainsail and maintopsail, and a forestay to the mainmast (there being no foremast), with forestaysail and jibs.
A small galley, formerly used in the Mediterranean, built mainly for speed. It was moved both by sails and oars, having one mast, and sixteen or twenty seats for rowers.
A strong, light-draft, Dutch merchant vessel, carrying a mainmast and a mizzenmast, and a large gaff mainsail.

galipot.explanation: Crude turpentine obtained from the maritime pine.
The turpentine which concretes upon the stem of Pinus Pinaster.
An impure resin of turpentine, hardened on the outside of pine trees by the spontaneous evaporation of its essential oil. When purified, it is called yellow pitch , white pitch , or Burgundy pitch .
An unrefined turpentine obtained from some European pines

galium.explanation: A plant of the genus Galium.

[ capitalized ] A large genus of rubiaceous herbs, with square slender stems, verticillate estipulate leaves, small tetramerous and usually white flowers, and a single seed in each of the two cells of the fruit, which is dry or sometimes berry-like.
Any of the genus Galium of annual and perennial herbaceous plants , including the bedstraws .
annual or perennial herbs: bedstraw; cleavers

gall.explanation: Outrageous insolence; effrontery.
Bitterness of feeling; rancor.
Something bitter to endure.
A skin sore caused by friction and abrasion.
Exasperation; vexation.
The cause of such vexation.
To irk or exasperate; vex.
To wear away or make sore by abrasion; chafe.
To become worn or sore by abrasion.
An abnormal growth of plant tissue caused by an organism, such as an insect, mite, or bacterium, or by a wound.
A sore on the skin, caused by fretting or rubbing; an excoriation.
A fault, imperfection, or blemish. Halliwell. [Prov. Eng.]
In stone - and marble-cutting , a hollow made in the surface of a slab by changing the direction of the cut.
A spot where grass, corn, or trees have failed. Halliwell (spelled gaul ).

In the southern United States, a low spot, as near the mouth of a river, where the soil under the matted surface has been washed away, or has been so exhausted that nothing will grow on it. See bay-gall .
The bitter secretion of the liver: same as bile , 1. See also ox-gall .
Hence—2. Bitterness of feeling; rancor; malignity; hate.
The gall-bladder.
[Cf. bile , 2.] Impudence; effrontery; cheek. [Local, slang.]
The scum of melted glass.
galls the back of a horse.
gall a mast or a cable.
galled by sarcasm.
galled by the shot of the enemy.
A long space without weft in a piece of cloth.
A small silver coin of Cambodia, worth about fourpence.

A vegetable excrescence produced by the deposit of the egg of an insect in the bark or leaves of a plant, ordinarily due to the action of some virus deposited by the female along with the egg, but often to the irritation of the larva.
An excrescence on or under the skin of a mammal or a bird, produced by the puncture of an acarid or of an insect of the dipterous genus Œstrus. Encyc. Brit.
A distortion in a plant caused by a species of parasitic fungus.
To impregnate with a decoction of gallnuts.
To scoff; to jeer.
A wound in the skin made by rubbing.
To fret and wear away by friction; to hurt or break the skin of by rubbing; to chafe; to injure the surface of by attrition
To fret; to vex.
To injure; to harass; to annoy.

An excrescence of any form produced on any part of a plant by insects or their larvae. They are most commonly caused by small Hymenoptera and Diptera which puncture the bark and lay their eggs in the wounds. The larvae live within the galls. Some galls are due to aphids, mites, etc. See gallnut .
any insect that produces galls.
any small dipterous insect that produces galls.
the oak ( Quercus infectoria ) which yields the galls of commerce.
the neutral salt skimmed off from the surface of melted crown glass;- called also glass gall and sandiver .
See Gallfly .
The bitter, alkaline, viscid fluid found in the gall bladder, beneath the liver. It consists of the secretion of the liver, or bile, mixed with that of the mucous membrane of the gall bladder.
The gall bladder.
Anything extremely bitter; bitterness; rancor.

gallacetophenone.explanation: A pale yellow powder, CH 3 .CO.C 6 H 2 (OH) 3 , known commonly as alizarin yellow C : employed in dermatology.
A yellowish-brown trioxyacetophenone powder with parasiticide and antiseptic qualities employed externally in the treatment of psoriasis and other skin diseases.

gallamine.explanation: neuromuscular blocking agent (trade name Flaxedil) used as a muscle relaxant in the administration of anesthesia

gallanilide.explanation: A colorless crystalline compound, C 6 H 2 (OH) 3 .CO.NH.C 6 H 5 .2H 2 O, formed by the action of aniline on gallic acid.
A derivative of acetanilide , employed locally in skin diseases as a substitute for chrysarobin .

gallant.explanation: Smartly or boldly stylish; dashing.
Unflinching in battle or action; valiant.
Nobly or selflessly resolute.
Stately; majestic.
Courteously attentive especially to women; chivalrous.
Flirtatious; amorous.
A fashionable young man.
A man courteously attentive to women.
A male lover, especially one who is courteously attentive.
To woo or pay court to (a lady).
To play the gallant.
gallant a lady to the theater.
gallant officer.
gallant antagonist.
Magnificent, brilliant.
, etc. (see brave ); bold, high-spirited, manful.
A gay, dashing person (rarely applied to a woman); a courtly or fashionable man.
An ardent, intrepid youth; a daring spirit; a man of mettle.
(Also ga-lant′ .) A man who is particularly attentive to women; one who habitually escorts or attends upon women; a ladies' man.
A wooer; a suitor; in a bad sense, a rake; a libertine.
Nautical , any flag carried at the mizzenmast.
Polite and attentive to ladies; courteous to women; chivalrous.
Showy; splendid; magnificent; gay; well-dressed.
Noble in bearing or spirit; brave; high-spirited; courageous; heroic; magnanimous
To attend or wait on, as a lady.
To handle with grace or in a modish manner.
A man of mettle or spirit; a gay, fashionable man; a young blood.
One fond of paying attention to ladies.
One who wooes; a lover; a suitor; in a bad sense, a seducer.
Very polite with women .
Fashionable young man, who is polite and attentive to women.
One who woos , a lover , a suitor , a seducer .
An animal or thing of grey colour, such as a horse , badger , or salmon .
topgallant
To attend or wait on (a lady).
To handle with grace or in a modish manner.
Brave , valiant .
Honorable .
Grand , noble .
lively and spirited
unflinching in battle or action
a man who is much concerned with his dress and appearance

gallanted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gallant .

gallantly.explanation: In a polite or courtly manner; like a gallant or wooer.
In a gallant manner, gentlemanly , with social graces.

gallantness.explanation: The state or quality of being gallant; gayness; fine appearance; bravery; dashing courage.

gallantry.explanation: Nobility of spirit or action; courage.
The act or an instance of gallant speech or behavior.
1. Fine appearance; show; finery; splendor; magnificence.
Heroic bearing; bravery; intrepidity; high spirit: as, the gallantry of the troops under fire was admirable.
Courtliness or polite attention to ladies.
In a sinister sense, equivocal attention to women; profligate intrigue.
Civility or polite attention to ladies; in a bad sense, attention or courtesy designed to win criminal favors from a female; freedom of principle or practice with respect to female virtue; intrigue.
an instance of gallant behaviour or speech
the qualities of a hero or heroine; exceptional or heroic courage when facing danger (especially in battle)

gallate.explanation: In chem. , a salt of gallic acid.
any salt or ester of gallic acid

gallature.explanation: The tread, treadle, or chalasa of an egg.

gallberry.explanation: Either of two eastern North American hollies, inkberry or Ilex coriacea, having leathery leaves, small white flowers, and black berries.
The inkberry, Ilex glabra , of the southern United States.
evergreen holly of eastern North America with oblong leathery leaves and small black berries

gallbladder.explanation: A small, pear-shaped muscular sac under the right lobe of the liver, where bile secreted by the liver is stored until needed by the body for digestion.
a muscular sac attached to the liver that stores bile (secreted by the liver) until it is needed for digestion

galleass.explanation: A large, fast, heavily armed three-masted Mediterranean galley of the 1500s and 1600s.

A large galley formerly used in the Mediterranean, carrying generally three masts and perhaps twenty guns, and having castellated structures fore and aft, and seats amidships for the rowers, who were galley-slaves, and numbered sometimes more than three hundred, there being as many as thirty-two oars on a side, each worked by several men.
A large galley, having some features of the galleon, as broadside guns; esp., such a vessel used by the southern nations of Europe in the 16th and 17th centuries. See galleon , and galley .
A type of rowable vessel of the 16th and 17th centuries, similar to a galley but larger, and normally equipped with sails .

galled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gall .
painful from having the skin abraded

gallegan.explanation: A native or an inhabitant of Galicia in Spain; a Galician.
A native or inhabitant of Galicia, in Spain; a Galician.

gallein.explanation: A coal-tar color used in dyeing, prepared by heating together phthalic anhydrid and pyrogallic acid, adding carbonate of soda, and precipitating with an acid. It produces tolerably fast shades of purple and violet on cotton, wool, and silk.
A red crystalline dyestuff, obtained by heating together pyrogallic and phthalic acids.
A red crystalline dyestuff obtained by heating pyrogallic acid and phthalic acid together.

galleon.explanation: A large three-masted sailing ship with a square rig and usually two or more decks, used from the 15th to the 17th century especially by Spain as a merchant ship or warship.
A large unwieldy ship, usually having three or four decks and carrying guns, of a kind formerly used by the Spaniards, especially as treasure-ships, in their commerce with South America.
A sailing vessel of the 15th and following centuries, often having three or four decks, and used for war or commerce. The term is often rather indiscriminately applied to any large sailing vessel.
A large, three masted , square rigged sailing ship with at least two decks .
a large square-rigged sailing ship with three or more masts; used by the Spanish for commerce and war from the 15th to 18th centuries

galler.explanation: One who or that which galls.

galleria.explanation: A roofed passageway or indoor court usually containing a variety of shops or businesses.
An indoor area, or covered courtyard , containing shops .

galleried.explanation: Having a gallery structure, particularly in the form of a covered passage supported by columns, or arches.

gallery.explanation: A roofed promenade, especially one extending along the wall of a building and supported by arches or columns on the outer side.
A long enclosed passage, such as a hallway or corridor.
A narrow balcony, usually having a railing or balustrade, along the outside of a building.
A projecting or recessed passageway along an upper story on the interior or exterior of a large building, generally marked by a colonnade or arcade.
Such a passageway situated over the aisle of a church and opening onto the nave.
An upper section, often with a sloping floor, projecting from the rear or side walls of a theater or an auditorium to provide additional seating.
The seats in such a section, usually cheaper than those on the main floor.
The cheapest seats in a theater, generally those of the uppermost gallery.
The audience occupying a gallery or cheap section of a theater.
A large audience or group of spectators, as at a tennis or golf match.
The general public, usually considered as exemplifying a lack of discrimination or sophistication.
A building, room, or website for the exhibition of artistic work.
An establishment that displays and sells works of art.
A photographer's studio.
A collection; an assortment.
An underground tunnel or passageway, as in a cave or one dug for military or mining purposes.
A tunnel or series of tunnels made by an animal.
A platform or balcony at the stern or quarters of some early sailing ships.
A decorative upright trimming or molding along the edge of a table top, tray, or shelf.
By extension, any company or group of interested spectators, as at a golf-match: a forced use.
Specifically, in écarté, spectators who are betting on either player and are allowed to offer suggestions.
A veranda; a piazza.
In a lamp-burner, the ring which supports the lamp-shade.

An apartment of much greater length than breadth, serving as a passage of communication between the different rooms of a building, or used for the reception of pictures, statues, armor, etc.; a corridor; a passage.
Hence A room or building for the exhibition of works of art, or, by extension, a collection of such works for exhibition.
A platform projecting from the interior walls of a building, supported by piers, pillars, brackets, or consoles, and overlooking the main floor, as in a church, theater, or public library.

A narrow passage, open at least on one side, and often treated as a decorative feature, on the exterior or interior walls of an edifice, entering into the architectural design and at the same time affording communication between different parts, or facilities for keeping the building in repair.
The persons occupying the gallery at a theater.
An ornamental walk or inclosure in a garden, sometimes formed by trees or shrubs.
An underground passage.
In zoology , a long narrow excavation of any kind made by an animal, as the underground passages dug by a mole, the boring of an insect, etc.
Nautical , a frame like a balcony projecting from the stern and quarters of a ship. The part at the stern is called the stern-gallery , that at the quarters the quarter-gallery.
In furniture-making , a small ornamental parapet or railing running along the edge of the top of a table, shelf of a cabinet, or the like, intended to prevent objects from being pushed off.
A long and narrow corridor, or place for walking; a connecting passageway, as between one room and another; also, a long hole or passage excavated by a boring or burrowing animal.
A room for the exhibition of works of art; ; hence, also, a large or important collection of paintings, sculptures, etc.

A long and narrow platform attached to one or more sides of public hall or the interior of a church, and supported by brackets or columns; -- sometimes intended to be occupied by musicians or spectators, sometimes designed merely to increase the capacity of the hall.
A frame, like a balcony, projecting from the stern or quarter of a ship, and hence called stern gallery or quarter gallery , -- seldom found in vessels built since 1850.
Any communication which is covered overhead as well as at the sides. When prepared for defense, it is a defensive gallery .
A working drift or level.
See under Whispering .
An institution , building , or room for the exhibition and conservation of works of art .
An establishment that buys , sells , and displays works of art.
Uppermost seating area projecting from the rear or side walls of a theater , concert hall , or auditorium .
A roofed promenade , especially one extending along the wall of a building and supported by arches or columns on the outer side
as a whole, the spectators of an event.

gallerygoer.explanation: One who attends an art gallery .

gallerylike.explanation: Resembling a gallery , especially an art gallery

gallet.explanation: A fragment of stone broken off by a mason's chisel; a spall.
gallet a wall. Parker. Also garret .

galleting.explanation: The act of inserting chips of stone or flint into the joints of rubblework while the mortar is wet. Also called garreting, garretting.

galley.explanation: A large, usually single-decked medieval ship of shallow draft, propelled by sails and oars and used as a merchant ship or warship in the Mediterranean.
An ancient Mediterranean seagoing vessel propelled by oars.
A large rowboat formerly used by British customs officers.
The kitchen of an airliner, ship, or camper.
A long, usually metal tray, used for assembling lines of printers' type in composing proofs and pages.
A proof made with printer's type before page composition to allow for the detection and correction of errors.
A sea-going vessel propelled by oars, or using both oars and sails.
A state barge; a large boat, especially one used in display; in a special use, an open boat formerly employed on the Thames in England by custom-house officers and press-gangs, and for pleasure.
A boat, somewhat larger than a gig, appropriated for the captain's use on a war-ship. [Eng.]
The cook-room, kitchen, or caboose of a merchant ship, man-of-war, or steamer; also, the stove or range in the galley.
In printing , an oblong shallow tray of brass or wood, rarely of zinc, on which the compositor deposits his type.
A vessel propelled by oars, whether having masts and sails or not.
A large vessel for war and national purposes; -- common in the Middle Ages, and down to the 17th century.
A name given by analogy to the Greek, Roman, and other ancient vessels propelled by oars.
A light, open boat used on the Thames by customhouse officers, press gangs, and also for pleasure.
One of the small boats carried by a man-of-war.
The cookroom or kitchen and cooking apparatus of a vessel; -- sometimes on merchant vessels called the caboose .
An oblong oven or muffle with a battery of retorts; a gallery furnace.
An oblong tray of wood or brass, with upright sides, for holding type which has been set, or is to be made up, etc.
A proof sheet taken from type while on a galley; a galley proof.
a person condemned, often as a punishment for crime, to work at the oar on board a galley.
a sliding false bottom to a large galley.
A long, slender ship propelled primarily by oars , whether having masts and sails or not; usually referring to rowed warships used in the Mediterranean from the 16th century until the modern era.
A light, open boat used on the Thames by customhouse officers, press gangs , and also for pleasure.
One of the small boats carried by a man-of-war .
The cookroom or kitchen and cooking apparatus of a vessel or aircraft; sometimes on merchant vessels called the caboose .
An oblong oven or muffle with a battery of retorts ; a gallery furnace.
An oblong tray of wood or brass, with upright sides, for holding type which has been set, or is to be made up, etc.
A proof sheet taken from type while on a galley; a galley proof .
a large medieval vessel with a single deck propelled by sails and oars with guns at stern and prow; a complement of 1,000 men; used mainly in the Mediterranean for war and trading
the kitchen area for food preparation on an airliner
the area for food preparation on a ship
(classical antiquity) a crescent-shaped seagoing vessel propelled by oars

gallfly.explanation: Any of various small insects, such as a gall midge, a gall wasp, or certain flies in the family Tephritidae, whose larvae cause the formation of galls in plants.
An insect which occasions galls on plants by puncturing them; especially, a hymenopter of the group Gallicolæ or Diplolepariæ , as a cynipid. See gall , and cut under Cynips .
An insect that deposits its eggs in plants, and occasions galls, esp. any small hymenopteran of the genus Cynips and allied genera. See Illust. of gall .
Any of various flies which produce galls .
small solitary wasp that produces galls on oaks and other plants
fragile mosquito-like flies that produce galls on plants
any of various insects that deposit their eggs in plants causing galls in which the larvae feed

galliambic.explanation: A galliambus; a verse consisting of four Ionics a minore with variations and substitutions.
Consisting of two iambic dimeters catalectic, the last of which lacks the final syllable; -- said of a kind of verse.

galliambus.explanation: In prosody , a kind of Ionic verse consisting of two iambic dimeters catalectic, the last of which wants the final syllable. The galliambus is also called metroïacon .

galliard.explanation: A spirited dance in triple time, popular in France in the 1500s and 1600s.
A brisk, lively man; a gay, jaunty fellow: as, “Selden is a galliard ,”
A spirited dance for two dancers only, common in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries: one of the precursors of the minuet. Also called romanesca .
Music written for such a dance, or in its rhythm, which is triple and emphatic, but not rapid.
A term used in northern England for a sandstone or grit of particularly close and uniform texture.
A gay, lively dance. Cf. gailliarde .
A lively dance , popular in 16th- and 17th-century Europe
The triple-time music for this dance

gallic.explanation: Pertaining to, or derived from, galls, nutgalls, and the like.

an organic acid, very widely distributed in the vegetable kingdom, being found in the free state in galls, tea, etc., and produced artificially. It is a white, crystalline substance, C6H2(HO)3.CO2H, with an astringent taste, and is a strong reducing agent, as employed in photography. It is usually prepared from tannin, and both give a dark color with iron salts, forming tannate and gallate of iron, which are the essential ingredients of common black ink.
Pertaining to Gaul or France; Gallican.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from galls
Of or pertaining to gallic acid or its derivatives
of or pertaining to France or the people of France
of or pertaining to Gaul or the Gauls

gallicize.explanation: To make French as the culture, customs, pronunciation, or style.

galliform.explanation: Like the Gallinae (or Galliformes) in structure.
Of or pertaining to a chicken or other member of the order Galliformes

galliformes.explanation: ornithology , formerly, gallinaceous birds collectively; now, in Garrod's classification, an order of a subclass Homalogonatæ , consisting of the three cohorts Struthiones, Gallinaceæ , and Psittaci.
pheasants; turkeys; grouse; partridges; quails; chickens; brush turkeys; curassows; hoatzins

galligaskins.explanation: Loosely fitting hose or breeches worn in the 1500s and 1600s.
Loose hose or breeches; leather leg quards. The word is used loosely and often in a jocose sense.
large, loose breeches . A fashion in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

gallimatia.explanation: Senseless talk. [Obs. or R.] See galimatias .

gallimaufry.explanation: A hash; a medley; a hodgepodge, made up of the remnants and scraps of the larder.
Hence Any inconsistent or ridiculous medley.
A hash of various kinds of meats, a ragout.
A hash of various kinds of meats, a ragout .

gallinacean.explanation: One of the Gallinaceæ, Gallinacei , or Gallinæ.
One of the Gallinae or gallinaceous birds.
One of the Gallinae or gallinaceous birds .
heavy-bodied largely ground-feeding domestic or game birds

gallinacei.explanation: Gallinaceæ or Gallinæ; sometimes the same as Rasores .

gallinaceous.explanation: Of, belonging to, or characteristic of the order Galliformes, which includes poultry, pheasants, and grouse.
Resembling the domestic fowls and pheasants; of or pertaining to the Gallinae.
related to the genus galina , poultry; notably said of the order Galliformes .
of or relating to or resembling a gallinacean

gallinae.explanation: Didus, Pavo, Meleagris, Crax, Phasianus, Numida , and Tetrao. It is practically the same as the later order Gallinaceæ , or Rasores without the pigeons.
Gallinaceæ of authors, from which sundry non-conformable genera have been eliminated; the same as the Alectoromorphæ of Huxley.
An order of birds, including the common domestic fowls, pheasants, grouse, quails, and allied forms; -- sometimes called Rasores .

gallinazo.explanation: The Spanish-American name of an American vulture of either of the genera Cathartes and Catharista , as the turkey-buzzard, Cathartes aura , or the carrion-crow, Catharista atrata.

galline.explanation: of, or pertaining to, the chicken

galling.explanation: Causing extreme irritation or chagrin; vexing.
Fitted to gall or chafe; vexing; harassing; irritating.

gallingness.explanation: The quality or character of being galling or irritating.

gallinipper.explanation: A large biting mosquito, especially Psorophora ciliata of the Americas.
A large mosquitolike insect such as a crane fly.
any large insect that bites, for example the mosquito

gallinula.explanation: The typical genus of the subfamily Gallinulinæ , formerly coextensive therewith, now restricted to such species as the common gallinule of Europe, G. chloropus , or that of America, G. galeata.

gallinule.explanation: Any of various waterbirds of the family Rallidae, frequenting swampy regions and characteristically having dark iridescent plumage and a colorful area where the bill extends onto the forehead.
A bird of the subfamily Gallinulinæ , and especially of the genus Gallinula.

One of several wading birds, having long, webless toes, and a frontal shield, belonging to the family Rallidae . They are remarkable for running rapidly over marshes and on floating plants. The purple gallinule of America is Ionornis Martinica , that of the Old World is Porphyrio porphyrio . The common European gallinule ( Gallinula chloropus ) is also called moor hen , water hen , water rail , moor coot , night bird , and erroneously dabchick . Closely related to it is the Florida gallinule ( Gallinula galeata ).
Several species of birds in the genera Porphyrio and Gallinula of the family Rallidae .
any of various small aquatic birds of the genus Gallinula distinguished from rails by a frontal shield and a resemblance to domestic hens

gallipot.explanation: A small glazed earthenware jar formerly used by druggists for medicaments.
A small pot or vessel, painted and glazed, used by druggists and apothecaries for holding medicines.
A glazed earthen pot or vessel, used by druggists and apothecaries for containing medicines, etc.
A small glazed earthenware jar once used by apothecaries for holding ointment and medicine

gallisin.explanation: In chem. , a substance analogous to dextrine, obtained by fermenting with yeast a solution of commercial glucose or starch-sugar and adding to the residual liquid absolute alcohol in excess.

gallium.explanation: A rare metallic element that is liquid near room temperature, expands on solidifying, and is found as a trace element in coal, bauxite, and other minerals. It is used in semiconductor technology, as a component of various low-melting alloys, and in producing blue light-emitting diodes. Atomic number 31; atomic weight 69.72; melting point 29.78°C; boiling point 2,403°C; specific gravity 5.907; valence 2, 3. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
Chemical symbol, Ga; specific gravity, 5.935. A rare malleable metal, discovered by means of spectrum analysis in 1875 by M. Lecoq de Boisbaudran in the zinc-blende of Pierrefitte in the Pyrenees.

The discovery of this chemical element was peculiarly interesting, as furnishing striking evidence of the soundness of the theoretical views, as to the relations of the elements, which led Mendeléjeff in 1869 to predict the existence of such a substance and give a description of the properties it would be found to exhibit: his prediction required scarcely any correction when the element was actually discovered.

A rare metallic element, found combined in certain zinc ores. It is white, hard, and malleable, resembling aluminium, and remarkable for its low melting point (86° F., 30° C.). Symbol, Ga; at. wt., 69.9. Gallium is chiefly trivalent, resembling aluminium and indium. It was predicted with most of its properties, under the name eka-aluminium , by the Russian chemist Mendelyeev on the basis of the periodic law. This prediction was verified in its discovery (in 1875) by the French chemist Lecoq de Boisbaudran by its characteristic spectrum (two violet lines), in an examination of a zinc blende from the Pyrenees.
A chemical element (symbol Ga) with an atomic number of 31; a soft bluish metal.
a rare silvery (usually trivalent) metallic element; brittle at low temperatures but liquid above room temperature; occurs in trace amounts in bauxite and zinc ores

gallivant.explanation: To roam about in search of pleasure or amusement. synonym : wander .
To play the beau; to wait upon the ladies; also, to roam about for pleasure without any definite plan.
To roam about for pleasure without any definite plan .
wander aimlessly in search of pleasure

gallivanted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gallivant .

gallivants.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gallivant .

gallivat.explanation: A large boat used in the far East, rarely exceeding 70 tons in burden, two-masted, and commonly carrying small swivel-guns. The Malay pirates employ these boats on account of their swiftness.
A small armed vessel, with sails and oars, -- used on the Malabar coast.
A small armed vessel , with sails and oars , used on the Malabar coast.

gallivorous.explanation: entomology , devouring the interior of galls: applied to the larvæ of gall-producing insects.

galliwasp.explanation: Any of several elongate, short-legged lizards of the subfamily Diploglossinae, native to wet regions of the West Indies, Central America, and northern South America.
A lizard, Celestus occiduus , about a foot long, remarkably stout and plump, and brown in general color.
A West Indian lizard ( Celestus occiduus ), about a foot long, imagined by the natives to be venomous.
Any of the lizards in the genus Celestus

gallize.explanation: wine-manuf. , to add (to the unfermented grape-juice) sufficient water to reduce it to a given standard of acidity, and then sufficient sugar to bring the whole to the standard of sweetness scientifically determined to be the most advantageous.
In wine making, to add water and sugar to (unfermented grape juice) so as to increase the quantity of wine produced.

gallnut.explanation: A round gall produced on the leaves and shoots of various species of the oak tree. See gall , and nutgall .
slight protuberance on a tree, caused by insects

gallocyanine.explanation: A coal-tar color used in dyeing, obtained by the action of nitroso-dimethyl-aniline on tannic acid.

galloflavin.explanation: A yellow compound, formed by oxidation of gallic acid , that is an inhibitor of lactate dehydrogenase

galloglass.explanation: An armed retainer or mercenary who serves an Irish chieftain.

gallomaniac.explanation: One who is very zealous for France and French interests and ways.

gallon.explanation: A unit of volume in the US Customary System, used in liquid measure, equal to 4 quarts (3.785 liters).
A unit of volume in the British Imperial System, used in liquid and dry measure, equal to 4 quarts (4.546 liters).
A container with a capacity of one gallon.
The butter-bur or butterdock, Petasites Petasites.
An English measure of capacity for dry or liquid substances, but usually for liquids, containing 4 quarts.
A measure of land. A gallon of land is supposed to have been the amount of land proper to sow a gallon of grain in.
A measure of capacity, containing four quarts; -- used, for the most part, in liquid measure, but sometimes in dry measure.
A unit of volume , equivalent to eight pints
231 cubic inches or approximately 3.785 liters for liquids (a "U.S. liquid gallon")
one-eighth of a U.S. bushel or approximately 4.405 liters for dry goods (a "U.S. dry gallon").
a British imperial capacity measure (liquid or dry) equal to 4 quarts or 4.545 liters
United States liquid unit equal to 4 quarts or 3.785 liters

gallonage.explanation: Amount or capacity stated or reckoned in gallons: as, the gallonage of a tank, or the gallonage of an oil-well during the period named.
An amount of liquid measured in gallons

galloon.explanation: A narrow band or braid used as trimming and commonly made of lace, metallic thread, or embroidery.
1. Originally, worsted lace, especially a closely woven lace like a narrow ribbon or tape for binding.

A fabric similar to the above, of wool, silk, tinsel, cotton, or a combination of any of these, A kind of gold or silver lace with a continuous even edge on each side, used on uniforms, liveries, etc.
A narrow tapelike fabric used for binding hats, shoes, etc., -- sometimes made ornamental.
A similar bordering or binding of rich material, such as gold lace.
A braided trimming with bullion thread, used on men's coats in the eighteenth century, on women's apparel in the nineteenth, and on such furnishings as draperies or cushions .

gallop.explanation: A gait of a horse, faster than a canter, in which all four feet are off the ground at the same time during each stride.
A fast running motion of other quadrupeds.
A ride taken at a gallop.
A rapid pace.
A disordered rhythm of the heart characterized by three or four distinct heart sounds in each cycle and resembling the sound of a galloping horse.
To cause to gallop.
To go or move at a gallop.
To move or progress swiftly.
galloped his horse all the way.
A leaping or springing gait or movement of horses (or other quadrupeds), in which the two fore feet are lifted from the ground in succession, and then the two hind feet in the same succession.
A ride at a gallop; the act of riding an animal on the gallop.
A kind of dance. See galop .
To cause to gallop.
A mode of running by a quadruped, particularly by a horse, by lifting alternately the fore feet and the hind feet, in successive leaps or bounds.
a slow or gentle gallop.
To move or run in the mode called a gallop; as a horse; to go at a gallop; to run or move with speed.
To ride a horse at a gallop.
Fig.: To go rapidly or carelessly, as in making a hasty examination.
The fastest gait of a horse .
A two-beat stride during which all four legs are off the ground simultaneously
To ride at a galloping pace
To make electrical or other utility lines sway and/or move up and down violently, usually due to a combination of high winds and ice accrual on the lines.
To run very fast
ride at a galloping pace
cause to move at full gallop
a fast gait of a horse; a two-beat stride during which all four legs are off the ground simultaneously
go at galloping speed

gallopade.explanation: In the manège , a sidelong or curveting kind of gallop.
A sprightly kind of dance, or the music adapted to it. See galop .
I horsemanship, a sidelong or curveting kind of gallop.
A kind of dance; also, music to the dance; a galop.
To perform the dance called gallopade.
A type of dance, also known as the galop
To perform the dance called gallopade.

galloped.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gallop .

galloper.explanation: A mounted (or unmounted) despatch-bearer on a battle-field; an aide-decamp.
One who or that which gallops.
In artillery , a carriage on which small guns are conveyed, fitted with shafts so as to be drawn without limbers. [Eng.]
One who, or that which, gallops.
A carriage on which very small guns were formerly mounted, the gun resting on the shafts, without a limber.
a light gun, supported on a galloper, -- formerly attached to British infantry regiments.

galloperdix.explanation: A genus of gallinaceous birds, the hill-partridges, of the subfamily Perdicinæ , of India and Ceylon, related to the jungle-fowl, but having no comb or wattles.

gallophile.explanation: One who is friendly to France.

gallophobe.explanation: One who hates or fears France.

gallophobia.explanation: Abhorrence or fear of France or French ways or institutions.

galloping.explanation: Of or resembling a gallop, especially in rhythm or rapidity.
Developing or progressing at an accelerated rate.
Of or relating to a disease that progresses rapidly toward a fatal conclusion.
The action of a horse that gallops; a running at a gallop.
galloping consumption (that is, a consumption that proceeds rapidly to a fatal termination).
Going at a gallop; progressing rapidly.

gallops.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gallop .

gallotannic.explanation: Pertaining to the tannin or nutgalls.
Pertaining to the tannin or nutgalls .

gallous.explanation: fit to be hanged ; wicked ; mischievous

gallovidian.explanation: A native or inhabitant of Galloway.

gallow.explanation: To fright or terrify. See gally , v. t.

gallowglass.explanation: A soldier or armed retainer of a chief in ancient Ireland, the Hebrides, or other Gaelic countries.
A heavy-armed foot soldier from Ireland and the Western Isles in the time of Edward �
A mercenary warrior élite among Gaelic-Norse clans residing in the Western Isles of Scotland and Scottish Highlands from the mid 13th century to the end of the 16th century.

gallows.explanation: A device usually consisting of two upright posts supporting a crossbeam from which a noose is suspended and used for execution by hanging; a gallows tree.
A similar structure used for supporting or suspending.
Execution by hanging.
gallows poor.
Specifically, on the great sheep-raising stations of Australasia, a high wooden frame on which the carcasses of butchered cattle or sheep are suspended; a meat-gallows.

A wooden frame on which criminals are executed by hanging, usually consisting of two posts and a cross-beam on the top, or of a single post with a projecting arm, from which the criminal is suspended by a rope fastened about his neck: a plural used as a singular, and having the double plural gallowses.
A similar contrivance for suspending objects.
Nautical , same as gallows-bitts .
In coal-mining , a set of timbers consisting of two upright pieces or props and a bar or crown-tree laid across their tops so as to support the roof in a level or in any other excavation.
In printing , a low trestle attached to old forms of hand printing-presses, to sustain the tympan.
A central core formed of several cornstalks interlaced diagonally (while uncut) to serve as a stool or support for cut maize which is placed about it in forming a shock.
plural A pair of braces for supporting the trousers. Also galluses .
A wretch who deserves to be hanged; a gallows-bird.
A frame from which is suspended the rope with which criminals are executed by hanging, usually consisting of two upright posts and a crossbeam on the top; also, a like frame for suspending anything.
A wretch who deserves the gallows.
The rest for the tympan when raised.
A pair of suspenders or braces.
a person who deserves the gallows.
one of two or more frames amidships on deck for supporting spare spars; -- called also gallows , gallows top , gallows frame , etc.
Gallows bitts.
the gallows.
Wooden framework on which persons are put to death by hanging .
Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gallow .
an instrument of execution consisting of a wooden frame from which a condemned person is executed by hanging

galls.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gall .

gallstone.explanation: A small, hard, pathological concretion, composed chiefly of cholesterol, calcium salts, and bile pigments, formed in the gallbladder or in a bile duct.
A concretion formed in the gall-bladder; a biliary calculus.
A concretion, or calculus, formed in the gall bladder or biliary passages. See calculus , n., 1.
A small, hard object, in the shape of a pebble , that sometimes forms in the gallbladder or bile duct ; composed of cholesterol , bile pigments and calcium salts .
a calculus formed in the gall bladder or its ducts

gallus.explanation: A genus of gallinaceous birds, of the family Phasianidæ , having as type the domestic hen, G. domesticus , some if not all varieties of which are the modified descendants of Gallus ferrugineus or bankivus; the jungle-fowl.
In ichthyology , a genus of carangoid fishes.
In classical antiquity , a priest of Cybele.
Fit to be hanged ; wicked ; mischievous .
elastic straps that hold trousers up (usually used in the plural)
common domestic birds and related forms

galluses.explanation: gallowses , plural of gallows , in sense 7.

gallwort.explanation: The common toad-flax, Linaria Linaria : so named from its bitterness.

gally.explanation: An obsolete or occasional spelling of galley .

galoot.explanation: A person, especially a clumsy or uncouth one.
A fellow: a term of humorous contempt, often implying something awkward, silly, or weak in the person so designated.
A noisy, swaggering, or worthless fellow; a rowdy.

galop.explanation: A lively dance in duple time, popular in the 1800s.
A lively round dance of German origin.
Music for such a dance, or in its rhythm, which is duple and quick.
A kind of lively dance, in 2-4 time; also, the music to the dance.
A lively French country dance of the nineteenth century, a forerunner of the polka , combining a glissade with a chassé on alternate feet, usually in a fast 2/4 time.

galosh.explanation: A sturdy heavy-soled boot or shoe.
A kind of clog or patten worn in the middle ages as a protection against wet, and common, because of the practice of making shoes of cloth, silk, or the like, or of ornamental leather.
In present use, any overshoe; a rubber: usually in the plural.
A strip of material, as leather, running around a shoe at and above the sole, as for protection or ornament.
A waterproof overshoe used to provide protection from rain or snow .
A waterproof rubber boot, intended to be worn in wet or muddy conditions.
a waterproof overshoe that protects shoes from water or snow

galoshe.explanation: Hence, an overshoe worn in wet weather.
A gaiter , or legging , covering the upper part of the shoe and part of the leg.

galt.explanation: In geology , the lowest division of the Upper Cretaceous series.

galtonia.explanation: A genus of plants of the family Liliaceæ , closely allied to the hyacinths, and formerly referred to the same genus.

galuchat.explanation: A kind of shark's skin or shagreen usually dyed green, used to cover cases, boxes, etc. As prepared it retains the tubercles with which it is studded in the natural state.

galumph.explanation: To move or run clumsily or heavily.

galumphed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of galumph .

galumphs.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of galumph .

galvanic.explanation: Of or relating to direct-current electricity, especially when produced chemically.
Having the effect of an electric shock.
Produced as if by an electric shock.
electricity ): same as voltaic , a word in more common use.
Of or pertaining to, or exhibiting the phenomena of, galvanism; employing or producing electrical currents.
an apparatus for generating electrical currents by the mutual action of certain liquids and metals; -- now usually called voltaic battery . See Battery .
the voltaic pile. See under Voltaic .
Of or pertaining to galvanism ; electric
affected by emotion as if by electricity; thrilling
pertaining to or producing electric current by chemical action

galvanise.explanation: To shock or stimulate into sudden activity.
: To coat with a thin layer of metal by electrochemical means.

galvanised.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of galvanise .

galvaniser.explanation: a skilled worker who coats iron or steel with zinc
a leader who stimulates and excites people to action

galvanising.explanation: affected by emotion as if by electricity; thrilling

galvanism.explanation: Direct-current electricity, especially when produced chemically.
Therapeutic application of direct-current electricity, especially the electric stimulation of nerves and muscle.
That branch of the science of electricity which treats of electric currents more especially as arising from chemical action, as from the combination of metals with acids.

In medicine , the application of an electric current from a number of cells: in distinction from faradism or the use of a series of brief alternating currents from an induction-coil, and from franklinism or the charging from a frictional or Holtz machine.
Electricity excited by the mutual action of certain liquids and metals; dynamical electricity.
The branch of physical science which treats of dynamical elecricity, or the properties and effects of electrical currents.
the therapeutic application of electricity to the body (as in the treatment of various forms of paralysis)

galvanization.explanation: The act of galvanizing, or the state of being so affected. Also spelled galvanisation .
Therapeutic application of the constant electric current by means of the active electrode passed slowly to and fro over the surface.
The act of process of galvanizing.
The act or process of galvanizing .
either the work of covering with metal by the use of a galvanic current or the coating of iron with zinc to protect it from rusting
stimulation that arouses a person to lively action

galvanize.explanation: To stimulate or shock with an electric current.
To arouse to awareness or action; spur.
To coat (iron or steel) with rust-resistant zinc.
To affect with galvanism; to subject to the action of electrical currents.
To plate, as with gold, silver, etc., by means of electricity.
To restore to consciousness by galvanic action (as from a state of suspended animation); hence, to stimulate or excite to a factitious animation or activity.

formerly, iron coated with zink by electrical deposition; now more commonly, iron coated with zink by plunging into a bath of melted zink, after its surface has been cleaned by friction with the aid of dilute acid.
To coat with a thin layer of metal by electrochemical means; to electroplate .

One who, or that which, galvanizes .

Cautery effected by a knife or needle heated by the passage of a galvanic current.
Cautery by means of a knife or needle heated by a galvanic current .

galvanoglyphy.explanation: A method of producing an electroplate which may be used in a printing-press.

galvanograph.explanation: A plate formed by the galvanographic process.
An impression taken from such a plate.
A copperplate produced by the method of galvanography; also, a picture printed from such a plate.
A picture printed from a plate of this kind.

galvanography.explanation: A process for producing plates which will give impressions after the manner of a plate used in copperplate engraving.

gamete.explanation: A reproductive cell having the haploid number of chromosomes, especially a mature sperm or egg capable of fusing with a gamete of the opposite sex to produce a zygote.
A general term for the mature germ-cells, either male (spermatozoön) or female (ovum), which unite to form the zygote.

In biology , a propagative protoplasmic body which unites with a similar or dissimilar body to form a spore, called a zygote, the latter being either a zygospore or an oöspore. Mobile gametes resembling zoöspores are called planogametes or zoögametes.

A sexual cell or germ cell having a single set of unpaired chromosomes; a conjugating cell which unites with another of like or unlike character to form a new individual. In Bot., gamete designates esp. the similar sex cells of the lower thallophytes which unite by conjugation, forming a zygospore . The gametes of higher plants are of two sorts, sperm (male) and egg (female); their union is called fertilization , and the resulting zygote an oöspore . In Zoöl., gamete is most commonly used of the sexual cells of certain Protozoa, though also extended to the germ cells of higher forms.
A reproductive cell (male ( sperm ) or female ( egg )) that has only half the usual number of chromosomes .
a mature sexual reproductive cell having a single set of unpaired chromosomes

gametocyst.explanation: A unicellular structure, found in the algæ and fungi, which produces only uninucleate gametes: distinguished from gametangium .

gametocyte.explanation: A cell from which gametes develop by meiotic division, especially a spermatocyte or an oocyte.
An immature animal or plant cell that develops into a gamete by meiosis.
A diploid germ cell that divides by meiosis into a gamete .
an immature animal or plant cell that develops into a gamete by meiosis

In the alternation of generations in plants, that generation or phase which bears sex organs and produces gametes. In the lower plants, as the algæ, the gametophyte is the conspicuous part of the plant body; in mosses it is the so-called moss plant; in ferns it is reduced to a small, early perishing body; and in seed plants it is usually microscopic or rudimentary.
A plant (or the haploid phase in its life cycle ) which produces gametes by mitosis in order to produce a zygote .
the gamete-bearing individual or phase in the life cycle of a plant having alternation of generations

to secure a weak point; to repair a defect.

“(Webster); cf. garnet-apple . The ult. source is the same; granat and grenade are doublets.] A common mineral species embracing many varieties, which, while conforming to the same general formula, differ in composition and hence also in color, specific gravity, and fusibility.

A mineral having many varieties differing in color and in their constituents, but with the same crystallization (isometric), and conforming to the same general chemical formula. gasolene.explanation: The lightest volatile liquid product commonly obtained from the distillation of petroleum.

Its principal hydrocarbon constituents are hexane and heptane, C 6 H 14 and C 7 H 16 , in varying proportions. It boils between 149° and 194° F. and gives off a vapor under atmospheric tension at all temperatures. The vapor of gasolene is 3.05 times as heavy as air. The volatile elements distil off on storage, unless the containing-vessels are very tight. Its calorific power is about 18,000 B. T. U. It is much used in the internal-combustion motors of motor-cars and motor-boats.
a volatile flammable mixture of hydrocarbons (hexane and heptane and octane etc.) derived from petroleum; used mainly as a fuel in internal-combustion engines

gasoline.explanation: A volatile mixture of flammable liquid hydrocarbons derived chiefly from crude petroleum and used principally as a fuel for internal-combustion engines.

A highly volatile mixture of fluid hydrocarbons, obtained mostly from petroleum, as also by the distillation of bituminous coal. It is used as a fuel for most automobiles and for many other vehicles with internal combustion engines. The gasoline of commerce is typically blended with additives to improve its performance in internal combustion engines. Gasoline was also used in the early 1900's in making air gas, and in giving illuminating power to water gas. See carburetor .
( North America ) A flammable liquid consisting of a mixture of refined petroleum hydrocarbons , mainly used as a motor fuel ; petrol .
a volatile flammable mixture of hydrocarbons (hexane and heptane and octane etc.) derived from petroleum; used mainly as a fuel in internal-combustion engines
