An instrument for measuring the quantity of gas employed in any chemical experiment.
A reservoir or storehouse for gas, especially for the ordinary illuminating gas produced in gas-works, which supplies the various pipes employed in lighting streets and houses.

An apparatus for holding and measuring of gas; in gas works, a huge iron cylinder closed at one end and having the other end immersed in water, in which it is made to rise or fall, according to the volume of gas it contains, or the pressure required.
Any of various instruments used to measure the flow of gas through pipelines .
a meter for measuring the amount of gas flowing through a particular pipe
a large gas-tight spherical or cylindrical tank for holding gas to be used as fuel

gasometric.explanation: Of or pertaining to the measurement of gases.

gasometry.explanation: The science, art, or practice of measuring gases.
The art or practice of measuring gases; also, the science which treats of the nature and properties of these elastic fluids.
The measurement of gases ; the determination of the relative proportion of gases in a mixture .

gasoscope.explanation: An instrument for indicating the presence of gas in buildings, mines, etc.
An apparatus for detecting the presence of any dangerous gas, from a gas leak in a coal mine or a dwelling house.
An apparatus for detecting the presence of dangerous gas , as for example in a mine or in a house .

gasp.explanation: To draw in the breath sharply, as from shock.
To utter in a breathless manner.
A short convulsive intake or catching of the breath.
The act of catching the breath with open mouth; labored respiration; a short, convulsive catching of the breath.
To open the mouth wide in catching the breath, or in laborious respiration; to labor for breath; to respire convulsively; to pant violently.
To pant with eagerness; to show vehement desire.
To emit or utter with gasps; -- with forth , out , away , etc.
The act of opening the mouth convulsively to catch the breath; a labored respiration; a painful catching of the breath.
A short, sudden intake of breath.
( slang ): A draw or drag on a cigarette (or gasper ).
: To draw in the breath suddenly , as if from a shock .
: To speak in a breathless manner
a short labored intake of breath with the mouth open
breathe noisily, as when one is exhausted

gasparillo.explanation: In Trinidad, the wood of a species of Licania , a rosaceous genus resembling Chrysobalanus.
In Jamaica, a species of Esenbeckia , a rutaceous genus, the bark of which has tonic properties.

gasped.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gasp .

gasper.explanation: A person or animal that gasps.
One who is aroused by asphyxiation .

gaspereau.explanation: A name given in New Brunswick and parts of Canada to the herring, Clupea vernalis.

gasping.explanation: The act by which one gasps .

gasps.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gasp .

gassed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gas .

gassendist.explanation: A follower or supporter of Gassendi, a French metaphysician (1592–1655) who defended Epicureanism.

gasser.explanation: A well or drilling that yields natural gas.

gasserian.explanation: Gasserian ganglion, often mistakenly called the Casserian. See ganglion .
Relating to Casserio (L. Gasserius), the discover of the Gasserian ganglion.
a large ganglion, at the root of the trigeminal, or fifth cranial, nerve.

gasses.explanation: Alternative spelling of gases . Plural form of gas .
Alternative spelling of gases . Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gas .

gassier.explanation: comparative form of gassy : more gassy

gassiest.explanation: superlative form of gassy : most gassy .

gassiness.explanation: The state or property of being gassy .

gassing.explanation: The process of singeing lace, cotton, yarn, etc., to remove the hairy filaments.
The act or practice of talking in an idle, empty manner; talking nonsense.
The fumigating of fruit-trees by means of hydrocyanic-acid gas, to destroy insects.
The evolution of gas from the plates of a storage or secondary cell.
The process of passing cotton goods between two rollers and exposing them to numerous minute jets of gas to burn off the small fibers; any similar process of singeing.
The liberation of hydrogen from an overcharged battery due to electrolysis of the electrolyte .
The process of passing cotton goods between two rollers and exposing them to numerous minute jets of gas to burn off the small fibres .
the deliberate act of poisoning some person or animal with gas
the process of interacting with gas

gassy.explanation: Of a beverage , containing dissolved gas (usually carbon dioxide ).
suffering from excessive gas in the alimentary canal

gast.explanation: A Middle English form of ghost .
To make aghast; to frighten; to terrify. See aghast .

gasted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gast .

gaster.explanation: The portion of the abdomen behind the petiole in ants and other hymenopterous insects.
The stomach; the belly or abdomen: rarely used alone, but entering into many compounds and derivatives referring to the stomach, abdomen, or abdominal organs, or a part likened thereto.
In certain hymenopterous insects, such as ants ( Formicidæ ), the abdomen exclusive of the stem, or pedicel.
the part of the abdomen behind the petiole in hymenopterous insects

gasterolichenes.explanation: Gasteromycetes , especially of Lycoperdon. Two genera and three species are known.

gasteromycete.explanation: Any of the obsolete class Gasteromycetes of fungi .
any fungus of the class Gasteromycetes

gasteromycetes.explanation: mycology , one of the principal divisions of the Basidiomycetes , characterized by having the hymenium inclosed, lining small cavities, which are formed within a peridium.
An order of fungi, in which the spores are borne inside a sac called the peridium, as in the puffballs.
fungi in which the hymenium is enclosed until after spores have matured: puffballs; earth stars; stinkhorn fungi

gasterophilus.explanation: A leading genus of dipterous insects, of the family Œstridæ , or bot-flies, several species of which infest the horse and ass.
The type genus of the Gasterophilidae , comprising the horse botflies.
type genus of the Gasterophilidae: horse botflies

gasteropod.explanation: A gastropodous mollusk; any one of the Gasteropoda.
gasteropodan, gastropodan. [The form gastropod is more commonly used.]

gasteropoda.explanation: snails and slugs and their relatives

gasterosteid.explanation: A fish of the family Gasterosteidæ ; a stickleback.

gasterosteoid.explanation: A fish of the family Gasterosteidæ ; a gasterosteid or stickleback.

gasterosteus.explanation: The typical genus of the family Gasterosteidæ , by some extended to include all the species of that family, but by others restricted to the short species with pelvic bones forming a triangular plate, and two dorsal spines, as G. aculeatus : so called from the extension of the pubic bones along the ventral aspect of the fish, making the belly bony. See stickleback .
type genus of the family Gasterosteidae

gasterotheca.explanation: In entomology , the abdomen-case, or that part of the integument of a pupa which covers the abdomen.

gastight.explanation: So tightly fitted as to preclude the escape of gas; impervious to gas.
not allowing air or gas to pass in or out

gastornis.explanation: A genus of gigantic Eocene birds found in the conglomerate below the plastic clay of the Paris basin.
A genus of large eocene birds from the Paris basin.

gastradenitis.explanation: Inflammation of the glands of the stomach, especially when caused by acute poisoning with arsenic or phosphorus.

gastraea.explanation: In biology , a hypothetical animal form assumed by Haeckel as the ancestor of all metazoic animals — that is, of those which pass through or attain to the morphological form of a gastrula. See gastrula .

A primeval larval form; a double-walled sac from which, according to the hypothesis of Haeckel, man and all other animals, that in the first stages of their individual evolution pass through a two-layered structural stage, or gastrula form, must have descended. This idea constitutes the Gastræa theory of Haeckel. See gastrula .

gastralgia.explanation: In pathology , neuralgia of the stomach; more generally, pain of any kind in the stomach or belly; belly-ache.
Pain in the stomach or epigastrium, as in gastric disorders.
an ache localized in the stomach or abdominal region

gastrectasia.explanation: Dilatation of the stomach. Also called gastrectasis .

gastrectomy.explanation: Surgical excision of part or all of the stomach.
In surgery , the resection of a portion of the stomach, as for instance a cancerous pylorus.
Removal or partial removal of the stomach .
surgical removal of all or part of the stomach

gastrelcosis.explanation: In pathology , ulceration of the stomach.

gastric.explanation: Of, relating to, or associated with the stomach.
Of, pertaining to, or situated near, the stomach.
the conversion of the albuminous portion of food in the stomach into soluble and diffusible products by the solvent action of gastric juice.
a fever attended with prominent gastric symptoms; -- a name applied to certain forms of typhoid fever; also, to catarrhal inflammation of the stomach attended with fever.

a thin, watery fluid, with an acid reaction, secreted by a peculiar set of glands contained in the mucous membrane of the stomach. It consists mainly of dilute hydrochloric acid and the ferment pepsin. It is the most important digestive fluid in the body, but acts only on proteid foods.
a form of remittent fever with pronounced stomach symptoms.
Of or relating to the stomach .
relating to or involving the stomach

gastricism.explanation: In pathology , gastric affections in general.
An old medical theory by which almost all diseases were attributed to the accumulation of impurities in the stomach and bowels.

gastriloquist.explanation: One who appears to speak from his stomach; a ventriloquist.

gastriloquy.explanation: A voice or utterance which appears to proceed from the stomach; ventriloquy.
A voice or utterance which appears to proceed from the stomach ; ventriloquy .

gastrin.explanation: A hormone secreted by glands in the mucous membrane of the stomach that stimulates the production of gastric juice.
A hormone that stimulates the production of gastric acid in the stomach
polypeptide hormone secreted by the mucous lining of the stomach; when peptides and amino acids are present in the small intestine the secretion of gastric acid is stimulated

gastritis.explanation: Chronic or acute inflammation of the stomach, especially of the mucous membrane of the stomach.
In pathology , inflammation of the stomach.
Inflammation of the stomach, esp. of its mucuos membrane.
Inflammation of the lining of the stomach , characterised by nausea , loss of appetite, and upper abdominal discomfort or pain.
inflammation of the lining of the stomach; nausea and loss of appetite and discomfort after eating

gastrocele.explanation: In pathology , a hernia of the stomach.
A cavity in the embryonic gastrula
A hernia in part of the stomach

gastrocnemius.explanation: The largest, most prominent muscle of the calf of the leg, the action of which extends the foot and bends the knee.

A superficial muscle of the posterior tibial region, arising from the femur and inserted into the tarsus, the action of which extends the foot upon the leg, and flexes the leg upon the thigh: so called from its character in man, in whom it forms, together with the soleus, the protuberant or “bellying” part of the calf of the leg.
The muscle which makes the greater part of the calf of the leg.
The muscle at the back of the calf , whose insertion is the Achilles tendon at the heel .
the muscle in the back part of the leg that forms the greater part of the calf; responsible for the plantar flexion of the foot

gastrocolic.explanation: anatomy , pertaining to the stomach and to the colon.
Pertaining to both the stomach and the colon.
Of or pertaining to the gastrointestinal tract and colon .

gastrocolostomy.explanation: Establishment by operation of a communication between the colon and the stomach.

gastrocystis.explanation: In embryology , the germ-vesicle or blastodermic vesicle of a mammal.

gastrodermis.explanation: The endodermis of the cnidarian gut

gastrodialysis.explanation: Sloughing of the mucous membrane of the stomach.

gastrodidymus.explanation: In teratology , a double monster joined in the abdominal region.

gastrodisc.explanation: The endoderm of the vertebrate embryo in the discogastrula stage, that is, when both the ectoderm and the underlying endoderm are spread out on the yolk in the form of a disk.
That part of blastoderm where the hypoblast appears like a small disk on the inner face of the epibladst.

gastroduodenal.explanation: Of or relating to the stomach and the duodenum.
anatomy , pertaining to the stomach and duodenum: as, the gastroduodenal artery.
Pertaining to the stomach and duodenum.
Relating to, or connecting the stomach and the duodenum
of or relating to the stomach and the duodenum

gastroduodenitis.explanation: In pathology , inflammation of the stomach and duodenum.
Inflammation of the stomach and duodenum. It is one of the most frequent causes of jaundice.
inflammation of the stomach and duodenum

gastroduodenostomy.explanation: Establishment by operation of a communication between the stomach and the duodenum elsewhere than at the pylorus.
The surgical creation of a new connection between the stomach and the duodenum .

gastrodynia.explanation: In pathology , pain in the stomach; gastralgia.

gastroelytrotomy.explanation: The operation of cutting into the upper part of the vagina, through the abdomen (without opening the peritoneum), for the purpose of removing a fetus. It is a substitute for the Cæsarean operation, and less dangerous.
The operation of cutting into the upper part of the vagina , through the abdomen (without opening the peritoneum ), for the purpose of removing a foetus .

gastroenteritis.explanation: Inflammation of the mucous membrane of the stomach and intestines.
In pathology , inflammation of the stomach and intestines.
Inflammation of the lining membrane of the stomach and the intestines.
Inflammation of the mucous membranes of the stomach and intestine ; often caused by an infection .
inflammation of the stomach and intestines; can be caused by Salmonella enteritidis

gastroenterocolitis.explanation: inflammation of the stomach , small intestines , and colon

gastroenterologist.explanation: A physician who specializes in gastroenterology
a physician who specializes in diseases of the gastrointestinal tract

gastroenterology.explanation: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis and treatment of diseases and disorders of the digestive system.
The study of the digestive system, from mouth to anus. May also include the study of accessory organs: pancreas, liver, gallbladder and bile ducts.
the branch of medicine that studies the gastrointestinal tract and its diseases

gastroenterostomy.explanation: The surgical procedure for making a connection between the stomach and the jejunum , usually as part of an operation , performed at the same time as a partial gastrectomy .
surgical creation of an opening between the stomach wall and the small intestines; performed when the normal opening has been eliminated

gastroepiploic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the stomach and omentum.
Of or pertaining to the stomach and omentum .

gastroesophageal.explanation: Of or relating to the stomach and esophagus.
Of or relating to the stomach and to the esophagus .
of or relating to or involving the stomach and esophagus

gastrograph.explanation: A device for recording the movements of the stomach during digestion.

gastrohepatic.explanation: Pertaining to the stomach and liver; hepatogastric.
Of or pertaining to both the stomach and the liver .

gastrohepatitis.explanation: Simultaneous inflammation of both stomach and liver.

gastrohyperneuria.explanation: Increased activity of the stomach due to disorder of the nerve-supply.

gastrohysteropexy.explanation: Operative fixation of the fundus of the uterus to the anterior abdominal wall, in order to correct a displacement of that organ.

gastrohysterotomy.explanation: In surgery , the Cæsarean section (which see, under Cæsarean ).

gastrointestinal.explanation: Of or relating to the stomach and intestines.
Of or pertaining to the stomach and intestines; gastroenteric.
Of or pertaining to the stomach and intestines .
of or relating to the stomach and intestines

gastrojejunal.explanation: Of or pertaining to the stomach and the jejunum

gastrojejunostomy.explanation: Establishment, of communication between the stomach and some portion of the jejunum.
A form of anastomosis in which a connection is made between the stomach and the jejunum

gastrolater.explanation: One whose god is his belly.

gastrolith.explanation: A pathological stony mass formed in the stomach; gastric calculus.
A small stone found in the stomach of some reptiles, fish, and birds that aids in digestion by helping grind ingested food material.

A gastric concretion or calculus; a stony concretion in the stomach; a bezoar; specifically, one of the concretions called crabs' eyes in the stomach of some crustaceans, as the crawfish. See eye , n. , 12.
rocks which are or have been held inside the digestive tract of an animal to aid in buoyancy or food processing.

gastrolobium.explanation: A genus of leguminous shrubs peculiar to western Australia, some of which are occasionally cultivated in greenhouses.
any of various Australian evergreen shrubs of the genus Gastrolobium having whorled compound leaves poisonous to livestock and showy yellow to deep reddish-orange flowers followed by two-seeded pods

gastrologer.explanation: One who is versed in gastrology.

gastrologist.explanation: One who is versed in gastrology, or skilled in catering to the demands of the stomach.
A physician who devotes special attention to the diagnosis and treatment of diseases of the stomach.

gastrology.explanation: The medical study of the stomach and its diseases.
The art of cookery or of catering to the demands of the stomach.
The scientific study of diseases of the stomach and of their treatment.
The science which treats of the structure and functions of the stomach; a treatise of the stomach.
the scientific study of the stomach

gastrolysis.explanation: The act or process of freeing the stomach from abnormal adhesions to adjacent parts.

gastromalacia.explanation: In pathology , softening of the stomach, arising in most cases from post-mortem digestion, but sometimes existing during life.
A softening of the coats of the stomach; -- usually a post-morten change.
A softening of the coatings of the stomach , usually after death .

gastromancy.explanation: A kind of divination among the ancients by means of words which seemed to be uttered from the belly; divination by ventriloquism.
A species of divination by means of large-bellied glasses or other round transparent vessels, in the center of which figures were supposed to appear by magic art.
A kind of divination, by means of words seemingly uttered from the stomach.
A species of divination, by means of glasses or other round, transparent vessels, in the center of which figures are supposed to appear by magic art.
Divination by interpreting the sounds and signs of the belly . It is now sometimes associated as being a form of ventriloquism , where vocal sounds are produced from the belly.

Divination by noting magical visions in large-bellied glasses. It is sometimes described as a technique where a child is placed in front of a glass filled with water, the images in the glass were then interpreted. Similar to crystallomancy .

gastromelus.explanation: In teratology , a monster which has one or several supernumerary limbs growing from the anterior abdominal wall; a form of epigastrius.

gastromenia.explanation: Vicarious menstruation from the mucous membrane of the stomach.

gastromyces.explanation: The fungoid growths sometimes found in the stomach; such as Torula, etc.

gastronome.explanation: A connoisseur of good food and drink; a gourmet.
One fond of good living; an epicure.
a lover of good food ; a connoisseur or gourmet
a person devoted to refined sensuous enjoyment (especially good food and drink)

gastronomer.explanation: One versed in gastronomy; one who is a judge of good living; a judge of the art of cookery; a gourmet; an epicure.
a lover of good food ; a connoisseur or gourmet

gastronomy.explanation: The art or science of good eating.
A style of cooking, as of a particular region.
The art of preparing and serving rich or delicate and appetizing food; hence, the pleasures of the table; epicurism.
The art or science of good eating; epicurism; the art of good cheer.
The study of the relationship between food and culture .
the art and practice of choosing and preparing and eating good food
a particular style of cookery (as of a region)

gastropancreatic.explanation: Relating to the stomach and pancreas .

gastroparalysis.explanation: In pathology , paralysis of the stomach.

gastroparesis.explanation: A condition, often a complication of diabetes , characterised by a delayed emptying of the stomach

gastropathy.explanation: In pathology , disease of the stomach.

gastroperiodynia.explanation: Intermittent paroxysmal pain at the pit of the stomach.

gastropexy.explanation: Operative fixation of the stomach to the abdominal wall.
The surgical fixation of the stomach to the abdominal wall or diaphragm .

gastrophile.explanation: One who loves good eating and plenty of it.

gastrophrenic.explanation: Pertaining to the stomach and diaphragm.
Pertaining to the stomach and diaphragm .

gastrophthisis.explanation: A cachectic state with emaciation consequent upon disease of the stomach.

gastroplasty.explanation: In surgery , an operation designed to restore the normal shape of a dilated or hour-glass stomach or to supply some defect in that organ.

gastroplication.explanation: In surgery , an operation for reducing the capacity of a dilated or sagging stomach by plaiting the wall and retaining the plaits by sutures.

gastropneumatic.explanation: Pertaining to the alimentary canal and air passages, and to the cavities connected with them.

gastropod.explanation: Any of numerous mollusks of the class Gastropoda, characteristically having a single, usually coiled shell or no shell at all, a ventral muscular foot, and eyes and tentacles located on a distinct head, and including the snails, slugs, cowries, and limpets.
Any member of a class of mollusks (Gastropoda) that includes snails and slugs; univalve mollusk.
a class of mollusks typically having a one-piece coiled shell and flattened muscular foot with a head bearing stalked eyes

gastropodous.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Gastropoda.
Of or pertaining to gastropods (snails and the like).

gastropore.explanation: The pore or orifice of a gastrozoöid or nutritive polypite.
In the cœnosteum of the hydrocorallines like Millepora , one of the larger, sometimes tabulated tubes of the skeleton which lodge the nutritive polyps.

gastroptosis.explanation: An abnormal downward displacement of the stomach

gastrorrhagia.explanation: In pathology , hemorrhage from the stomach.
A hemorrhage from the stomach , also known as a gastric hemorrhage.

gastrorrhaphy.explanation: In surgery , the operation of sewing up wounds of the abdomen.

gastrorrhea.explanation: In pathology , a morbid increase in the secretion of the mucous glands of the stomach.

gastroschisis.explanation: Congenital fissure of the abdominal wall.
A defect of the abdominal wall through which the viscera protrude

gastroscope.explanation: An endoscope that is inserted through the mouth and used for examining the interior of the stomach.
A hollow tube provided with reflecting mirrors and an electric light, which is passed through the esophagus into the stomach in order to enable the operator to inspect the interior of that organ.
An instrument for viewing or examining the interior of the stomach.
a form of endoscope used to view the inside of the stomach
a type of endoscope for visually examining the stomach

gastroscopy.explanation: In medicine , an examination of the abdomen in order to detect disease.
Inspection of the mucous membrane of the stomach by means of a gastroscope.
Examination of the abdomen or stomach, as with the gastroscope.
An examination of esophagus , stomach and duodenum using endoscope .
visual examination of the stomach by means of a gastroscope inserted through the esophagus

gastrosplenic.explanation: Pertaining to the stomach and spleen.
Of or pertaining to the stomach and the spleen

gastrostege.explanation: One of the scales or scutes which cover the abdomen of a snake from the head to the tail; an abdominal scute or scutellum.
One of the large scales on the belly of a serpent.
One of the large scales on the belly of a snake .

gastrostomize.explanation: surgery , to subject to the operation of gastrostomy.

gastrostomus.explanation: A genus of deepsea fishes, of the order Lyomeri and family Eurypharyngidæ , having an eel-like form and enormously developed jaws, six or seven times as long as the rest of the skull, supporting a great gular pouch like a pelican's.

gastrostomy.explanation: Surgical construction of a permanent opening from the external surface of the abdominal wall into the stomach, usually for inserting a feeding tube.
In surgery , the operation of forming an artificial opening into the stomach, for introducing food when it cannot pass through the gullet, on account of obstruction or stricture.
The operation of making a permanent opening into the stomach, for the introduction of food.
The surgical procedure for making an opening in the stomach as part of an operation .
surgical creation of an opening through the abdominal wall into the stomach (as for gastrogavage)

gastrotomy.explanation: The operation of cutting into the stomach.
A cutting into, or opening of, the abdomen or the stomach.
Any form of incision into the stomach

gastrotrich.explanation: Any of various microscopic marine and freshwater aquatic animals of the phylum Gastrotricha, having a long thin ciliated body.
A microscopic aquatic animal of the phylum Gastrotricha , with a worm-like body and cilia .

gastrovascular.explanation: Having both a digestive and a circulatory function, as the guts of flatworms and cnidarians.
Having the structure, or performing the functions, both of digestive and circulatory organs.
That has both a digestive and a circulatory function

gastrula.explanation: An embryo at the stage following the blastula, after the movement of cells results in the formation of the three germ layers, ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
In embryology , that form of the germ of the Metazoa which is a germcup of which the walls consist of two layers.

It is the result of that process of invagination which occurs in most animals, whereby a vesicular morula, blasto-sphere, or blastula is converted into a cup-like two-layered germ, with a blastopore or orifice of invagination, and an endoderm or membrane inclosing a primitive intestinal cavity, the endoderm itself being inclosed within an ectoderm. The word enters into many loose compounds of obvious meaning, as gastrula-body, -cup, -form, -formation, -germ, -mouth, -stage, -stomach , etc., mostly derived from the translation of the German compounds used in Haeckel's works. See gastrulation .

An embryonic form having its origin in the invagination or pushing in of the wall of the planula or blastula (the blastosphere ) on one side, thus giving rise to a double-walled sac, with one opening or mouth (the blastopore ) which leads into the cavity (the archenteron ) lined by the inner wall (the hypoblast ). See Illust. under invagination . In a more general sense, an ideal stage in embryonic development. See gastræa .
A stage in the development of embryos of most animals consisting of a two-layered sac of ectoderm and endoderm .
double-walled stage of the embryo resulting from invagination of the blastula; the outer layer of cells is the ectoderm and the inner layer differentiates into the mesoderm and endoderm

gastrular.explanation: Of or pertaining to a gastrula .

gastrulate.explanation: To form or become a gastrula.

gastrulated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gastrulate .

gastrulation.explanation: In embryology , the formation of a gastrula; the process whereby a germ is converted from a morula or a blastula into a gastrula.
The process of invagination, in embryonic development, by which a gastrula is formed.
The stage of embryo development at which a gastrula is formed from the blastula by the inward migration of cells
the process in which a gastrula develops from a blastula by the inward migration of cells

gasts.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gast .

gasworker.explanation: Someone who works in a gasworks

gasworks.explanation: A factory where gas for heating and lighting is produced.
A factory where coal is converted to coal gas and coke .
the workplace where coal gas is manufactured

gat.explanation: A narrow passage extending inland from a shore; a channel.
An opening or passage in a sand-bank; a way from the cliffs to the sea.
Any type of gun ; usually in reference to a pistol .
To shoot someone with a pistol or other handheld firearm .

gata.explanation: A large spotted shark, Ginglymostoma cirratum of the West Indies.

gatch.explanation: Plaster as used in Persian gatch-work.
Plaster as used in Persian architecture and decorative art.
decoration in plaster often producing design of great beauty.
work in which gatch is employed; also, articles of gatch ornamentation collectively.
A form of plaster of Paris formerly used in Persia

gate.explanation: A path or way.
A particular way of acting or doing; manner.
A structure that can be swung, drawn, or lowered to block an entrance or a passageway.
An opening in a wall or fence for entrance or exit.
The structure surrounding such an opening, such as the monumental or fortified entrance to a palace or walled city.
A means of access.
A passageway, as in an airport terminal, through which passengers proceed when boarding or leaving an airplane.
A mountain pass.
The total paid attendance or admission receipts at a public event.
A device for controlling the passage of water or gas through a dam or conduit.
The channel through which molten metal flows into a shaped cavity of a mold.
A passage between two upright poles through which a skier must go in a slalom race.
A logic gate.
To confine (a student) to the grounds of a college as punishment.
To select part of (a wave) for transmission, reception, or processing by magnitude or time interval.
To furnish with a gate.
( get the gate ) To be dismissed or rejected.
( give (someone) the gate ) To discharge from a job.
( give (someone) the gate ) To reject or jilt.
An archaic or dialectal form of goat .

A passage or opening closed by a movable barrier (a door or gate in sense 3); a gateway: commonly used with reference to such barrier, and specifically for the entrance to a large inclosure or building, as a walled city, a fortification, a great church or palace, or other public monument.
Hence, any somewhat contracted or difficult means or avenue of approach or passage; a narrow opening or defile: as, the Iron Gates of the Danube.
A movable barrier consisting of a frame or solid structure of wood, iron, or other material, set on hinges or pivots in or at the end of a passage in order to close it.
The movable framework which shuts or opens a passage for water, as at the entrance to a dock or in a canal-lock.
In coal-mining , an underground road connecting a stall with a main road or inclined plane. Also called gate-road, gateway.
In founding :

One of various forms of channels or openings made in the sand or molds, through which the metal flows ( pouring-gate ), or by means of which access is had to it, either for skimming its surface ( skimming-gate ) or for other purposes.
The waste piece of metal cast in the gate.
A ridge in a casting which has to be sawn off.
In locksmithing , one of the apertures in the tumblers for the passage of the stub.
A sash or frame in which a saw is extended, to prevent buckling or bending.

gavelet.explanation: An ancient and special cessavit, in the English county of Kent, where the custom of gavelkind continues, by which the tenant, if he withdraws the rent and services due to his lord, forfeits his lands and tenements. See gavelkind .
An ancient special kind of cessavit used in Kent and London for the recovery of rent.
A special kind of cessavit once used in Kent and London for the recovery of rent .

gavelkind.explanation: An English system of land tenure dating from Anglo-Saxon times and continuing in Kent until 1926, in which land was divided equally among all qualified heirs.
Originally, in old English law , the tenure of land let out for rent, including in that term money, labor, and provisions, but not military service; also, the land so held.

Hence In general use, land in Great Britain or Ireland, or an estate therein, which by custom having the force of law is inheritable by all the sons together, and therefore subject to partition, instead of going exclusively to the eldest.

A tenure by which land descended from the father to all his sons in equal portions, and the land of a brother, dying without issue, descended equally to his brothers. It still prevails in the county of Kent.

a system of inheritance associated with the county of Kent in England whereby, at the death of a tenant , intestate estate is divided equally among all his sons; also, a similar system employed in Ireland

gavelled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gavel .

gaveller.explanation: Someone who pays gavel for rented land.

gavelman.explanation: A tenant holding land in gavelkind.

gavels.explanation: Third person singular simple present of to gavel .

gaverick.explanation: A name of the red gurnard, Trigla cuculus , a common fish on the coast of Cornwall in England.
The European red gurnard ( Trigla cuculus ).

gavia.explanation: In ornithology , a name variously used.
type genus of the Gavidae: loons

gaviae.explanation: The division of birds which includes the gulls and terns.

gavial.explanation: The Gangetic crocodile, Gavialis gangeticus , having long, slender, subcylindric jaws with a protuberance at the end of the upper one.

A crocodile -like reptile with long, narrow jaws ( species Gavialis gangeticus); one of two surviving members of the family Gavialidae.
large fish-eating Indian crocodilian with a long slender snout

gavialis.explanation: The genus of crocodiles of which the gavial, Gavialis gangeticus , is the type.

gavot.explanation: A dance of French origin, somewhat resembling the minuet, remarkable for its combination of vivacity and dignity.
Music for such a dance, or in its rhythm, which is duple and quick. Gavots are frequent in old-fashioned suites, and have recently come again into favor.
A kind of difficult, old formal French dance in quadruple time.
Music composed in quadruple time for dancing the gavotte, having a dance tune which has two brisk and lively, yet dignified, strains in common time, each played twice over.

gavotte.explanation: A French peasant dance of Baroque origin in moderately quick duple meter.
A French dance , either in 4/4 or 2/2 time.
an old formal French dance in quadruple time

gawk.explanation: To stare or gape stupidly. synonym : gaze .
A cuckoo. [Scotch and North. Eng.] — 2. A stupid, awkward fellow; a fool; a simpleton; a booby. Also gawky .
A simpleton; a booby; a gawky.

a simpleton , stupid or clumsy person.

small swift graceful antelope of Africa and Asia having lustrous eyes

Hence An official or authoritative report or announcement in or as if in the Gazette.

Any lizard of the family Geckonidæ . The geckoes are small, carnivorous, mostly nocturnal animals with large eyes and vertical, elliptical pupils. Their toes are generally expanded, and furnished with adhesive disks, by which they can run over walls and ceilings. They are numerous in warm countries, and a few species are found in Europe and the United States. See wall gecko , fanfoot .
Any lizard of the family Gekkonidae. They are small, carnivorous, mostly nocturnal animals with large eyes and adhesive toes enabling them to climb on vertical surfaces.

Chem.), a nitrogeneous colloid, not existing as such in the animal body, but formed by the hydrating action of boiling water on the collagen of various kinds of connective tissue (as tendons, bones, ligaments, etc.). It is an important ingredient of calf's-foot jelly, isinglass, glue, etc. It is used as food, but its nutritious qualities are of a low order.

The first or electron generation consists of the down quark, up quark, electron, and electron neutrino lepton. The second or muon generation consists of the strange quark, charm quark, muon, and muon neutrino lepton. The third or tauon generation consists of the bottom quark, top quark, muon, and muon neutrino lepton.

alternation of sexual with asexual generation, in which the products of one process differ from those of the other, -- a form of reproduction common both to animal and vegetable organisms. In the simplest form, the organism arising from sexual generation produces offspiring unlike itself, agamogenetically. These, however, in time acquire reproductive organs, and from their impregnated germs the original parent form is reproduced. In more complicated cases, the first series of organisms produced agamogenetically may give rise to others by a like process, and these in turn to still other generations. Ultimately, however, a generation is formed which develops sexual organs, and the original form is reproduced.
the fancied production of living organisms without previously existing parents from inorganic matter, or from decomposing organic matter, a notion which at one time had many supporters; abiogenesis.

A disembodied spirit regarded as affecting human beings in certain ways, but not as connected with any one individually.

gens.explanation: A patrilineal clan of ancient Rome composed of several families of the same name claiming a common ancestor and belonging to a common religious cult.

In ancient Rome, a clan or house embracing several families claiming descent from a common ancestor, united by a common name and by certain religious rites and legal privileges and obligations, but not necessarily by consanguinity: as, the Fabian gens , all bearing the name Fabius; the Julian gens , all named Julius; the Cornelian gens , etc.
In historical and ethnological use, a tribe or clan; any community of persons in a primitive state of society constituting a distinct or independent branch of a general aggregate or race.
A clan or family connection, embracing several families of the same stock, who had a common name and certain common religious rites; a subdivision of the Roman curia or tribe.
A minor subdivision of a tribe, among American aborigines. It includes those who have a common descent, and bear the same totem.

A legally defined unit of Roman society closest in meaning to and translated by English clan , but not identical to it. The gens was a collection of families whose members were related by birth , marriage or adoption . All the families were considered to have descended from a common clan ancestor although in cases where the time from the ancestor to the contemporary time was great the kinship was more remote than is meant by the English term "related." In such cases the legal definition still prevailed.
a tribal subgroup whose members are characterized by having the same descent , usually along the male line

Genteel, Polite , well-mannered, polished. Genteel refers to the outward chiefly; polite to the outward as an expression of inward refinement and kindness. Genteel has latterly tended to express a somewhat fastidious pride of refinement, family position, and the like. Genteel is often largely negative, meaning free from what is low, vulgar, or connected with the uncultivated classes; polite is positive and active, meaning that one acts in a certain way. Polite has, however, a passive meaning, that of ‘polished’: as, polite society, polite literature. See polite .

Possessing or exhibiting the qualities popularly regarded as belonging to high birth and breeding; free from vulgarity, or lowness of taste or behavior; adapted to a refined or cultivated taste; polite; well-bred.

genus.explanation: A taxonomic category ranking below a family and above a species and designating a group of species that are presumed to be closely related and usually exhibit similar characteristics. In a scientific name, the genus name is capitalized and italicized, for example, Ovis for sheep and related animals.
A class of objects divided into subordinate species having certain common attributes.
A class, group, or kind with common attributes.
A kind; a sort; a class.

In zoology and botany , a classificatory group ranking next above the species, containing a group of species (sometimes a single species) possessing certain structural characters different from those of any others. The value assigned to a genus is wholly arbitrary—that is, it is entirely a matter of opinion or current usage what characters shall be considered generic and thus constitute a genus; and genera are constantly modified and shifted by specialists, the tendency being mostly to restriction of genera, with the consequent multiplication of their number, and the coinage of new generic names. A genus has no natural, much less necessary, definition, its meaning being at best a matter of expert opinion; and the same is true of the species, family, order, class, etc. A genus of the animal kingdom in the time of Linnæus and other early naturalists was a group of species approximately equivalent to a modern family, sometimes even to an order. Probably upward of 100,000 generic names of as many supposed genera have been coined or used in zoölogy; those in current use at present are estimated at about 60,000, or an average of about (rather more than) one genus for every five species in the animal kingdom. In botany the genera are less restricted and average a much larger number of species, the 9,000 phanerogamic genera, for example, including 100,000 species. The tenable name of any genus is that which has priority of publication, if it has been properly published and characterized, and is not the same as the prior name of some other genus. The names of the genus and the species together form the scientific name of an animal or a plant. In writing the technical name of any animal or plant, the generic term always precedes the specific, and begins with a capital letter: as, Musca domestica , the house-fly, where Musca is the genus, and domestica differentiates the species. Genera are often subdivided into lesser groups called subgenera. (See subgenus .) A group of genera constitutes a family or subfamily. The name of a genus as such has properly no plural. If a genus name, as for example Ada , is pluralized, as Adœ , it means, not two or more genera named Ada , but either all the species of Ada , or some supergeneric group of which Ada is the type. The former usage is loose, or somewhat cant; the latter is frequent and regular in zoölogy. A genus name is always supposed to be Latin (though its derivation is in the great majority of cases from the Greek), and its plural, if used, is in Latin form; but when it is also Anglicized an English plural is used: as, the chinchillas , the animals of the genus Chinchilla.

In old music , a formula or method of dividing the tetrachord. Three genera were distinguished: the diatonic, in which whole steps or “tones” were used; the chromatic, in which only half-steps or semitones were used; and the enharmonic, in which intervals less than a half-step were used.

A class of objects divided into several subordinate species; a class more extensive than a species; a precisely defined and exactly divided class; one of the five predicable conceptions, or sorts of terms.

An assemblage of species, having so many fundamental points of structure in common, that in the judgment of competent scientists, they may receive a common substantive name. A genus is not necessarily the lowest definable group of species, for it may often be divided into several subgenera. In proportion as its definition is exact, it is natural genus; if its definition can not be made clear, it is more or less an artificial genus.
a genus which may be a species of a higher genus, as the genus denoted by quadruped , which is also a species of mammal .
the highest genus; a genus which can not be classed as a species, as being .

geometrized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of geometrize .

geometry.explanation: The mathematics of the properties, measurement, and relationships of points, lines, angles, surfaces, and solids.
A system of geometry.
A geometry restricted to a class of problems or objects.
A book on geometry.
Configuration; arrangement.
A surface shape.
A physical arrangement suggesting geometric forms or lines.

The oldest classification of geometry is , that in which it is divided according to the method of logical procedure, namely into synthetic and analytic , the method of geometrical analysis having been invented or taught by Plato. In modern times this classification intertwines with another, namely , that which is based on the mental instrument or equipment used, giving: pure or synthetic geometry ; rational ; descriptive ; projective ; algebraic, algorithmic, analytical, Cartesian , or coördinate ; differential, infinitesimal, natural , or intrinsic ; enumerative or denumerative. Some of these are subdivided on the same principle, as: ( α ) geometry of the ruler or straight-edge ; ( β ) of the ruler and sect-carrier ; ( γ ) of the ruler and unitsect-carrier ; ( δ ) of the compasses ; of the ruler and compasses ; ( ζ ) of linkages. Further divisions are: By dimensionality: geometry on the straight or on the line ; two-dimensional geometry ; ( α ) plane geometry ; ( β ) spherics ; ( γ ) pseudo-spherics ; tri-dimensional geometry : ( α ) geometry of planes ; ( β ) solid geometry ; ( γ ) spherics ; four-dimensional geometry : ( α ) geometry of straight? ; ( β ) of hyperspace ; n-dimeimonal geometry. By elements: point geometry ; straight or line ; plane ; point, straight , and plane ; straightest or geodesic ; geometry of the sphere ; of other elements , By subject-matter: pure descriptive, pure projective , or pure positional geometry , or geometry of position ; topologic geometry ; metric geometry ; geometry of curves ; of surfaces ; of solids ; of hyper-solids ; of numbers ; of motion or kinematic. By assumptions made, omitted, or denied: Euclidean geometry ; non-Euclidean ; metageometry, or pan-geometry ; finite geometry ; semi-Euclidean ; non-Legendrian ; Archimedean ; non-Archimedean ; non-Arguesian ; non-Pascalian. By the kind of space or universe of the geometry: Euclidean or parabolic geometry ; Bolyaian, Lobachevskian, Bolyai-Lobachevskian, absolute , or hyperbolic ; Riemannian, spherical , or double elliptic ; Killing's, single elliptic , or simple elliptic ; Clifford's or Clifford-Kleinian. By the complexity or difficulty of the part treated: elementary geometry ; higher , By the period of its development: ancient or the antique geometry ; modern ; recent, of the triangle , or the Lemoine-Brocard.
That branch of mathematics which deduces the properties of figures in space from their defining conditions, by means of assumed properties of space. Abbreviated geometry
A text-book of geometry.
Modern projective geometry, commonly written in German Geometrie der Lage , to distinguish it from .
Higher synthetic geometry in general.
The art of geometrical drawing.
Geometry of three dimensions.

That branch of mathematics which investigates the relations, properties, and measurement of solids, surfaces, lines, and angles; the science which treats of the properties and relations of magnitudes; the science of the relations of space.
A treatise on this science.
that branch of mathematical analysis which has for its object the analytical investigation of the relations and properties of geometrical magnitudes.
that part of geometry which treats of the graphic solution of all problems involving three dimensions.
that part of geometry which treats of the simple properties of straight lines, circles, plane surface, solids bounded by plane surfaces, the sphere, the cylinder, and the right cone.
that pert of geometry which treats of those properties of straight lines, circles, etc., which are less simple in their relations, and of curves and surfaces of the second and higher degrees.
the branch of mathematics dealing with spatial relationships
a type of geometry with particular properties
the spatial attributes of an object, etc.
the pure mathematics of points and lines and curves and surfaces

geomorphic.explanation: Of or resembling the earth or its shape or surface configuration.
Of or pertaining to the shape or structure of the surface of the Earth

geomorphogenist.explanation: A specialist in the investigation of the development of earth-forms; a physiographer.

geomorphogeny.explanation: In geology , the study of the origin of the surface features of the earth.

geomorphologic.explanation: Of or pertaining to geomorphology ; geomorphological

geomorphologist.explanation: A geologist whose speciality is geomorphology

geomorphology.explanation: The study of the evolution and configuration of landforms.
The morphology of the earth; the study of the form of the earth's surface features and of their origin.
The study of landforms , their classification , origin , development , and history .
the branch of geology that studies the characteristics and configuration and evolution of rocks and land forms

geomorphy.explanation: The theory of the figure of the earth.

geomys.explanation: The typical genus of Geomyidœ , with grooved incisors, rudimentary external ears, and enormous fore claws.

geon.explanation: A hypothetical electromagnetic or gravitational wave held together in a confined region by the gravitational attraction of its own field energy .

geonoma.explanation: A genus of low, slender, graceful, unarmed palms, with reed-like stems, of about 100 species, common in the forests of tropical America.

geophagia.explanation: Consumption of clay , chalk or dirt .
eating earth, clay, chalk; occurs in some primitive tribes, sometimes in cases of nutritional deficiency or obsessive behavior

geophagism.explanation: The act or habit of eating earth. See Dirt eating, under dirt .
The act or habit of eating earth .

geophagist.explanation: One who practises geophagism; one who eats earth.
One who eats earth, as dirt, clay, chalk, etc.
One who eats earth , clay , chalk , etc.

geophagy.explanation: The eating of earthy substances, such as clay or chalk, practiced among various peoples as a custom or for dietary or subsistence reasons.
The act or practice of eating earth, as dirt, clay, chalk, etc. See dirt-eating . Also geophagism .
The practice of eating earthy substances such as clay and chalk , often thought to augment a mineral-deficient diet.
eating earth, clay, chalk; occurs in some primitive tribes, sometimes in cases of nutritional deficiency or obsessive behavior

geophila.explanation: The division of Mollusca which includes the land snails and slugs.

geophilid.explanation: A myriapod of the family Geophilidœ.

geophilidae.explanation: A natural family of small extremely elongate earth-living centipedes.
small extremely elongate centipedes that live in earth

geophilous.explanation: botany Terrestrial; growing or rooting in the ground.
phytogeography , growing on the ground or on decaying vegetable matter: applied by Pound and Clements to a class of fungi.
Loving the ground: specifically applied to sundry animals, especially the Geophila or land-snails.
Terrestrial; growing or rooting in the ground.
growing on the ground or on decaying vegetable matter: applied by Pound and Clements to a class of fungi.

geophilus.explanation: The typical genus of centipeds of the family Geophilidæ , having the anterior segment of the head square. G. electricus , a European species, is phosphorescent, shining like a glow-worm.
A genus of pigeons: same as Calœnas .
The type type genus of the Geophilidae , a cosmopolitan genus of centipedes sometimes called earwigs.
type genus of the Geophilidae: a cosmopolitan genus of centipedes sometimes called earwigs

geophone.explanation: An electronic receiver designed to pick up seismic vibrations.
A form of microphone that detects and records seismic vibrations

geophysically.explanation: In a geophysical manner; in terms of geophysics .

geophysicist.explanation: A student of geophysics; one who studies the relations between the features of the earth and the laws of physics.
( physics ) A physicist who specialises in geophysics
a geologist who uses physical principles to study the properties of the earth

geophysics.explanation: The physics of the earth and its environment, including the physics of fields such as meteorology, oceanography, and seismology.
Physics of the earth: same as physiography .
A branch of geology that uses physical principles to study the properties of the earth.
A branch of earth science dealing with the physical processes and phenomena occurring in the earth and in its vicinity .
geology that uses physical principles to study properties of the earth

geophyte.explanation: A perennial plant, such as a crocus or tulip, that resprouts by means of buds on underground bulbs, tubers, or corms.
A plant which produces underground buds that do not develop there.
a perennial plant propagated by overwintering buds on underground bulbs or tubers or corms.
A perennial plant, for example the potato or daffodil , which in spring propagates from an underground organ such as a bulb , tuber , corm or rhizome .
a perennial plant that propagates by underground bulbs or tubers or corms

geoplana.explanation: The typical genus of land-planarians of the family Geoplanidœ.

geopolar.explanation: heliopolar , which refers to the pole of the sun's rotation.

geopolitics.explanation: The study of the relationship among politics and geography, demography, and economics, especially with respect to the foreign policy of a nation.
A Nazi doctrine holding that the geographic, economic, and political needs of Germany justified its invasion and seizure of other lands.
A combination of geographic and political factors relating to or influencing a nation or region.
the study of the effects of economic geography on the powers of the state.
The study of the effects of geography (especially economic geography) on international politics .
the study of the effects of economic geography on the powers of the state

geoponic.explanation: Of or relating to agriculture or farming.
One who tills or cultivates the earth.
Pertaining to tillage of the earth, or agriculture.
Relating to tillage of the earth , or agriculture .

geoponics.explanation: The art or science of cultivating the earth.
The art or science of cultivating the earth; agriculture.

geopotential.explanation: The work that must be done at a given altitude in raising a unit mass from sea level to that altitude against the earth's gravitational field .

georama.explanation: A large hollow globe or spherical chamber lined with cloth on which is depicted a general view of the geography of the earth's surface so as to be seen by a spectator from the interior.
A hollow globe on the inner surface of which a map of the world is depicted, to be examined by one standing inside.
A hollow globe with a map of the world on its inner surface, so as to be examined by one standing inside.

georgette.explanation: A sheer, strong, silk or silklike fabric with a dull, crinkled finish.
A thin lightweight silk or cotton fabric with a matte finish.

georgiadesite.explanation: A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing arsenic , chlorine , hydrogen , lead , and oxygen .

georgic.explanation: Of or relating to agriculture or rural life.
A poem concerning farming or rural life.
A poem on agriculture or rural affairs: as, the Georgics of Virgil.
A rural poem; a poetical composition on husbandry, containing rules for cultivating lands, etc..
Relating to agriculture and rural affairs.
A rural poem ; a poetical composition on husbandry , containing rules for cultivating land, etc.

geoscience.explanation: Any one of the sciences, such as geology or geochemistry, that deals with the earth.
Any of several sciences that deal with the Earth

geoscientist.explanation: A scholar or researcher in geoscience , an inclusive term for the earth sciences .

geoscopy.explanation: Knowledge of the earth, ground, or soil obtained by inspection.
Knowledge of the earth, ground, or soil, obtained by inspection.
Knowledge of the earth or soil , obtained by inspection .

geoselenic.explanation: Pertaining to the earth and moon; belonging to the joint action or mutual relations of the earth and moon.
Pertaining to the Earth and Moon .

geosphere.explanation: The lithosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere, considered as a single system.
Any of the layers of the earth.
The atmosphere of the earth as distinguished from that of other planets.
One of the concentric, spheroidal shells of which the earth may be conceived to consist.
the solid body of the Earth
the solid part of the earth consisting of the crust and outer mantle

geospiza.explanation: A remarkable genus of fringilline birds peculiar to the Galapagos islands, having an enormous bill. G. magnirostris is an example; there are several others.

geostatic.explanation: Relating to the pressure exerted by earth or similar substance.
an arch having a form adapted to sustain pressure similar to that exerted by earth.
Relating to the pressure exerted by earth or similar substance.

geostationary.explanation: Of, relating to, or being a satellite that travels above earth's equator from west to east at an altitude of approximately 35,900 kilometers (22,300 miles) and at an angular speed matching that of the earth's rotation, thus remaining stationary as observed from any location on the earth's surface.
Of, relating to, or being the orbit of such a satellite.
At a fixed distance in three dimensions relative to a particular point on the Earth's surface; generally only possible with orbital satellites .
of or having a geosynchronous orbit such that the position in such an orbit is fixed with respect to the earth

geostrategic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or using geostrategy .

geostrategist.explanation: A geopolitical strategist ; one concerned with the strategies of political geography.

geostrategy.explanation: the branch of geopolitics dealing with strategy

geostrophic.explanation: Of or relating to the pseudo force caused by the earth's rotation.
. Referring to the balance , in the atmosphere , between the horizontal Coriolis forces and the horizontal pressure forces.
. Relates to or arises from the deflective force exerted on the atmosphere due to the rotation of the earth .

geosynchronous.explanation: Of, relating to, or being an orbit that has a period of one sidereal day.

Refers to the orbit of a satellite whose rate of revolution is matched to the rotation period of the Earth. A special case is the geostationary orbit which is is circular and equatorial, so that the satellite appears to be fixed over a particular point on Earth's sky.
of or having an orbit with a fixed period of 24 hours (although the position in the orbit may not be fixed with respect to the earth)

geosynclinal.explanation: In geology , a region of depression, having, consequently, a synclinal structure. See geanticlinal .

the downward bend or subsidence of the earth's crust, which allows of the gradual accumulation of sediment, and hence forms the first step in the making of a mountain range; -- opposed to geanticlinal .
The downward bend or subsidence of the Earth 's crust , which permits the gradual accumulation of sediment and hence forms the first step in the formation of a mountain range .

geosyncline.explanation: A usually elongate, basinlike depression along the edge of a continent, in which a thick sequence of sediments and volcanic deposits has accumulated.
In geology , a considerable tract in which the strata are bent into a great trough with many minor undulations on the flanks.
A large, linear depression in the Earth 's crust in which sediment accumulates.

geotaxis.explanation: Movement of a motile organism using the earth's gravity for orientation.
The orientation or locomotion of cells or of organisms in relation to the direction of the earth (or to gravity).
A living creature's ability to move by orienting itself by gravitational forces .

geotechnics.explanation: A branch of civil engineering related to soil and rocks

geotectonic.explanation: Of or relating to the shape, structure, and arrangement of the rock masses resulting from structural deformation of the earth's crust.

geoteuthis.explanation: A genus of fossil squids or calamaries whose pens are found abundantly in the Lias and Oölite formations. The ink-bag and other fragments, in addition to the pens, occur in the Oxford clay.

geothermal.explanation: Of or relating to the internal heat of the earth.
A line connecting places having the same temperature at a given depth below the earth's surface. Geothermic degree. See degree .
pertaining to heat energy extracted from reservoirs in the earth 's interior
of or relating to the heat in the interior of the earth

geothermally.explanation: By geothermal means, especially by means of geothermal energy
by means of heat from the interior of the earth

geothermic.explanation: of or relating to the heat in the interior of the earth

geothermometer.explanation: An instrument for measuring the degree of terrestrial heat at different places, especially in mines and artesian wells.
A thermometer specially constructed for measuring temperetures at a depth below the surface of the ground.
A thermometer designed for measuring temperatures below ground level .

geothlypis.explanation: A genus of American passerine birds, of the family Mniotiltidæ , or Sylvicolidæ , containing certain ground-warblers, such as the abundant and familiar Maryland yellowthroat, G. trichas.

geotropism.explanation: In botany , growth downward, as shown in the roots of plants and sometimes in stems and rootstocks; the power or tendency to grow toward the earth.
A disposition to turn or incline towards the earth; the influence of gravity in determining the direction of growth of an organ.
The movement of a plant in response to gravity (either downwards or upwards)

gephyrea.explanation: Vermes , or worms, including marine vermiform animals without distinct external segmentation, parapodia, or calcareous skeleton.
An order of marine Annelida, in which the body is imperfectly, or not at all, annulated externally, and is mostly without setæ.

gephyrean.explanation: Belonging to the Gephyrea. -- n. One of the Gerphyrea.

gephyrocercal.explanation: ichthyology , having the tail-fin formed from the hinder portions of the dorsal and anal fins, which unite over the end of the aborted axis of the body, as the family Molidæ.

ger.explanation: A terminal element in words of Latin origin, meaning ‘bearing,’ as in armiger , etc.

gerah.explanation: An ancient Hebrew coin and unit of weight.
Among the ancient Jews, a unit of weight and of monetary reckoning, the twentieth part of a heavy shekel, or about three fourths of a gram.
A small coin and weight; 1-20th of a shekel.
an ancient Hebrew unit of weight and currency equal to one twentieth of a shekel

geraniaceous.explanation: Of or pertaining to a natural order of pants (Geraniaceæ) which includes the genera Geranium, Pelargonium, and many others.
Of or pertaining to the family Geraniaceae of flowering plants , including the geranium .

geraniales.explanation: Geraniaceæ, Oxalidaceæ, Linaeeæ, Rutaceæ, Balsameaceæ , and Euphorbiaceæ.
an order of plants of subclass Rosidae including geraniums and many other plants; see Euphorbiaceae; Geraniaceae; Rutaceae; Malpighiaceae; Simaroubaceae; Meliaceae; Zygophyllaceae; Tropaeolaceae

geraniol.explanation: A fragrant, pale yellow liquid alcohol, C 10 H 18 O, derived chiefly from the oils of geranium and citronella and used in cosmetics and flavorings.
A colorless liquid, (CH 3 ) 2 .C:CH.CH 2 .CH 2 C (CH 3 ):CH.CH 2 OH, with an odor of roses.
A terpene alcohol (C10H18O) which constitutes the principal part of the oil of palmarosa and the oil of rose. Chemically it is 3,7-Dimethyl-2,6-octadien-1-ol. It has a sweet rose odor.
A monoterpenoid alcohol found in the essential oils of rose , palmarosa and citronella

geranium.explanation: Any of various plants of the genus Pelargonium, native chiefly to southern Africa and widely cultivated for their rounded, often variegated leaves and showy clusters of red, pink, or white irregular flowers. An essential oil is obtained from the leaves of some species.
Any of various plants of the genus Geranium, having palmately divided leaves and pink or purplish regular flowers.
An impure magenta which contains phosphene.
A plant of the genus Geranium.

[ capitalized ] A genus of herbaceous plants (rarely undershrubs), the type of the order Geraniaceæ , distinguished by opposite lobed leaves, regular flowers, and five one-seeded carpels which separate elastically from the axis at maturity, the styles forming long tails which become revolute or spirally twisted.
A plant of the genus Pelargonium , of South Africa, of which many varieties are common in house-culture and gardens under the names of scarlet geranium, rose geranium , etc.
One of ⋅everal plants of other genera.

A genus of plants having a beaklike torus or receptacle, around which the seed capsules are arranged, and membranous projections, or stipules, at the joints. Most of the species have showy flowers and a pungent odor. Called sometimes crane's-bill .
Any flowering plant of the genus Geranium , the cranesbills , of family Geraniaceae .
The common name for flowering plants of the genus Pelargonium .
A bright red color tinted with orange, like that of a scarlet geranium.
Of a bright red color tinted with orange, like that of a scarlet geranium.
any of numerous plants of the family Geraniaceae

geranyl.explanation: A univalent radical derived from geraniol

gerardia.explanation: Any of various herbaceous, root-parasitizing plants of the genus Agalinis, native to temperate regions of the Western Hemisphere, having large pink, purple, or white flowers with yellow markings in some species.

gerated.explanation: heraldry , covered by a number of small bearings (compare semé ); especially, differenced by the use of such small bearings. See difference , and marks of cadency (under cadency ).

geratology.explanation: The study of decadence and decay, as of the changes wrought in a species or other group of animals approaching extinction.
The study of the elderly and diseases and other matters associated with senility; gerontology and geriatrics

gerb.explanation: A firework that produces a fountain of sparks

gerbe.explanation: A strong paper case filled with a pyrotechnic composition, used in fireworks; a bouquet or sheaf of fire.
something resembling a (wheat) sheaf in appearance
an abstract construction in homological algebra and geometry providing a certain type of generalisation for a sheaf

gerbera.explanation: Any of several rosette-forming plants of the genus Gerbera of the composite family, widely cultivated for their colorful daisylike flower heads.
A daisy of the genus Gerbera.

gerbil.explanation: Any of various small, mouselike rodents of the genus Gerbillus and other genera of the subfamily Gerbillinae, having long hind legs and a long tail and inhabiting arid regions of Africa and Asia.
A Mongolian jird (Meriones unguiculatus) of the subfamily Gerbillinae, commonly domesticated and kept as a pet.
A book-name of any animal of the subfamily Gerbillinœ.

One of several species of small, jumping, murine burrowing rodents, of the genus Gerbillus and related genera of the subfamily Gerbillinae . They have long soft pale fur and hind legs adapted for leaping. In their leaping powers they resemble the jerboa. They inhabit Africa, India, and Southern Europe.

A rodent ( Meriones unguiculatus ) of the subfamily Gerbillinae that is commonly kept as a pet; it is also called the tamarisk gerbil , sand rat and jird . Its natural habitats are the dry regions of Northern Africa and Asia.
One of several species of small, jumping, murine rodents , of the genus Gerbillus. In their leaping powers they resemble the jerboa . They inhabit Africa, India, and Southern Europe.
To rotate inside a monowheel or similar apparatus due to sudden acceleration or braking .
To insert a small animal into the rectum of a person .
small Old World burrowing desert rodent with long soft pale fur and hind legs adapted for leaping

gerbille.explanation: small Old World burrowing desert rodent with long soft pale fur and hind legs adapted for leaping

gerbillinae.explanation: A natural family of rodents including the gerbils.

gerbillus.explanation: The typical and leading genus of Gerbillinœ , containing upward of 40 species, of which the Egyptian gerbil, G. œgyptiacus , is one of the best-known; another is G. longifrons.
The type genus of the Gerbillinae , comprising the typical gerbils{1}.
type genus of the Gerbillinae: typical gerbils

gerbils.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gerbil .

gere.explanation: A Middle English form of gear .

gerefa.explanation: In Anglo-Saxon history , an officer corresponding to the steward or seneschal of Norman times; a reeve.

gerent.explanation: A ruling power or agency; a doer or performer.

gerenuk.explanation: A gazelle (Litocranius walleri) of eastern Africa having long legs, a long slender neck, and backward-curving horns in the male.
The native name, adopted as a book-name, for Waller′ s gazelle, Lithocranius walleri , an excessively long-necked species found in East Africa.

A slender East African antelope ( Litocranius walleri ) with a long slim neck and backward-curving horns; called also Waller's gazelle , and in German Giraffengazelle . It feeds on the foliage of bushes and trees, and often stands erect on its hind legs, leaning against the bush, to browse on the higher branches; in this habit it is distinctive and easy to recognize.
slender East African antelope with slim neck and backward-curving horns

gerfalcon.explanation: A large falcon of arctic Europe, Falco gyrfalco , or one of other kinds of boreal falcons forming the subgenus Hierofalco , of large size, very robust organization, and highly raptorial nature.
large and rare Arctic falcon having white and dark color phases

gerhardtite.explanation: A basic nitrate of copper occurring in dark-green orthorhombic crystals, “with cuprite and malachite, at Jerome in Arizona.
An orthorhombic-disphenoidal mineral containing copper , hydrogen , nitrogen , and oxygen .

geriatric.explanation: Of or relating to the aged or to characteristics of the aging process.
Of or pertaining to the elderly .
of or relating to or practicing geriatrics
of or relating to the aged

geriatrician.explanation: A physician who specializes in geriatrics.
A medical doctor specialising in the assessment and treatment of elderly people.

geriatrics.explanation: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis and treatment of diseases and problems specific to the aged.

The branch of medicine that focuses on health promotion and the prevention and treatment of disease and disability in later life. The term itself can be distinguished from gerontology , which is the study of the aging process itself.
Plural form of geriatric ; old people.
the branch of medical science that deals with diseases and problems specific to old people

gerland.explanation: A Middle English form of garland .

germ.explanation: A small mass of protoplasm or cells from which a new organism or one of its parts may develop.
The earliest form of an organism; a seed, bud, or spore.
A microorganism, especially a pathogen.
Something that may serve as the basis of further growth or development.

In biology , the first rudiment of any organism; the earliest stage in the development of an organism; the simplest recognizable condition of a living thing; in botany , technically, the embryo of a seed, or, in the Linnean use of the word, the ovary.
By extension, an early or but slightly developed state of an organism; an early embryo. See embryo .
Some or any microbe or micro-organism; a spore: as, a cholera-germ. See germicide .
That from which anything springs or may spring as if from a seed or root; a rudimentary element; a formative principle: as, the germs of civil liberty or of prosperity.

In pathology , the doctrine that zymotic diseases, together with some not usually classed as zymotic, are due to the presence in the body of living organisms. These organisms, which, so far as they have been positively identified, belong for the most part to the group of bacteria, produce their morbid effects by their vital activity, and probably in large part by the formation of poisons called ptomaines . This doctrine no longer rests upon indirect evidence alone, but also on the positive identification of the peccant organisms in a certain number of diseases, as in phthisis, anthrax, relapsing fever, typhoid fever, and some others. Synonyms Fetus, Rudiment. See embryo .
That which is to develop a new individual; ; the earliest form under which an organism appears.
That from which anything springs; origin; first principle.
The germ cells, collectively, as distinguished from the somatic cells, or soma . Germ is often used in place of germinal to form phrases
A microorganism, especially a disease-causing bacterium or virus; -- used informally, .

a name applied to certain tiny bacterial organisms or their spores, such as Anthrax bacillus and the Micrococcus of fowl cholera, which have been demonstrated to be the cause of certain diseases; same as germ{4}. See Germ theory (below).

the germ, egg, spore, or cell from which the plant or animal arises. At one time a part of the body of the parent, it finally becomes detached, and by a process of multiplication and growth gives rise to a mass of cells, which ultimately form a new individual like the parent. See Ovum .
See Gonad .
a special process on which buds are developed in certain animals. See Doliolum .

the theory that living organisms can be produced only by the evolution or development of living germs or seeds. See Biogenesis , and Abiogenesis . As applied to the origin of disease, the theory claims that the zymotic diseases are due to the rapid development and multiplication of various bacteria, the germs or spores of which are either contained in the organism itself, or transferred through the air or water. See Fermentation theory.
To germinate.
The small mass of cells from which a new organism develops ; a seed , bud or spore .
A pathogenic microorganism .
An idea that forms the basis of some project .
The embryo of a seed , especially of a seed used as a cereal or grain . See Wikipedia article on cereal germ.
To germinate
to grow, as if parasitic
anything that provides inspiration for later work
a small apparently simple structure (as a fertilized egg) from which new tissue can develop into a complete organism
a minute life form (especially a disease-causing bacterium); the term is not in technical use

german.explanation: One sprung from the same stock; specifically, a full brother, sister, or cousin.
A member of the German race, or a native or an inhabitant of Germany. See I.

The language of Germany or of the German people, a sub-branch or division of the Teutonic or Germanic branch of Indo-European or Aryan language. Its two principal divisions are the Low German, of the northern or lower part of the country, and the High German, of the southern or higher part. See High German, Low German , below.
Especially, the literary language of Germany.

[ lowercase ] In dancing : An elaborate form of the cotillion, in which round dances predominate and the figures vary according to the invention of the leader, and in which the changing of partners and giving of favors form a special feature.
An entertainment at which the german exclusively is danced.
[ lowercase ] In coal-mining , a straw filled with gunpowder, used as a fuse in blasting.
Nearly related; closely akin.
See Brother german .
See the Note under Cousin .
A native or one of the people of Germany.
The German language.
A round dance, often with a waltz movement, abounding in capriciosly involved figures.
A social party at which the german is danced.

the Teutonic dialect of Upper or Southern Germany, -- comprising Old High German , used from the 8th to the 11th century; Middle H. G ., from the 12th to the 15th century; and Modern or New H. G ., the language of Luther's Bible version and of modern German literature. The dialects of Central Germany, the basis of the modern literary language, are often called Middle German , and the Southern German dialects Upper German ; but High German is also used to cover both groups.

the language of Northern Germany and the Netherlands, -- including Friesic ; Anglo-Saxon or Saxon ; Old Saxon ; Dutch or Low Dutch , with its dialect, Flemish ; and Plattdeutsch (called also Low German ), spoken in many dialects.
Of or pertaining to Germany.
See Dunker .
a wood-boring tool, having a long elliptical pod and a scew point.
the crucian carp.
a kind of millet ( Setaria Italica , var.), whose seed is sometimes used for food.
a prepared food for caged birds.
the process of reducing copper ore in a blast furnace, after roasting, if necessary.
a substitute for sarsaparilla extract.
a polony, or gut stuffed with meat partly cooked.

a silver-white alloy, hard and tough, but malleable and ductile, and quite permanent in the air. It is essentially identical with the Chinese alloy packfong . It was formerly much used for tableware, knife handles, frames, cases, bearings of machinery, etc., but is now largely superseded by other white alloys.
