a protein substance that remains when starch is removed from cereal grains; gives cohesiveness to dough

glutenin.explanation: That portion of vegetable gluten which is insoluble in alcohol. Also termed gluten-fibrin. See gluten .

glutethimide.explanation: A hypnotic sedative formerly used as an alternative to barbiturates to treat insomnia .
sedative (trade name Doriden) used to treat some sleep disorders

gluteus.explanation: Any of the three large muscles of each buttock, especially the gluteus maximus, that extend, abduct, and rotate the thigh.
One of the several muscles of nates , which arises from a pelvis and inserted into a femur .
Short for gluteus maximus , the large muscles in the human buttocks .
any one of three large skeletal muscles that form the buttock and move the thigh

glutin.explanation: Same as gelatin . It forms the chief part of carpenters' glue. Not to be confounded with gluten or any of its components.

glutinate.explanation: To unite with glue; to cement; to stick together.
To unite with glue ; to cement ; to stick together.

glutination.explanation: The act of glutinating or uniting with glue.
The act of uniting with glue; sticking together.
A gluing together; a joining together with, or as though with, glue .
Something that is used to close up a wound or join together the parts of a broken bone, torn vein, etc; the process of applying such a glutination to a wound.

glutinative.explanation: Having the quality of cementing; tenacious; viscous; glutinous.

glutinosity.explanation: The state or quality of being glutinous; glutinousness.
The quality of being glutinous; viscousness.
The quality of being glutinous or viscous .
the property of having a viscosity like jelly

glutinous.explanation: Of the nature of or resembling glue; sticky.
Of the nature of glue; resembling glue; viscous; viscid; adhesive; gluey.
Havig a moist and adhesive or sticky surface, as a leaf or gland.
having the sticky properties of an adhesive

glutinousness.explanation: The state or quality of being glutinous; viscosity; viscidity; tenacity; glutinosity.
the property of having a viscosity like jelly

glutoid.explanation: Gelatin hardened with formaldehyde: used in making capsules.

gluts.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of glut .

glutted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of glut .

glutton.explanation: A person who eats or consumes immoderate amounts of food and drink.
A person with an inordinate capacity to receive or withstand something.
One who indulges to excess in eating, or in eating and drinking; one who gorges himself with food; a gormandizer.
One who indulges in anything to excess; a greedy person.
In zoöl.: A popular name of the wolverene, Gulo luscus or arcticus , the largest and most voracious species of the family Mustelidæ.
In pugilism , one who takes a great deal of punishment before he is beaten.
One who eats voraciously, or to excess; a gormandizer.

A carnivorous mammal ( Gulo gulo formerly Gulo luscus ), of the weasel family Mustelidæ , about the size of a large badger; called also wolverine , wolverene and carcajou . It was formerly believed to be inordinately voracious, whence the name. It is a native of the northern parts of America, Europe, and Asia.
the giant fulmar ( Ossifraga gigantea ); -- called also Mother Carey's goose , and mollymawk .
One who eats voraciously , obsessively , or to excess ; a gormandizer .
One who consumes voraciously , obsessively , or to excess

A carnivorous mammal (Gulo gulo), of the family Mustelidæ , about the size of a large badger. It was formerly believed to be inordinately voracious, whence the name; the wolverine . It is a native of the northern parts of America, Europe, and Asia.
a person who is devoted to eating and drinking to excess

gluttonise.explanation: eat a lot and without restraint

gluttonism.explanation: The state of being a glutton .

gluttonize.explanation: To eat to excess; to eat voraciously; to gormandize.
To eat an excessive amount, or voraciously .
eat a lot and without restraint

gluttonized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gluttonize .

gluttonous.explanation: Given to gluttony; eating to excess; indulging the appetite; voracious.
Given to excessive eating ; prone to overeating .
given to excess in consumption of especially food or drink

gluttony.explanation: Excess in eating, or in eating and drinking; extravagant indulgence of the appetite for food; voracity; luxury of the table.
Excess in eating; extravagant indulgence of the appetite for food; voracity.
The vice of eating to excess .
eating to excess (personified as one of the deadly sins)

glycan.explanation: Any of a group of sugar molecules that are freestanding as oligosaccharides or polysaccharides or are combined in conjugates, as in glycoproteins.
Any polysaccharide or oligosaccharide , epsecially one that is part of a glycoprotein or glycolipid

glycemia.explanation: Presence of (an unusual amount of) glucose in the blood .

glycemic.explanation: Of, pertaining to or suffering from glycemia

glyceral.explanation: One of certain compounds obtained by the action of glycerol on an aldehyde.

glyceraldehyde.explanation: A sweet colorless crystalline solid, C 3 H 6 O 3 , that is an intermediate compound in carbohydrate metabolism.
The aldotriose 2,3-dihydroxypropanal formed by oxidation of glycerol
a sweet crystalline aldehyde formed by the breakdown of sugars

glycerate.explanation: Any salt or ester of glyceric acid

glyceria.explanation: A genus of grasses, closely allied to Poa and Festuca.

glyceric.explanation: Pertaining to, or derived from, glycerin.
an organic acid, obtained by the partial oxidation of glycerin, as a thick liquid. It is a hydroxyl derivative of propionic acid, and has both acid and alcoholic properties.
Of or pertaining to glyceric acid or its derivatives

glyceride.explanation: An ester formed between one or more acids and glycerol. Fatty acid esters with glycerol are found in plant oils and animal fats.
In chem. , a compound ether of the triatomic alcohol glycerol or glycerin.
A compound ether (formed from glycerin ). Some glycerides exist ready formed as natural fats, others are produced artificially.
An ester of glycerol and one or more fatty acid ; they are the major constituents of lipids .
an ester of glycerol and fatty acids that occurs naturally as fats and fatty oils

glyceridic.explanation: Of or pertaining to glycerol or glycerides

glycerin.explanation: Glycerol or a preparation of glycerol.
Formerly a general designation for compounds similar to glycerol in that they contain three hydroxyl groups.
A transparent, colorless, hygroscopic liquid (C 3 H 5 (OH) 3 ), with a sweet taste and syrupy consistence.

An oily, viscous liquid, C3H5(OH)3, colorless and odorless, and with a hot, sweetish taste, existing in the natural fats and oils as the base, combined with various acids, as oleic, margaric, stearic, and palmitic. It may be obtained by saponification of fats and oils. It is a triatomic alcohol, and hence is also called glycerol . See Note under gelatin .
a sweet syrupy trihydroxy alcohol obtained by saponification of fats and oils

glycerinated.explanation: Modified by reaction or treatment with glycerine

glycerination.explanation: Treatment or dilution with glycerol. Thus calf's lymph is mixed with glycerol, which, after a time, kills bacterial organisms that are often present in ordinary lymph.

glycerine.explanation: a sweet syrupy trihydroxy alcohol obtained by saponification of fats and oils

glycerite.explanation: The general name of a class of preparations consisting of a medicinal substance dissolved or suspended in glycerol. Also glycerate, glycerol, glycerole.
A medicinal preparation made by mixing or dissolving a substance in glycerin.
A medicinal preparation made by mixing or dissolving a substance in glycerine .
a medicine made by mixing a substance in glycerin

glycerogel.explanation: a medicated skin preparation made from glycerin and glycerinated gelatin

glycerogelatin.explanation: A stiff jelly consisting of gelatin 1 part, water 6 parts, and glycerin 7 parts: used in microscopy as a mounting and embedding medium. Also glycerin gelatin, glycerin jelly, glycerin gum.
a medicated skin preparation made from glycerin and glycerinated gelatin

glycerol.explanation: A syrupy, sweet, colorless or yellowish liquid triol, C 3 H 8 O 3 , obtained from fats and oils as a byproduct of saponification and used as a solvent, antifreeze, plasticizer, and sweetener and in the manufacture of dynamite, cosmetics, liquid soaps, inks, and lubricants.

A syrupy sweet liquid obtained as a by-product in the manufacture of soap from animal or vegetable oils and fats ; it is used as an antifreeze , a plasticizer , and a food sweetener and in the manufacture of dynamite , cosmetics etc.
a sweet syrupy trihydroxy alcohol obtained by saponification of fats and oils

glycerole.explanation: a medicine made by mixing a substance in glycerin

glycerolysis.explanation: Any reaction of an ester with glycerol , but especially the reaction of triglycerides with glycerol to form monoglycerides and diglycerides

glycerophosphate.explanation: A salt of glycerophosphoric acid with a base (iron, quinine, calcium, etc.): employed in medicine as a nerve tonic.
Any salt or ester of glycerophosphoric acid ; but especially the phospholipids

glycerophosphoric.explanation: 3 H 9 O 6 P, a decomposition-product of lecithin in which it is present, in combination with choline, two of its hydroxyl groups being replaced by fatty-acid radicals.
Of or pertaining to glycerophosphoric acid or its derivatives

glycerose.explanation: A substance formed by the oxidation of glycerol by dilute nitric acid or bromine. It was thought to be a triose, C 3 H 6 O 3 , but is now known to be a mixture of glycerol aldehyde and glycerol ketone.

glyceryl.explanation: A trivalent alkyl group, CH 2 CH 2 , obtained from glycerol by the removal of hydroxyl groups.
The hypothetical triatomic radical of glycerol and the glycerides. Also called, more suitably, propenyl.
A compound radical, C3H5, regarded as the essential radical of glycerin. It is metameric with allyl. Called also propenyl .
Either of the univalent , divalent or trivalent radicals derived from glycerol by removing hydrogen atoms from one, two or three hydroxyl groups
a trivalent radical derived from glycerol by removing the three hydroxyl radicals

glycid.explanation: A colorless liquid the anhydrid of glycerol, into which it is rapidly converted by the action of water. It boils at 160°C. Also called hydroxypropyleneoxid .

glycide.explanation: A colorless liquid, obtained from certain derivatives of glycerin, and regarded as a partially dehydrated glycerin; -- called also glycidic alcohol .
A colourless liquid obtained from certain derivatives of glycerin , and regarded as a partially dehydrated glycerin; glycidic alcohol .

glycidic.explanation: Pertaining to, or derived from, glycide.
Pertaining to, or derived from, glycide .

glycidol.explanation: The epoxide derived from glycerol ; it has a number of industrial uses

glycin.explanation: A poisonous crystalline derivative of glycine, C 8 H 9 NO 3 , used as a photographic developer.
A phenolic derivative of glycine , N-(4-hydroxyphenyl)glycine, used as a photographic developer

glycine.explanation: A sweet-tasting crystalline nonessential amino acid, C 2 H 5 NO 2 , that is the principal amino acid occurring in sugar cane. The simplest amino acid found in protein, it is derived from the alkaline hydrolysis of gelatin and used in biochemical research and medicine.
A genus of plants of the family Fabaceæ. See Apios .
A name incorrectly applied to Soia , a genus of plants belonging to the family Fabaceæ and including the soy-bean. See Soia .
A nonessential amino acid , amino-acetic acid, C2H5NO2 found in most proteins but especially in sugar cane ; the simplest amino acid .
genus of Asiatic erect or sprawling herbs: soya bean
the simplest amino acid found in proteins and the principal amino acid in sugar cane

glycinin.explanation: A globulin found in the soy-bean.
Any of the main protein found in soybean

glycocholate.explanation: A salt formed by the union of glycocholic acid with a base.
Any salt or ester of glycocholic acid .

glycocholic.explanation: Pertaining to, or composed of, glycocoll and cholic acid.
a conjugate acid, composed of glycocoll and cholic acid, present in bile in the form of a sodium salt. The acid commonly forms a resinous mass, but can be crystallized in long, white needles.

glycogelatin.explanation: A jelly-like mixture of glycerin and gelatin, used in the manufacture of lozenges and pastils and also as a vehicle for exhibiting external remedies.

glycogen.explanation: A polysaccharide, (C 6 H 10 O 5 ) n , that is the main form of carbohydrate storage in animals and occurs primarily in the liver and muscle tissue. It is readily converted to glucose as needed by the body to satisfy its energy needs.
A substance, C 6 H 10 O 5 , belonging to the carbohydrates.

A white, amorphous, tasteless substance resembling starch, soluble in water to an opalescent fluid. It is found abundantly in the liver of most animals, and in small quantity in other organs and tissues, particularly in the embryo. It is quickly changed into sugar when boiled with dilute sulphuric or hydrochloric acid, and also by the action of amylolytic ferments.
A polysaccharide that is the main form of carbohydrate storage in animals ; converted to glucose as needed.
one form in which body fuel is stored; stored primarily in the liver and broken down into glucose when needed by the body

glycogenesis.explanation: The formation or synthesis of glycogen.
In pathology , the formation of glucose.
The synthesis of glycogen from glucose
the formation in animals of glycogen from glucose
the conversion of glucose to glycogen when the glucose in the blood exceeds the demand

glycogenic.explanation: Pertaining to, or caused by, glycogen.
Pertaining to, or caused by, glycogen .
of or relating to or involving glycogen

glycogenolysis.explanation: The biochemical breakdown of glycogen to glucose.
The production of glucose-1-phosphate by splitting a glucose monomer from glycogen using inorganic phosphate

glycogenolytic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or capable of glycogenolysis , the catabolism of glycogen

glycogenosis.explanation: Any of various genetic diseases caused by enzyme deficiencies and characterized by the abnormal accumulation of glycogen in tissue.
A metabolic disorder characterized by the inability to metabolize glycogen properly

glycogeny.explanation: The production or formation of sugar from gycogen, as in the liver.

glycol.explanation: Any of various diols, usually containing vicinal hydroxyl groups.
The general name of a class of compounds intermediate in their properties and chemical relations between alcohol and glycerol, or the bodies of which these are the types.
A thick, colorless liquid, C2H4(OH)2, of a sweetish taste, produced artificially from certain ethylene compounds. It is a diacid alcohol, intermediate between ordinary ethyl alcohol and glycerin.
Any one of the large class of diacid alcohols, of which glycol proper is the type.
A thick , colourless liquid , C2H4(OH)2, of a sweetish taste , produced artificially from certain ethylene compounds and used as an antifreeze ; ethylene glycol .
a sweet but poisonous syrupy liquid used as an antifreeze and solvent
any of a class of alcohols having 2 hydroxyl groups in each molecule

glycolaldehyde.explanation: A syrupy compound, HOCH 2 .CHO, obtained by the action of barium hydroxid on bromacetaldehyde. It readily gives rise to sugars. Also called hydroxyacetaldehyde .
The hydroxy aldehyde HO-CH2-CHO related to ethylene glycol ; the only biose

glycolate.explanation: Any salt or ester of a glycolic acid

glycolic.explanation: Pertaining to, or derived from, glycol

an organic acid, found naturally in unripe grapes and in the leaves of the wild grape ( Ampelopsis quinquefolia ), and produced artificially in many ways, as by the oxidation of glycol , -- whence its name. It is a sirupy, or white crystalline, substance, HO.CH2.CO2H, has the properties both of an alcohol and an acid, and is a type of the hydroxy acids; -- called also hydroxyacetic acid .
Of or pertaining to glycolic acid or its derivatives

glycolide.explanation: A white amorphous powder, C4H4O, obtained by heating and dehydrating glycolic acid.
A lactone formed from two molecules of glycolic acid ; any derivative of this compound

glycolipid.explanation: A lipid that contains one or more carbohydrate groups.
an association of a carbohydrate and a phospholipid , such as phosphatidylinositol , found in cell membranes

glycollate.explanation: Any salt or ester of glycolic acid .

glycoluric.explanation: Pertaining to, derived from, glycol and urea.

glycoluril.explanation: A colorless compound, which crystallizes in white needles: formed by the action of hydrochloric acid on a mixture of glyoxal and urea. Also called acetylene urea .
A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance, obtained by the reduction of allantoïn.
A nitrogenous substance obtained by reduction of allantoin .

glycolyl.explanation: A bivalent organic radical, CH 2 CO.
A divalent, compound radical, CO.CH2, regarded as the essential radical of glycolic acid, and a large series of related compounds.
The univalent radical HO-CH2-CO- derived from glycolic acid

glycolysis.explanation: An ATP-generating metabolic process that occurs in nearly all living cells in which glucose is converted in a series of steps to pyruvic acid.
The metabolic breakdown of glucose and other sugars that releases energy in the form of ATP.
The destruction of sugar in the animal body.
The cellular degradation of the simple sugar glucose to yield pyruvic acid , and ATP as an energy source.
a metabolic process that breaks down carbohydrates and sugars through a series of reactions to either pyruvic acid or lactic acid and releases energy for the body in the form of ATP

glycolytic.explanation: Of, pertaining to or producing glycolysis

glyconic.explanation: [ lowercase ] In ancient prosody , a meter consisting in a series similar to a trochaic tetrapody catalectic . but differing from it by the substitution of a dactyl for the second trochee; by an extension of meaning, any logaœdic tetrapody, catalectic or acatalectic, in which three of the feet are trochees and one is a dactyl.
Consisting of a spondee, a choriamb, and a pyrrhic; -- applied to a kind of verse in Greek and Latin poetry.

glyconin.explanation: In pharmacy , an emulsion of glycerol and yolk of egg.
An emulsion of glycerin and the yolk of eggs, used as an ointment, as a vehicle for medicines, etc.
An emulsion of glycerin and egg yolk , used as an ointment , as a vehicle for medicines , etc.

glycopeptide.explanation: any compound of a carbohydrate and a peptide

glycoprotein.explanation: Any of a group of conjugated proteins having a carbohydrate as the nonprotein component.
A protein with covalently bonded carbohydrates .
a conjugated protein having a carbohydrate component

glycose.explanation: One of a class of carbohydrates having from three to nine atoms of carbon in the molecules and having the constitution either of an aldehyde alcohol or of a ketone alcohol. Most glycoses have hydrogen and oxygen present in the proportion to form water, while the number of carbon atoms is usually equal to the number of atoms of oxygen.

glycosidase.explanation: Any enzyme that catalyses the hydrolysis of a glycoside

glycoside.explanation: Any of a group of organic compounds, occurring abundantly in plants, that yield a sugar and one or more nonsugar substances on hydrolysis.
A molecule in which a sugar group (the glycone) is bound to a non-sugar group (the corresponding aglycone ) by a nitrogen or oxygen atom. Glycosides yield a sugar after undergoing hydrolysis .
a group of compounds derived from monosaccharides

glycosidic.explanation: Of or pertaining to a glycoside .

glycosidically.explanation: In a glycosidic manner; by means of a glycoside

glycosine.explanation: A colorless compound, , crystallizing in needles which sublime without melting. It is prepared by the interaction of ammonia and glyoxal. Also called diglyoxaline .
An organic base, C6H6N4, produced artificially as a white, crystalline powder, by the action of ammonia on glyoxal.
An organic base , C6H6N4, produced by the action of ammonia on glyoxal .

The organic compound 1-methyl-2-(phenylmethyl)-4(1H)-quinazolinone (a fused derivative of pyrimidine ) found in the toothbrush plant, Glycosmis pentaphylla, sometimes used to ease the pain of arthritis

glycosuria.explanation: Excess sugar in the urine, often associated with diabetes mellitus.
The presence of sugars (especially glucose ) in the blood , often as a result of diabetes mellitus
the presence of abnormally high levels of sugar in the urine

glycosyl.explanation: Any functional group derived from a sugar (especially from a monosaccharide ) by removal of the hemiacetal hydroxy group

glycyl.explanation: The univalent radical obtained by removal of a hydrogen atom from the carboxylic acid group of glycine

glycyrrhizin.explanation: A peculiar saccharine matter (C 24 H 36 O 9 ) obtained from the root of Glycyrrhiza glabra.
A glucoside found in licorice root (Glycyrrhiza), in monesia bark (Chrysophyllum), in the root of the walnut, etc., and extracted as a yellow, amorphous powder, of a bittersweet taste.
The main sweet -tasting compound from liquorice root , thirty to fifty times as sweet as sucrose (table sugar).

glyn.explanation: An element in some Celtic place-names, meaning ‘glen’: as, Glyn-crwg, Glyn-taf , in Wales; Glynn in Antrim, Ireland.
A glen. See glen . [Obs. singly, but occurring often in locative names in Ireland, as Glen does in Scotland.]
A valley in a mountain area, especially one with a stream in the bottom

glyoxal.explanation: A white, amorphous, deliquescent solid (CHO.CHO), soluble in water and alcohol. It is an aldehyde of oxalic acid.
A white, amorphous, deliquescent powder, (CO.H)2, obtained by the partial oxidation of glycol. It is a double aldehyde, between glycol and oxalic acid.
The dialdehyde ethanedial derived from ethylene glycol ; it is used in the preparation of modified starch for the paper industry.

glyoxalase.explanation: Either of a pair of related thiol -dependent enzymes : glyoxalase І, which catalyses the isomerisation of the spontaneously formed hemithioacetal adduct between GSH and 2-oxoaldehydes (such as methylglyoxal ) into S-2-hydroxyacylglutathione; and glyoxalase ІІ, which hydrolyses these thiolesters.

glyoxalic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, an aldehyde acid, intermediate between glycol and oxalic acid.

glyoxaline.explanation: A colorless compound , formed together with glycoside, by the action of concentrated ammonia on glyoxal.

A white, crystalline, organic base, C3H4N2, produced by the action of ammonia on glyoxal, and forming the origin of a large class of derivatives hence, any one of the series of which glyoxaline is a type; -- called also oxaline .
An organic base , C3H4N2, produced by the action of ammonia on glyoxal .
Any of the series of which glyoxaline is a type .
an organic base C3H4N2; a histamine inhibitor

glyoxime.explanation: A colorless compound, HON:CHCH: NOH, prepared by the action of hydroxylamine on glyoxal. It crystallizes in trimetrie plates and melts at 178° C.

A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance, produced by the action of hydroxylamine on glyoxal, and belonging to the class of oximes ; also, any one of a group of substances resembling glyoxime proper, and of which it is a type. See oxime .
The oxime HO-N=CH-CH=N-OH produced by the action of hydroxylamine on glyoxal

glyoxylic.explanation: Of or pertaining to glyoxylic acid or its derivatives

glyph.explanation: A vertical groove, especially in a Doric column or frieze.
A symbolic figure that is usually engraved or incised.
A symbol, such as a stylized figure or arrow on a public sign, that imparts information nonverbally.
In sculpture and architecture , a groove or channel, usually vertical, intended as an ornament. See triglyph .
A written or pictured character, sign, or symbol representing a word or an idea; an ideograph: as, the Mexican or Mayan glyphs.
A sunken channel or groove, usually vertical. See triglyph .
A carved figure or character, incised or in relief; a carved pictograph; hence, a pictograph representing a form originally adopted for sculpture, whether carved or painted.
A figure carved in relief or incised , especially representing a sound , word , or idea .
Any non-verbal symbol that imparts information .
A visual representation of a letter , character , or symbol , in a specific font and style .
glyptic art in the form of a symbolic figure carved or incised in relief

glyphic.explanation: A picture or figure by which a word is implied; a hieroglyphic.
Of or pertaining to sculpture or carving of any sort, esp. to glyphs.

glyphograph.explanation: A plate formed by glyphography, or an impression taken from such a plate.
A plate made by glyphography, or an impression taken from such a plate.
A plate made by glyphography , or an impression taken from such a plate.

glyphographer.explanation: One versed in, or one who practises, glyphography.

glyphography.explanation: A kind of electrotypy by means of which plates engraved in relief are made, from which impressions can be taken.
A process similar to etching, in which, by means of voltaic electricity, a raised copy of a drawing is made, so that it can be used to print from.
A process similar to etching in which, by means of voltaic electricity , a raised copy of a drawing is made, so that it can be used to print from.

glyptic.explanation: Of or relating to engraving or carving, especially on precious stones.
Of or pertaining to gem engraving.
Of or pertaining to engraving , especially on precious stones.

glyptics.explanation: The art of engraving or carving, especially on precious stones; glyptography.
The art of carving or engraving.
The art of engraving on precious stones.
The art of engraving on precious stones .
the art of engraving on precious stones

glyptodon.explanation: The typical and best-known genus of the family Glyptodontidæ ; the long-tailed fossil armadillos or glyptodons, with 5 toes on the hind feet and 4 on the fore, the fifth digit of which is wanting. Species are G. clavipes and G. reticulatus , from the Pleistocene of South America.
[ lowercase ] An animal of the family Glyptodontidæ ) or Hoplophoridæ ; one of the gigantic fossil armadillos of South America.
An extinct South American quaternary mammal, allied to the armadillos. It was as large as an ox, was covered with tessellated scales, and had fluted teeth.
An extinct South American quaternary mammal , allied to the armadillos , with tessellated scales and fluted teeth .

glyptodont.explanation: One of a family ( Glyptodontidæ ) of extinct South American edentates, of which Glyptodon is the type. About twenty species are known.
Any extinct South American edentate of the family Glyptodontidae

glyptograph.explanation: An engraved inscription on a precious stone.
An engraving on a gem or other small object. See gem-engraving .

glyptographer.explanation: An engraver on gems or the like.

glyptographic.explanation: Relating to glyptography, or the art of engraving on precious stones.
Relating to glyptography , the art of engraving on precious stones.

glyptography.explanation: The art or process of carving or engraving on precious stones.
The art or process of carving or engraving, particularly of engraving on gems or the like.
A description of the art of gemengraving.
The art or process of engraving on precious stones.
carving or engraving on precious stone
carvings or engravings (especially on precious stones)

glyptologist.explanation: A student or collector of engraved gems.

glyptology.explanation: The study of engraved gems and other small sculpture.

glyptotheca.explanation: A building or room for the preservation of works of sculpture.
A building or room devoted to works of sculpture.
A room or building devoted to works of sculpture .

gmelina.explanation: A deciduous Asian tree (Gmelina arborea) in the mint family, having large leaves, brownish-yellow flowers, and yellow fruit, and widely grown for timber and pulp.
A genus of verbenaceous shrubs and trees, including 8 species of eastern Asia and Australia.

gmelinite.explanation: A zeolitic mineral closely related to chabazite in form and composition, and like it often occurring in rhombohedral crystals. It varies in color from white to flesh-red. Ledererite is a variety from Nova Scotia.
A rhombohedral zeolitic mineral, related in form and composition to chabazite.
A rare zeolite mineral related to chabazite .

gnamma.explanation: A rock hole , capable of holding water , formed by weathering .

gnaphalioid.explanation: botany , belonging or pertaining to the group of genera (in the order Compositæ ) of which Gnaphalium is the type.

gnaphalium.explanation: A large genus of hoary-tomentose or woolly herbs, belonging to the order Compositæ.
[ lowercase ] A plant of this genus.
A genus of composite plants with white or colored dry and persistent involucres; a kind of everlasting.
Any of the genus Gnaphalium of flowering plants , the cudweeds .
large widely distributed genus of coarse hairy herbs with whitish involucres

gnar.explanation: A knot or gnarl in wood; hence, a tough, thickset man; -- written also gnarr .
To gnarl; to snarl; to growl; -- written also gnarr .

gnarl.explanation: A protruding knot on a tree.
A knot; a knotty growth in wood; a rough irregular protuberance on a tree.
a knot in wood; a large or hard knot, or a protuberance with twisted grain, on a tree.
To snarl or growl ; to gnar .
A knot in wood ; a large or hard knot, or a protuberance with twisted grain, on a tree.
Something resembling a knot in wood, such as in stone or limbs.

The average value of the magnitude squared of the curl of a vector field over a continuous path that is tangent to the vector field at every point. In mathematical notation, gnarl is represented by the lowercase Greek letter ξ .
make complaining remarks or noises under one's breath
something twisted and tight and swollen
twist into a state of deformity

gnarled.explanation: Rugged and roughened, as from old age or work.
Knotty; full of knots or gnarls; twisted; crossgrained.
Simple past tense and past participle of gnarl. (Etymology 2)
made rough by age or hard work
Simple past tense and past participle of gnarl. (Etymology 1)
used of old persons or old trees; covered with knobs or knots

gnarlier.explanation: comparative form of gnarly : more gnarly

gnarliest.explanation: superlative form of gnarly : most gnarly .

gnarling.explanation: Roughened ridging or milling on the edge of a set-screw or other part of a machine. It is made with a gnarling-tool for the purpose of affording a firm hold. Also called gnarled work .

gnarls.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gnarl .

gnarly.explanation: Characterized by violent motion; powerful or turbulent.
Full of knots; knotty; twisted; crossgrained.
having or characterized by gnarls ; gnarled
Of music or a sound, harsh
used of old persons or old trees; covered with knobs or knots

gnarred.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gnar .

gnars.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gnar .

gnash.explanation: To grind or strike (the teeth, for example) together.
To bite (something) by grinding the teeth.
To grind or strike the teeth together.
To strike together, as in anger or pain.
To grind one's teeth in pain or in anger .

gnashed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gnash .

gnashes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gnash .

gnashing.explanation: The act of snapping, grating, or grinding together (the teeth), as in anguish or despair.

gnast.explanation: A spark; a dying spark; a dead spark, as of a candle snuffed.
A spark ; a dying spark; a dead spark, as of a snuffed candle.

gnat.explanation: Any of various tiny two-winged flies, especially those that sometimes form swarms.
A small two-winged fly, Culex pipiens , of the family Culicidæ , suborder Nemocera , and order Diptera , called in America mosquito .
Any other insect of the family Culicidæ .—
A nemocerous dipterous insect; a midge.

A blood-sucking dipterous fly, of the genus Culex, undergoing a metamorphosis in water. The females have a proboscis armed with needlelike organs for penetrating the skin of animals. These are wanting in the males. In America they are generally called mosquitoes . See mosquito .
Any fly resembling a Culex in form or habits; esp., in America, a small biting fly of the genus Simulium and allies, as the buffalo gnat, the black fly, etc.
one of several species of small American singing birds, of the genus Polioptila, allied to the kinglets.
the European goatsucker; -- called also gnat owl .
a person ostentatiously punctilious about trifles. Cf. Matt. xxiii. 24.
Any small insect of the order Diptera , specifically within the suborder Nematocera .
any of various small biting flies: midges; biting midges; black flies; sand flies

gnatcatcher.explanation: Any of several tiny birds of the genus Polioptila, found throughout the Americas and having a long tail and a slender bill.
A bird of the genus Polioptila , of which there are about 12 American Species.
A member of any of various species of small passerine birds found in North America and South America , close relatives of the wrens .
very small North American and South American warblers

gnateater.explanation: Any of the South American passerine birds in the family Conopophagidae .

gnathic.explanation: Of or relating to the jaw.
craniometry , pertaining to the alveolus of the jaws; alveolar: as, the gnathic or alveolar index (which see, under craniometry ). Also gnathal .
Of or pertaining to the jaw.

in a skull, the ratio of the distance from the middle of the nasofrontal suture to the basion (taken equal to 100), to the distance from the basion to the middle of the front edge of the upper jaw; -- called also alveolar index .
Of or pertaining to the jaw .

gnathidium.explanation: The mandibular ramus of a bird's bill; either prong or fork of the lower mandible.
The ramus of the lower jaw of a bird as far as it is naked; -- commonly used in the plural.
The ramus of the lower jaw of a bird as far as it is naked.

gnathion.explanation: Same as mental point (which see). See also cut under craniometry .
the most inferior point of the mandible in the midline

gnathism.explanation: The angle of projection of the upper jaw measured by the angle between the horizontal and one of the facial lines. see prognathism, orthognathism.

gnathite.explanation: A jawlike appendage of an arthropod.
In zoology , one of the appendages of the mouth of an arthropod or articulate animal, as a mandible, maxilla, maxilliped, gnathopod, etc.
Any one of the mouth appendages of the Arthropoda. They are known as mandibles, maxillæ, and maxillipeds.
Any of the mouth appendages of the Arthropoda .

gnathitis.explanation: In pathology , inflammation of the jaw.

gnatho.explanation: A genus of tiger-beetles or Cicindelinæ: same as Megacephala .
A genus of wasps, of the family Crabronidæ.
A genus of hymenopterous parasites, of the family Chalcididæ .

gnathobase.explanation: The proximal or coxal extremity of the leg in many Crustacea when modified for the purpose of crushing food by the development of a series of short hard spines, as in Limulus .
A lower appendage of many arthropods , used to macerate food items.

gnathometer.explanation: An instrument used for measuring the angles of the lower jaw.

gnathopod.explanation: Gnathopoda , in any sense. Also gnathopodous .
A member of the Gnathopoda , of any kind.
A gnathopodite or maxilliped. See maxilliped .

gnathopoda.explanation: Crustacea , corresponding to Entomostraca in a broad sense; the lower series of the crustaceans, contrasted with the malacostracans or Thoracipoda .
Arthropoda considered as a prime division of a phylum Appendiculata (which see).

gnathopodite.explanation: One of the limbs which in crustaceans and other arthropods are modified into mouth-parts; a mouth-foot, jaw-foot, or foot-jaw; a maxilliped; a gnathite.
Any leglike appendage of a crustacean, when modified wholly, or in part, to serve as a jaw, esp. one of the maxillipeds.
Any leg -like appendage of a crustacean that is modified to serve as a jaw .

gnathostegite.explanation: In Crustacea , a lamellar expansion of the ischiopodite and meropodite of the external maxilliped or third thoracic limb, which with its fellow covers the other mouth-parts. It may be terminated by a small jointed endognathal palp.
One of a pair of broad plates, developed from the outer maxillipeds of crabs, and forming a cover for the other mouth organs.
One of a pair of broad plates , developed from the outer maxillipeds of crabs , and forming a cover for the other organs in the mouth .

gnathostoma.explanation: A genus of nematoid entozoic worms, found in the stomach of the Felidœ or cat tribe. R. Owen . See Chiracanthus , 2.
A comprehensive division of vertebrates, including all that have distinct jaws, in contrast with the leptocardians and marsipobranchs (Cyclostoma), which lack them.

gnathostomata.explanation: A tribe of irregular echinoids having a central peristome surrounded by a perignathic girdle, the ambulacra all similar, and the jaws present but sometimes rudimentary. It includes both living and extinct genera.
A name given by Haeckel to a superclass of vertebrates containing the forms with true jaws, (normally) two pairs of limbs, and double nostrils. Same as Gnathostomi and synonomous with Amphirhina.
comprising all vertebrates with upper and lower jaws

gnathostome.explanation: Any of numerous animals of the group Gnathostomata, consisting of all vertebrates with jaws and including the mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fishes except for lampreys and hagfishes.
A member of the Gnathostomata , or vertebrates having true jaws.
Any vertebrate with jaws , including amphibians , reptiles , mammals , and most modern fish .
a vertebrate animal possessing true jaws

gnathotheca.explanation: In ornith ., the integument of the gnathidium; the horny or leathery investment of the under mandible.
The horney covering of the lower mandible of a bird.
The horny covering of the lower part of a bird's beak .

gnatlike.explanation: Resembling a gnat or some aspect of one; tiny , insignificant .

gnatling.explanation: A little gnat: used contemptuously of a person.

gnatoo.explanation: A paper-cloth ( kapa or tapa ) made from the bark of the paper-mulberry ( Broussonetia papyrifera ), and printed with a pattern.

gnatworm.explanation: The aquatic larva of a gnat; -- called also, colloquially, wiggler .
The aquatic larva of a gnat .

gnaw.explanation: To bite, chew on, or erode with the teeth.
To erode or diminish gradually as if by gnawing.
To cause erosion or gradual diminishment.
To cause persistent worry or pain.
To use the teeth in biting; to bite with repeated effort, as in eating or removing with the teeth something hard, unwieldy, or unmanageable.

To bite, as something hard or tough, which is not readily separated or crushed; to bite off little by little, with effort; to wear or eat away by scraping or continuous biting with the teeth; to nibble at.
To bite in agony or rage.
To corrode; to fret away; to waste.
To trouble in a constant manner; to plague; to worry; to vex; -- usually used with at.
To produce excessive anxiety or worry.
bite or chew on with the teeth

gnawed.explanation: botany , irregularly toothed, as if from gnawing; erose.
Simple past tense and past participle of gnaw .

gnawer.explanation: One who or that which gnaws or corrodes.
plural The Rodentia, Rosores , or Glires .
One who, or that which, gnaws.
A rodent or other similar type of animal that gnaws .
relatively small placental mammals having a single pair of constantly growing incisor teeth specialized for gnawing

gnawing.explanation: The act of continued biting, consuming, or fretting.

gnaws.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gnaw .

gneiss.explanation: A banded or foliated metamorphic rock, usually of the same composition as granite.

A rock which consists essentially of the same mineral elements as granite, namely orthoclase, quartz, and mica, but in which there is a more or less distinctly foliated arrangement of the constituent minerals, and especially of the mica.

A crystalline rock, consisting, like granite, of quartz, feldspar, and mica, but having these materials, especially the mica, arranged in planes, so that it breaks rather easily into coarse slabs or flags. Hornblende sometimes takes the place of the mica, and it is then called hornblendic gneiss or syenitic gneiss . Similar varieties of related rocks are also called gneiss.
A common and widely-distributed metamorphic rock having bands or veins , but not schistose .
a laminated metamorphic rock similar to granite

gneissic.explanation: Relating to, or resembling, gneiss; consisting of gneiss.

gneissoid.explanation: gneissoid when they have the gneissic structure only imperfectly developed.
Resembling gneiss; having some of the characteristics of gneiss; -- applied to rocks of an intermediate character between granite and gneiss, or mica slate and gneiss.
Having a structure similar to that of gneiss , or intermediate between that of gneiss and mica or granite
A metamorphic rock having the composition of a laminated granite

gnetaceae.explanation: plants having small unisexual flowers and fleshy or winged fruit: in some classifications includes the genera Ephedra and Welwitschia as well as genus Gnetum

gnetales.explanation: chiefly tropical or xerophytic woody plants; practically unknown as fossils but considered close to the ancestral line of angiosperms

gnetum.explanation: A genus of climbing shrubs, type of the order Gnetaceæ , including 15 species, natives of tropical regions.
small tropical tree with tiered branches and divaricate branchlets having broad glossy dark green leaves; exploited for its edible young leaves and seeds that provide a fine flour

gnide.explanation: To rub; to bruise; to break in pieces.
To rub (usually with or between the hands); bruise ; crush ; pound ; break in pieces; rub out.

gnocchi.explanation: Dumplings made of flour, semolina, or potatoes, boiled or baked and served with grated cheese or a sauce.
Italian pasta -like dumplings made of potato or semolina .
(Italian) a small dumpling made of potato or flour or semolina that is boiled or baked and is usually served with a sauce or with grated cheese

gnoff.explanation: A churl ; a curmudgeon ; boor ; lout .

gnome.explanation: One of a fabled race of dwarflike creatures who live underground and guard treasure hoards.
In the occult philosophy of Paracelsus, a being that has earth as its element.
A pithy saying that expresses a general truth or fundamental principle; an aphorism.
A brief reflection or maxim; an aphorism; a saying; a saw.
Synonyms See aphorism .
One of a race of imaginary beings, first conceived as spirits of the earth, inhabiting its interior and that of everything earthly, animal, vegetable, or mineral.
Hence A grotesque dwarf; a goblin-like person of small stature and misshapen figure.
A name of sundry humming-birds: as, the giant gnome ( Patagona gigas ).
An imaginary being, supposed by the Rosicrucians to inhabit the inner parts of the earth, and to be the guardian of mines, quarries, etc.
A dwarf; a goblin; a person of small stature or misshapen features, or of strange appearance.
A small owl ( Glaucidium gnoma ) of the Western United States.
A brief reflection or maxim.
A brief reflection or maxim; a pithy saying.
A legendary being, supposed to be short, usually bearded men who inhabit the inner parts of the earth, and act as guardians of mines, treasure, etc.
The elemental being of earth.
A dwarf; a goblin; a person of small stature or misshapen features, or of strange appearance.
A small owl ( Glaucidium gnoma) of the Western United States.
A small statue placed in a garden to ward off pests and protect a home from sorcery.
An upper atmospheric optical phenomenon associated with thunderstorms, a compact blue starter .
a short pithy saying expressing a general truth
a legendary creature resembling a tiny old man; lives in the depths of the earth and guards buried treasure

gnomic.explanation: grammar , used in maxims or general statements; applied to express a universal truth: as, a gnomic aorist.
Sententious; uttering or containing maxims, or striking detached thoughts; aphoristic.
Greek poets, as Theognis and Solon, of the sixth century B. C., whose writings consist of short sententious precepts and reflections.
Mysterious and often incomprehensible yet seemingly wise .

gnomically.explanation: In a gnomic, didactic, or sententious manner.

gnomist.explanation: A gnomic poet; a writer of proverbs and apothegms.

gnomologic.explanation: Pertaining to, of the nature of, or resembling, a gnomology.

gnomological.explanation: Relating to, of the nature of, or resembling, a gnomology .

gnomology.explanation: A collection of or treatise on maxims or sententious and pithy reflections.
A collection of, or a treatise on, maxims, grave sentences, or reflections.
A collection of, or a treatise on, maxims , grave sentences, or reflections .

gnomon.explanation: An object, such as the style of a sundial, that projects a shadow used as an indicator.
The geometric figure that remains after a parallelogram has been removed from a similar but larger parallelogram with which it shares a corner.

On a sun-dial, the triangular projecting piece which by its shadow shows the hour of the day; also, any index to a sun-dial or to a meridian-mark, especially a very large one. The early gnomons used for astronomical purposes were vertical pillars or obelisks.
The index of the hour-circle of a globe.
A piece of a parallelogram left after a similar parallelogram has been removed from a corner of it. Thus, in the figure, EFGBCD is a gnomon.
An odd number; one of the terms of an arithmetical series by which polygonal numbers are found. Also called gnomonic number .
The style or pin, which by its shadow, shows the hour of the day. It is usually set parallel to the earth's axis.
A style or column erected perpendicularly to the horizon, formerly used in astronomocal observations. Its principal use was to find the altitude of the sun by measuring the length of its shadow.
The space included between the boundary lines of two similar parallelograms, the one within the other, with an angle in common. The parallelogram bf is the complement of the parallelogram df.
The index of the hour circle of a globe.
A plane figure formed by removing a parallelogram from a corner of a larger parallelogram.
indicator provided by the stationary arm whose shadow indicates the time on the sundial

gnomonia.explanation: A genus of pyrenomycetous fungi, type of the family Gnomoniaceæ , having the perithecia embedded in the tissue of the host, with only the elongated necks projecting.

gnomonic.explanation: botany , bent at right angles. Also gnomic, gnomical.
Of or pertaining to the gnomon, or the art of dialing.
a projection of the circles of the sphere, in which the point of sight is taken at the center of the sphere, and the principal plane is tangent to the surface of the sphere.
Showing all great circles as straight lines , and thus preserving the shortest distances between any two locations.

gnomonics.explanation: The art or science of dialing, or of constructing instruments to show the hour of the day or to aid in making astronomical observations by the shadow of a gnomon.
The art or science of dialing, or of constructing dials to show the hour of the day by the shadow of a gnomon.
The art of designing and constructing sundials

gnosis.explanation: Intuitive apprehension of spiritual truths, an esoteric form of knowledge sought by the Gnostics.
Science; knowledge; knowledge of the highest kind; specifically, mystical knowledge. See Gnostic .
The deeper wisdom; knowledge of spiritual truth, such as was claimed by the Gnostics.
An immanent form of knowledge or transcendent insight , such as sought by the Gnostics .
An altered state of awareness in which the will is magically effective.
intuitive knowledge of spiritual truths; said to have been possessed by ancient Gnostics

gnotobiology.explanation: The study of animals in a germ - free environment

gnotobiotically.explanation: In terms of, or by means of, gnotobiotics .

gnotobiotics.explanation: The study of organisms or environmental conditions that have been rendered free of bacteria or contaminants or into which a known microorganism or contaminant has been introduced for research purposes.
The science involved with maintaining a microbiologically controlled environment .

gnow.explanation: A Middle English preterit of gnaw .

gnu.explanation: Either of two large African antelopes (Connochaetes gnou or C. taurinus) having a drooping mane and beard, a long tufted tail, and curved horns in both sexes.
An African animal of the genus Catoblepas (or Connochætes ), belonging to the antilopine division of the family Bovidæ; a wildebeest.
One of two species of large South African antelopes of the genus Catoblephas, having a mane and bushy tail, and curved horns in both sexes.
A large antelope native to Africa having curved horns .
large African antelope having a head with horns like an ox and a long tufted tail

go.explanation: To move away from a place; depart.
To resort to another, as for aid.
To extend between two points or in a certain direction; run.
To pass from one person to another; circulate.
To pass as the result of a sale.
Used as an intensifier or to indicate annoyance when joined by and to a coordinate verb.
Used in the progressive tense with an infinitive to indicate future intent or expectation.
To continue to be in a certain condition or continue an activity.
To come to be in a certain condition.
To continue to be in effect or operation.
To carry out an action to a certain point or extent.
To be capable of entering or fitting.
To be such, by and large.
To be used up or finished.
To be suitable or appropriate as an accessory or accompaniment.
To be valid, acceptable, or adequate.

goa.explanation: A brownish-gray gazelle (Procapra picticaudata) native to the Tibetan Plateau, having a short tail with a black tip and backward-curving horns in the male.
A name of a Tibetan antelope, Procapra picticauda. Gray. Also called ragoa .
A species of antelope ( Procapra picticauda ), inhabiting Thibet.
The Tibetan gazelle , Procapra picticaudata, a species of antelope that inhabits the Tibetan Plateau.
a state of southwestern India; a former Portuguese colony

goad.explanation: A long stick with a pointed end used for prodding animals.
An agent or means of prodding or urging; a stimulus.
To prod or urge with or as if with a long pointed stick.
A stick, rod, or staff with a pointed end, used for driving cattle; hence, anything that urges or stimulates.
A decoy at an auction; a Peter Funk.
[Cf. yard, rod, perch , as measures of length.] A little-used English Measure of length.
To impel, spur, arouse, stir up, set on.
A sort of false die.
A plaything.
A pointed instrument used to urge on a beast; hence, any necessity that urges or stimulates.
To prick; to drive with a goad; hence, to urge forward, or to rouse by anything pungent, severe, irritating, or inflaming; to stimulate.
A long, pointed stick used to prod animals.
To prod with a goad.
To encourage or stimulate .
To incite or provoke .
stab or urge on as if with a pointed stick
urge with or as if with a goad
a verbalization that encourages you to attempt something
goad or provoke,as by constant criticism
a pointed instrument that is used to prod into a state of motion
give heart or courage to

goaded.explanation: compelled forcibly by an outside agency.
Simple past tense and past participle of goad .
compelled forcibly by an outside agency

goading.explanation: a verbalization that encourages you to attempt something

goadlike.explanation: Resembling a goad or some aspect of one.

goads.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of goad .

goadsman.explanation: One who drives oxen with a goad; an ox-driver.

goadster.explanation: One who drives with a goad; a goadsman.

goaf.explanation: A stack or cock, as of grain.
A rick of corn in the straw laid up in a barn.
3. In coal-mining , a space from which coal has been worked away, and which is more or less filled up with refuse.
That part of a mine from which the mineral has been partially or wholly removed; the waste left in old workings; -- called also gob .
to remove the pillars of mineral matter previously left to support the roof, and replace them with props.
That part of a mine from which the mineral has been partially or wholly removed; the waste left in old workings .

goal.explanation: The object toward which an endeavor is directed; an end. synonym : intention .
A structure or area into which players endeavor to propel a ball or puck in order to score points.
A play or shot that sends a ball or puck into or through the goal.
The score awarded for such an act.
The finish line of a race.
A noun or noun phrase referring to the place to which something moves.
gaol (now commonly jail ), often found in books of the seventeenth century.
In astronomy , the point on the celestial sphere toward which the motion of a body is directed; thus, the earth's goal at any moment is a point on the ecliptic about 90 degrees west of the sun.

A pole, post, or other object set up to mark the point determined for the end of a race, or for both its beginning and end, whether in one course or several courses; a mark or point to be reached in a race or other contest; the limit of a race.
In athletic games and plays, the mark, point, or line toward which effort is directed.
Hence—3. In foot-ball , etc., the act of throwing or kicking the ball through or over the goal: as, to make a goal.
4. The end or termination; the finish.
The end or final purpose; the end to which a design or a course of action tends, or which a person aims to reach or accomplish.
A barrow or tumulus.
The mark set to bound a race, and to or around which the constestants run, or from which they start to return to it again; the place at which a race or a journey is to end.
The final purpose or aim; the end to which a design tends, or which a person aims to reach or attain.

A base, station, or bound used in various games as the point or object which a team must reach in order to score points; in certain games, the point which the ball or puck must pass in order for points to be scored. In football, it is a line between two posts across which the ball must pass in order to score points; in soccer or ice hockey, it is a net at each end of the soccer field into which the soccer ball or hocjey puck must be propelled; in basketball, it is the basket{7} suspended from the backboard, through which the basketball must pass.
The act or instance of propelling the ball or puck into or through the goal{3}, thus scoring points.
the player charged with the defense of the goal, such as in soccer or ice hockey.
A result that one is attempting to achieve .
In many sports , an area into which the players attempt to put an object.
The act of placing the object into the goal.
A point scored in a game as a result of placing the object into the goal.
A noun or noun phrase that receives the action of a verb. The subject of a passive verb or the direct object of an active verb. Also called a patient, target, or undergoer.
a successful attempt at scoring
the place designated as the end (as of a race or journey)
the state of affairs that a plan is intended to achieve and that (when achieved) terminates behavior intended to achieve it
game equipment consisting of the place toward which players of a game try to advance a ball or puck in order to score points

goaler.explanation: Relating to a specified number or type of goal.

goalie.explanation: the defensive position on an ice hockey or soccer or lacrosse team who stands in front of the goal and tries to prevent opposing players from scoring
the soccer or hockey player assigned to protect the goal

goalkeeper.explanation: A player assigned to protect the goal in various sports.
a designated player that attempts to prevent the opposing team from scoring by protecting a goal .
the defensive position on an ice hockey or soccer or lacrosse team who stands in front of the goal and tries to prevent opposing players from scoring
the soccer or hockey player assigned to protect the goal

goalless.explanation: having no points scored; -- of games.
In which no goals have been scored .

goalmouth.explanation: The area directly in front of the goal, as in soccer or hockey.
The area immediately in front of the goal.
The area in front of the goal .
(sports) the area immediately in front of the goal

goalpost.explanation: One of a pair of posts usually joined with a crossbar to form a goal, as in soccer or ice hockey.
A post or a pair of posts supporting a crossbar and either supporting or extending into the uprights of a goal, as in football.
One of the upright posts forming one side of the goal. See goal , 2.

One of two posts supporting a crossbar which forms a goal{3}, especially in American football; also, in football the entire structure consisting of the posts, crossbar, and two uprights. To score a goal by kicking the football, the ball must pass above the crossbar and between the vertical lines formed by the uprights.

In American football, the tall Y-shaped upright, now usually of fiberglass, at either end of the playing field, through which a football must go in order to score a field goal. Originally, they were H-shaped, with two wooden posts on either side.
One of the two side poles of the goal .
one of a pair of posts (usually joined by a crossbar) that are set up as a goal at each end of a playing field

goaltending.explanation: The act of protecting a goal, as in hockey and other such sports.
An illegal play in which a player touches the ball when it is on a downward path to the basket or when it is on, above, or within the area over the opening of the rim of the basket.
A violation which occurs when a player interferes with the movement of the ball toward the basket

goan.explanation: Eye dialect spelling of going to .

goanna.explanation: Any of various monitor lizards of Australia.
A popular variant of guana (an abbreviated form of iguana ) in common use in Australia for any large lizard; specifically, the lace-lizard, Varanus varius. Also gohanna .
Any of various monitor lizards native to Australia .

goat.explanation: A domesticated ruminant mammal (Capra hircus) having backward curving horns and a beard in the male, raised for its wool, milk, and meat.
Any of various wild ruminant mammals of the genus Capra and related genera, including the ibexes and the wild goat (C. aegagrus) of Eurasia.
A lecherous man.
A person who is blamed for a failure or misfortune, especially a scapegoat.
Another spelling of gote .
A horned ruminant quadruped of the genus Capra ( Or Hircus ).
plural In zoology , the Caprinœ as a subfamily of Bovidœ or Antilopidœ. There are several genera and species. See Ægocerus , Capra, Hemitragus, Kemas.
Same as goatskin , 2.
A stepping-stone.
A hollow-horned ruminant of the genus Capra, of several species and varieties, esp. the domestic goat ( Capra hircus ), which is raised for its milk, flesh, and skin.
one of several species of antelopes, which in some respects resemble a goat, having recurved horns, a stout body, large hoofs, and a short, flat tail, as the goral, thar, mazame, and chikara.
the wild fig.
A brothel.

any moth of the genus Cossus, esp. the large European species ( Cossus ligniperda ), the larva of which burrows in oak and willow trees, and requires three years to mature. It exhales an odor like that of the he-goat.
a scrophulariaceous plant, of the genus Capraria ( Capraria biflora ).
a poisonous plant ( Aconitum Lucoctonum ), bearing pale yellow flowers, introduced from Switzerland into England; wolfsbane.
a kind of wood sorrel ( Oxalis caprina ) growing at the Cape of Good Hope.
a leguminous plant ( Galega officinalis of Europe, or Tephrosia Virginiana in the United States).
a thorny leguminous plant ( Astragalus Tragacanthus ), found in the Levant.
the genus Tragopyrum (now referred to Atraphaxis).
A mammal, of the genus Capra .
A lecherous man .
A scapegoat .
To allow goats to feed on.
To scapegoat.
(astrology) a person who is born while the sun is in Capricorn
the tenth sign of the zodiac; the sun is in this sign from about December 22 to January 19
any of numerous agile ruminants related to sheep but having a beard and straight horns
a victim of ridicule or pranks

goatee.explanation: A small chin beard, especially one connected to a mustache or trimmed into a point.
A tuft of beard left on the chin after the rest has been shaved off; an imperial, especially one extending under the chin.
A part of a man's beard on the chin or lower lip which is allowed to grow, and trimmed so as to resemble the beard of a goat.
A beard trimmed to grow only at the center of the chin .
a small chin beard trimmed to a point; named for its resemblance to a goat's beard

goateed.explanation: having a small pointed chin beard.
having a small pointed chin beard

goatfish.explanation: Any of various fishes of the family Mullidae of warm seas, having two sensory barbels on the chin and usually a brightly colored body.
A West Indian and South American mulloid fish, Upeneus maculatus , of a red color with bluish longitudinal lines on the sides of the head and three black blotches on the body above the lateral line.
A fish of the genus Upeneus, inhabiting the Gulf of Mexico. It is allied to the surmullet.
Any of many brightly coloured fishes , of the family Mullidae, having two barbels on the chin.
brightly colored tropical fishes with chin barbels

goatherd.explanation: One whose occupation is the care of goats.
a person who tends a flock of goats

goatishness.explanation: The quality of being goatish; lustfulness; salaciousness.
The state or condition of being goatish .

goatland.explanation: The land of goats; a mountainous region.

The incidence of goiter has been substantially reduced by addition of iodine to ceratin foods, such as salt.

Atomic number 79; atomic weight 196.967; melting point 1,064.2°C; boiling point 2,856.0°C; specific gravity 19.3; valence 1, 3. cross-reference : Periodic Table .

[English dial. also goolds (ef. Sc. gool, gule, gules , the corn-marigold), ⟨ ME. gold, goold, guld , merely a particular use of gold , the metal. Cf. marigold .] The marigold, Calendula officinalis.
Tho corn-marigold, Chrysanthemum segetum .
The turnsol; heliotrope.
A sulphid of tin, the aurum musivum of the ancients.
gold chain; gold color.
An old English name of some yellow flower, -- the marigold (Calendula), according to Dr. Prior, but in Chaucer perhaps the turnsole.

A metallic element of atomic number 79, constituting the most precious metal used as a common commercial medium of exchange. It has a characteristic yellow color, is one of the heaviest substances known (specific gravity 19.32), is soft, and very malleable and ductile. It is quite unalterable by heat (melting point 1064.4° C), moisture, and most corrosive agents, and therefore well suited for its use in coin and jewelry. Symbol Au ( Aurum ). Atomic weight 196.97.
Money; riches; wealth.
A yellow color, like that of the metal.
Figuratively, something precious or pure.
See Golden age, under Golden .
etc. See under Dutch , Dust , etc.
a mineral, found in Columbia and California, composed of gold and mercury.
one whose occupation is to beat gold into gold leaf.
the prepared outside membrane of the large intestine of the ox, used for separating the leaves of metal during the process of gold-beating.
any small gold-colored beetle of the family Chrysomelidæ ; -- called also golden beetle .
printing with gold leaf, as upon a book cover, by means of an engraved block.

a part of the coast of Guinea, in West Africa.

the places, or region, where gold is found by digging in sand and gravel from which it is separated by washing.
a fragment of broken gold or jewelry.
An itinerant jeweler.
a popular mania for gold hunting.
a region in which are deposits of gold.
One who empties privies.
a composite plant with dry and persistent yellow radiating involucral scales, the Helichrysum Stœchas of Southern Europe. There are many South African species of the same genus.
thin sheets of gold, as used by dentists and others. See Gold leaf .
buttercups.
a kind of lace, made of gold thread.
a thin plate of gold or gilded metal.
gold beaten into a film of extreme thinness, and used for gilding, etc. It is much thinner than gold foil.

an artisan who beats gold into gold leaf
an artisan who beats gold into gold leaf

goldbeating.explanation: The act, process, or art of beating sheets of gold into gold leaf.

goldbrick.explanation: A person, especially a soldier, who avoids assigned duties or work; a shirker.
To shirk one's assigned duties or responsibilities.

a soldier who performs his duties without proper care or effort
anything that is supposed to be valuable but turns out to be worthless
a brick-shaped block that looks like gold but is not

goldcrest.explanation: A golden-crested bird of the genus Regulus.

A very small passerine bird , Regulus regulus, that breeds in Eurasia .
European kinglet with a black-bordered yellow crown patch

goldcup.explanation: One of various species of crowfoot or Ranunculus , especially R. acris and R. bulbosus. Also called buttercup, kingcup.
any of various plants of the genus Ranunculus

golden.explanation: Of, relating to, made of, or containing gold.
Having the color of gold or a yellow color suggestive of gold.
Lustrous; radiant.
Suggestive of gold, as in richness or splendor.
Of the greatest value or importance; precious.
Marked by peace, prosperity, and often creativeness.
Very favorable or advantageous; excellent.
Having a promising future; seemingly assured of success.
Of or relating to a 50th anniversary.
golden sun; golden fruit: sometimes poetically used of blood.
golden rule.
golden age.
golden opportunity.
arithmetic , the rule of three. See rule .
Made of gold; consisting of gold.
Having the color of gold.
Very precious; highly valuable; excellent; eminently auspicious.

That period in the history of a literature, etc., when it flourishes in its greatest purity or attains its greatest glory; as, the Elizabethan age has been considered the golden age of English literature.
three gilt balls used as a sign of a pawnbroker's office or shop; -- originally taken from the coat of arms of Lombardy, the first money lenders in London having been Lombards.

the shrub Cytisus Laburnum , so named from its long clusters of yellow blossoms.
an aquatic plant ( Orontium aquaticum ), bearing a thick spike of minute yellow flowers.
the buttercup.

a large and powerful eagle ( Aquila Chrysaëtos ) inhabiting Europe, Asia, and North America. It is so called from the brownish yellow tips of the feathers on the head and neck. A dark variety is called the royal eagle ; the young in the second year is the ring-tailed eagle .
An order of knighthood instituted in 1429 by Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy; -- called also Toison d'Or .
a bribe; a fee.
a South African shrubby composite plant with golden yellow flowers, the Chrysocoma Coma-aurea .
a tribe of Mongolian Tartars who overran and settled in Southern Russia early in the 18th century.

a hagiology (the “ Aurea Legenda ”) written by James de Voragine, Archbishop of Genoa, in the 13th century, translated and printed by Caxton in 1483, and partially paraphrased by Longfellow in a poem thus entitled.
tin.
the way of wisdom and safety between extremes; sufficiency without excess; moderation.
one of several South African Insectivora of the family Chrysochloridæ , resembling moles in form and habits. The fur is tinted with green, purple, and gold.
a number showing the year of the lunar or Metonic cycle. It is reckoned from 1 to 19, and is so called from having formerly been written in the calendar in gold.
See Oriole .
See under Pheasant .
a kind of apple, of a bright yellow color.

one of several species of plovers, of the genus Charadrius, esp. the European ( Charadrius apricarius , syn. Charadrius pluvialis ; -- called also yellow plover , black-breasted plover , hill plover , and whistling plover . The common American species ( Charadrius dominicus ) is also called frostbird , and bullhead .
See Baltimore oriole , in Vocab.
a gold or gilded rose blessed by the pope on the fourth Sunday in Lent, and sent to some church or person in recognition of special services rendered to the Holy See.
The rule of proportion, or rule of three.
a composite plant ( Inula crithmoides ), found on the seashore of Europe.
a low herb with yellow flowers ( Chrysosplenium oppositifolium ), blossoming in wet places in early spring.
a perennial ranunculaceous herb ( Hydrastis Canadensis ), with a thick knotted rootstock and large rounded leaves.
the pentasulphide of antimony, a golden or orange yellow powder.
a common American wood warbler ( Dendroica æstiva ); -- called also blue-eyed yellow warbler , garden warbler , and summer yellow bird .
a bright-colored hymenopterous insect, of the family Chrysididæ . The colors are golden, blue, and green.

goldenback.explanation: The American golden plover, Charadrius dominicus.

goldeneye.explanation: Either of two diving ducks (Bucephala clangula or B. islandica) of northern regions, having a short black bill, a rounded head, and yellow eyes.
Any of various lacewings of the family Chrysopidae having yellow or copper-colored eyes.
Any of several seaducks , of the genus Bucephala , having black and white plumage .
Any of several lacewings of the family Chrysopidae.

goldenpert.explanation: The Gratiola aurea , a low scrophulariaceous herb of the Atlantic States, with golden-yellow flowers.

goldenrod.explanation: Any of numerous chiefly North American plants of the genus Solidago of the composite family, having clusters of small usually yellow flower heads that bloom in late summer or fall.
A plant of the genus Solidago , the species of which have numerous small golden heads: these in the original species, S. Virgaurea of Europe, are arranged in a wand-like spike. See Solidago .
A tall herb ( Solidago Virga-aurea ), bearing small yellow flowers in a graceful elongated cluster. The name is common to all the species of the genus Solidago.
a shrub ( Bosea Yervamora ), a native of the Canary Isles.
A tall-stemmed, plant with clusters of small yellow flowers.
A golden-yellow colour, like that of the goldenrod plant.
Of a golden-yellow colour, like that of the goldenrod plant.
any of numerous chiefly summer-blooming and fall-blooming North American plants especially of the genus Solidago

goldenseal.explanation: A North American woodland plant (Hydrastis canadensis) in the buttercup family, having small greenish-white flowers and a yellow root used in herbal medicine.

The false or wild spikenard, Vagnera racemosa.
A perennial herb of Northeastern U. S. ( Hydrastis Canadensis ) having a thick knotted yellow rootstock and large rounded leaves.

Hydrastis canadensis, a perennial herb of the buttercup family, native to southeastern Canada and the northeastern United States, with a thick, yellow knotted rootstock and diverse medicinal properties.
perennial herb of northeastern United States having a thick knotted yellow rootstock and large rounded leaves
perennial herb of northeastern United States having a thick knotted yellow rootstock and large rounded leaves

goldentop.explanation: An ornamental grass, Achyrodes aureum , which grows in low tufts and bears elegant one-sided panicles. It has been introduced from the Mediterranean region into southern California, where it has become spontaneous.

goldenwing.explanation: A shortened form of golden-winged woodpecker ; the flicker.

goldeye.explanation: A North American freshwater fish of the mooneye family, Hiodon alosoides, usually eaten smoked.

goldfield.explanation: An area containing abundant deposits of gold or gold ore.
A district or region where gold-mining is carried on.

plural In California, a plant of the composite genus Bæria and to some extent of the related genus Lasthenia : so named from the fact that these plants cover the ground with their yellow bloom. The species are low herbs, some of which endure saline or alkaline soil.
a district where gold is mined.
An area where gold ore is found
a district where gold is mined

small slender woolly annual with very narrow opposite leaves and branches bearing solitary golden-yellow flower heads; southwestern Oregon to Baja California and Arizona; often cultivated

In angling , the name of an artificial salmon-fly.
An elegant European siskin or thistle-bird, Carduelis elegans , of the family Fringillidæ , having wings conspicuously marked with yellow, and a crimson face.
The American thistle-bird, Chrysomitris tristis , of the family Fringillidæ , having a yellow body, with black cap, wings, and tail, the latter marked also with white.
Some finch like or likened to either of the above, as the Arkansan goldfinch, Chry-somitris psaltria.
The yellow bunting, Emberiza citrinella : a misnomer.

A beautiful bright-colored European finch ( Carduelis elegans ). The name refers to the large patch of yellow on the wings. The front of the head and throat are bright red; the nape, with part of the wings and tail, black; -- called also goldspink , goldie , fool's coat , drawbird , draw-water , thistle finch , and sweet William .
A small American finch ( Spinus tristis ); the thistle bird.

A small passerine bird of the finch family; the European goldfinch, Carduelis carduelis, the American goldfinch, Carduelis tristis, Lawrence's Goldfinch, Carduelis lawrencei, or the lesser goldfinch, Carduelis psaltria.
American finch whose male has yellow body plumage in summer
small European finch having a crimson face and yellow-and-black wings

goldfinny.explanation: A variety of the Conner, Crenilabrus melops. [Eng.] Also goldsinny .
The Crenilabrus rupestris , a fish specifically named Jago's goldfinny.
One of two or more species of European labroid fishes ( Crenilabrus melops , and Ctenolabrus rupestris ); -- called also goldsinny , and goldney .
One of two or more species of European labroid fishes (Crenilabrus melops and Ctenolabrus rupestris).

goldfish.explanation: A freshwater cyprinid fish (Carassius auratus) native to eastern Asia, usually having brassy or reddish coloring and bred in many ornamental forms as an aquarium fish.
A fish of the carp family Cyprinidæ, Cyprinus or Carassius auratus , originally a Chinese species, now domesticated and bred everywhere for ornament in ponds, tanks, and aquariums.

A small domesticated cyprinoid fish ( Carassius auratus ); -- so named from its color. It is a native of China, and is said to have been introduced into Europe in 1691. It is often kept as an ornament, in small ponds or glass globes. Many varieties are known. Called also golden fish , and golden carp . See Telescope fish, under telescope .
A California marine fish of an orange or red color; the garibaldi.
A type of fish (scientific name Carassius auratus ), typically orange -colored.
small golden or orange-red freshwater fishes of Eurasia used as pond or aquarium fishes

goldilocks.explanation: A person, usually a woman or girl, with golden or blond hair.

The Linosyris vulgaris , a native of Europe, resembling goldenrod, with small heads of yellow flowers.
A person with golden hair, especially a girl with long hair.
early-flowering perennial of southern and southeastern Europe with flower heads resembling those of goldenrod

goldin.explanation: A conspicuous yellow flower, commonly the corn marigold ( Chrysanthemum segetum ).

golding.explanation: A kind of red hop, a sub-variety of the Canterbury hop.
A kind of apple ; a goldling.

goldlike.explanation: Resembling or characteristic of the metal gold .

goldney.explanation: The goldenmaid, golden wrasse, gilthead, or conner, Crenilabrus melops or C. tinca.

golds.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gold .

goldsmith.explanation: An artisan who fashions objects of gold.
A trader or dealer in gold articles.
An artisan who manufactures vessels and ornaments of gold; a worker in gold.
An artisan who manufactures vessels and ornaments, etc., of gold.
a large, bright yellow, American beetle ( Cotalpa lanigera ), of the family Scarabæidæ
A person who forges things out of gold , especially jewelry.

an artisan who makes jewelry and other objects out of gold
Irish writer of novels and poetry and plays and essays (1728-1774)

aventurine spangled densely with fine gold-colored particles
