Used to describe various creatures with a gold -coloured tail .

goldthread.explanation: Any of several plants of the genus Coptis of the buttercup family, having small white flowers, ternately divided evergreen leaves, and slender yellow rhizomes used in herbal medicine.
A ranunculaceous evergreen plant, Coptis trifolia , growing in the United States and Europe: so called from its fibrous yellow roots. See Coptis .
low-growing perennial of North America woodlands having trifoliate leaves and yellow rootstock and white flowers

goldwork.explanation: Work done using gold metal, as in embroidery .

goldworker.explanation: an artisan who makes jewelry and other objects out of gold

goldylocks.explanation: A plant of several species of the genus Chrysocoma; -- so called from the tufts of yellow flowers which terminate the stems; also, the Ranunculus auricomus , a kind of buttercup.

golem.explanation: In Jewish folklore, an artificially created human supernaturally endowed with life.
In Jewish use, a shapeless mass; an unfinished vessel or a lifeless bulk; in modern Jewish parlance, a blockhead; a stupid.
A Creature made of mud and clay. Brought to life from a magical spell on a piece of paper shoved in its mouth.
a mechanism that can move automatically
(Jewish folklore) an artificially created human being that is given life by supernatural means

golet.explanation: A Middle English form of gullet .
A Californian trout: same as Dolly Varden , 2.

golf.explanation: A game played on a large outdoor course with a series of 9 or 18 holes spaced far apart, the object being to propel a small, hard ball with the use of various clubs into each hole with as few strokes as possible.
A game played over an extensive stretch of ground in which holes about 4 inches in diameter are placed at distances from 100 to 500 yards apart.

A game played with a small ball and a bat or club crooked at the lower end. He who drives the ball into each of a series of small holes in the ground and brings it into the last hole with the fewest strokes is the winner.
A ball game played by individuals competing against one another in which the object is to hit a ball into each of a series of (usually 18 or nine) holes in the minimum number of strokes .
The letter G in the ICAO spelling alphabet .
a game played on a large open course with 9 or 18 holes; the object is use as few strokes as possible in playing all the holes

golfed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of golf .

golfer.explanation: someone who plays the game of golf

golfs.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of golf .

golgotha.explanation: A place or occasion of great suffering.
The Hebrew (Aramaic) name of the place of Christ's crucifixion, somewhere near Jerusalem.
A graveyard or place of interment.
Calvary. See the Note under Calvary .
a hill near Jerusalem where Jesus was crucified

goliard.explanation: A wandering student in medieval Europe disposed to conviviality, license, and the making of ribald and satirical Latin songs.
A buffoon or jester; specifically, one of an order or class of inferior monks who attended on the tables of the richer ecclesiastics as professional jesters or buffoons.
One of the writers of the satirical poems collectively known as goliardery.
A buffoon in the Middle Ages, who attended rich men's tables to make sport for the guests by ribald stories and songs.
a wandering scholar in medieval Europe; famed for intemperance and riotous behavior and the composition of satirical and ribald Latin songs

goliardery.explanation: A series of Latin poems written in the thirteenth century, satirizing the abuses of the church.
The satirical or ribald poetry of the Goliards.
The satirical or ribald poetry of the Goliards .

goliardic.explanation: Relating to Goliards , wandering medieval students.
Describing a form of medieval lyric poetry that typically celebrated licentiousness and drinking .

this sense?) (Rhyming slang as "the" golliwogs): greyhound racing

golliwogg.explanation: Alternative spelling of golliwog . (The original spelling in 1895 had the double g.)

golly.explanation: Used to express mild surprise or wonder.

golosh.explanation: a waterproof overshoe that protects shoes from water or snow

golp.explanation: In heraldry , a roundel of a purple color.

goma.explanation: a city in eastern Congo at the northern end of Lake Kivu near the border with Rwanda

gomarist.explanation: A follower of Francis Gomarus (1563-1641), a Dutch disciple of Calvin.
One of the followers of Francis Gomar or Gomarus , a Dutch disciple of Calvin in the 17th century, who strongly opposed the Arminians.

gomashta.explanation: In India, a native factor or agent.

gombay.explanation: A festal performance among the negroes of Bermuda, usually held on Christmas eve: probably a survival, much modified, of an ancient African rite.

gombeenism.explanation: The practice of resorting to or depending on money-lenders.

gome.explanation: The black grease on the axle of a cart or wagon wheel; -- called also gorm . See gorm .

gomer.explanation: A patient considered irksome by a health care provider, especially a patient with chronic complaints that are trivial or unresponsive to repeated treatment.
A particular form of chamber in ordnance, consisting in a conical narrowing of the bore toward its inner end. It was devised for the service of mortars in the wars of the first Napoleon.
A conical chamber at the breech of the bore in heavy ordnance, especially in mortars; -- named after the inventor.
A Hebrew measure of dry weight .
A conical chamber at the breech of the bore in heavy ordnance , especially in mortars .

gomerel.explanation: A stupid or senseless person; a blockhead.

gomlah.explanation: In India, a water-jug or ewer, usually of earthenware. Also gamla .

A disease of the teeth, which causes them to loosen and fall out of their sockets.
A disease of the teeth that causes them to loosen and fall out of their sockets .

gomphocarpus.explanation: A genus of asclepiadaceous herbs, distinguished from Asclepias merely by the absence of a horn or crest on the hood.

gomphodont.explanation: zoology , having the teeth inserted by gomphosis; socketed, as teeth.

gomphosis.explanation: A type of immovable articulation, as of a tooth inserted into its bony socket.
A kind of synarthrosis or immovable articulation in which one part enters into another like a peg or nail.
A form of union or immovable articulation where a hard part is received into the cavity of a bone, as the teeth into the jaws.
a type of fibrous , immovable joint such as the one between the teeth and the alveolar bone

gomphrena.explanation: A genus of herbs or undershrubs, of the order Amarantaceæ , including about 80 species, especially abundant in the warmer parts of America, but found also in southern Asia and Australia.
Any plant of the genus Gomphrena, the globe amaranths.
genus of tropical herbs or subshrubs having flowers in close heads; tropical America and Australia

gomuti.explanation: 2. The black fiber obtained from the sago-palm, remarkable for its power of resisting decay in water.

A black, fibrous substance resembling horsehair, obtained from the leafstalks of two kinds of palms, Metroxylon Sagu , and Arenga saccharifera , of the Indian islands. It is used for making cordage. Called also ejoo .
A black, fibrous substance resembling horsehair , obtained from the leafstalks of two palms , Metroxylon sagu, and Arenga saccharifera, of the Indian islands, and used for making cordage .
Malaysian feather palm with base densely clothed with fibers; yields a sweet sap used in wine and trunk pith yields sago

gon.explanation: go and of the past participle gone.
One hundredth of a right angle ; a gradian .

gonad.explanation: An organ in animals that produces gametes, especially a testis or ovary.

In biology , a germ-gland; a germinal or reproductive gland or organ, in the widest sense, producing sperm-cells or egg-cells; an ovary or a spermary, of whatever kind, in a primitive or an indifferent state.
One of the masses of generative tissue primitively alike in both sexes, but giving rise to either an ovary or a testis; a generative gland; a germ gland.
A sex organ that produces gametes ; specifically, a testicle or ovary .
a gland in which gametes (sex cells) are produced

gonadal.explanation: Of or pertaining to the gonads
of or relating to the gonads

gonadectomy.explanation: The procedure to remove an ovary or testis .

gonadotrophic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or stimulating the functions of the gonads
of or relating to or involving gonadotropin

gonadotrophin.explanation: Any of a group of protein hormones secreted by gonadotrope cells of the pituitary gland of vertebrates .
hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and placenta; stimulates the gonads and controls reproductive activity

Of, pertaining to, or similar in function to gonadotropin
of or relating to or involving gonadotropin

any of a group of protein hormones secreted by gonadotrope cells of the pituitary gland of vertebrates
hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and placenta; stimulates the gonads and controls reproductive activity

gonagra.explanation: In pathology , an affection of the knee; gout or rheumatism in the knee.

gonakie.explanation: The Acacia Arabica , which yields a hard and durable wood.
An African timber tree ( Acacia Adansonii ).
An African timber tree , Acacia adansonii.

gonangium.explanation: In zoology , an organ of some Hydrozoa.

gonapophysis.explanation: One of the paired pieces forming the external genital organs of insects.

gonarthritis.explanation: In pathology , inflammation of the knee-joint.
inflammation of the joint of the knee

gondolier.explanation: A man who rows a gondola.

a (Venetian) boatman who propels a gondola

gondoliere.explanation: a (Venetian) boatman who propels a gondola

gone.explanation: Being away from a place; absent or having departed.
No longer in existence; not part of the present.
Advanced, as in illness or deterioration.
archery , wide of the mark or beyond bounds: said of an arrow.
No longer part of the present situation.
Intoxicated to the point of being unaware of one's surroundings

goneness.explanation: A faint or sinking sensation; faintness: as, a feeling of goneness.
A state of exhaustion; faintness, especially as resulting from hunger.
A state of exhaustion or faintness , especially from hunger .

goner.explanation: One that is ruined or doomed.
One who or that which is lost, ruined, or past recovery.
Someone (or something) doomed ; a hopeless case.
a person in desperate straits; someone doomed

goners.explanation: Plural form of goner . (persons who are in a desperate strait or doomed)

gonfalon.explanation: A banner suspended from a crosspiece, especially as a standard in an ecclesiastical procession or as the ensign of a medieval Italian republic.

Originally, a banderole or small pennon attached to a lance or spear; an ensign or standard, especially one having two or three streamers or tails, fixed on a frame made to turn like a ship's vane, or suspended from a cross-yard, as in the case of the papal or ecclesiastical gonfalon. See labarum .
The ensign or standard in use by certain princes or states, such as the mediæval republics of Italy, and in more recent times by the pope.
A name popularly given to any flag which hangs from a crosspiece or frame instead of from the staff or the mast itself.
A standard or ensign , consisting of a pole with a crosspiece from which a banner is suspended, especially as used in church processions , but also for civic and military display.

gonfalonier.explanation: The bearer of a gonfalon; a chief standard-bearer.
In the middle ages, the title of the chief magistrate of Florence and other Italian republics, elected by the people.
An officer at Rome who bears the standard of the Church.
The chief magistrate of any one of several republics in mediæveal Italy.
A Turkish general, and standard keeper.
an official , particularly a chief magistrate of a mediaeval Italian republic; the bearer of the republic's gonfalon

gong.explanation: A rimmed metal disk that produces a loud, sonorous tone when struck with a padded mallet.
A usually saucer-shaped bell that is struck with a mechanically operated hammer.
To make the sound of a gong.
A musical instrument, of Asiatic origin, consisting of a large shallow metallic bowl, made of an alloy of copper and tin, which is struck with a stick having a stuffed leather head.
A stationary bell in the form of a shallow bowl, which is struck with a hammer.
An instrument, first used in the East, made of an alloy of copper and tin, shaped like a disk with upturned rim, and producing, when struck, a harsh and resounding noise.
A flat saucerlike bell, rung by striking it with a small hammer which is connected with it by various mechanical devices; a stationary bell, used to sound calls or alarms; -- called also gong bell .
an alloy (78 parts of copper, 22 of tin), from which Oriental gongs are made.
A percussion instrument consisting of a metal disk that emits a sonorous sound when struck with a soft hammer .
To make the sound of a gong; to ring a gong.
a percussion instrument consisting of a metal plate that is struck with a softheaded drumstick
a percussion instrument consisting of a set of tuned bells that are struck with a hammer; used as an orchestral instrument

gonged.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gong .

gonglike.explanation: Resembling a gong or some aspect of one.

gongorist.explanation: a practitioner of the affected elegant style of the Spanish poet Gongora

gongs.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gong .

gonia.explanation: A genus of flies, of the family Tachinidæ. They are rather large black or blackish-brown species, with the abdomen usually reddish-yellow.
A genus of tineid moths, of the family Gelechiidæ. The sole species is the German

goniac.explanation: anthropology , relating or pertaining to the gonion.

gonial.explanation: Of or pertaining to the gonia , primitive germ cells .
Of or pertaining to the gonion , the point at the apex of the mandible , or lower jaw.

goniaster.explanation: A genus of starfishes, giving name to the family Goniasteridæ. L. Agassiz.

goniatite.explanation: A fossil cophalopod of the family Goniatitidæ.
One of an extinct genus of fossil cephalopods, allied to the Ammonites. The earliest forms are found in the Devonian formation, the latest, in the Triassic.
Any member of the extinct Goniatitida, a taxonomic order of ammonites .

goniatites.explanation: A genus of fossil ammonites, giving name to the family Goniatitidæ , having a discoid shell with angu-lated lobed sutures.

Originally (as introduced by de Haan) a genus of Paleozoic ammonoid cephalopods with closely coiled shells, simple septal sutures, and mostly broad lateral saddles and lobes. The genus was later subdivided into other genera of more restricted scope, so that the name, which originally had a value parallel to that of Ammonites , has now, like the latter, disappeared from classification.

gonidangium.explanation: In mycology , a sporangium within which asexual spores (gonidia, conidia) are produced, as in Mucor .
Specifically, the asexual reproductive organ, borne upon the gametophyte, in distinction from the sporangium, whichis borne upon the sporophyte.

gonidial.explanation: gonidial grooves of a sea-anemone, serving to convey ova.
Of or pertaining to the angles of the mouth.
Of or pertaining to the angles of the mouth .

gonidium.explanation: An asexually produced cell that can generate a new colony, found in certain algae such as volvox.
In algol. , a reproductive body produced asexually, as a tetraspore or zoöspore.
In bryology , a cell filled with granules.
One of the green or chlorophyl-bearing elements of lichens, usually occurring in the thalli in a distinct layer, but sometimes not definitely arranged.
A component cell of the yellowish green layer in certain lichens.
A special groove or furrow at one or both angles of the mouth of many Anthozoa.
A photosynthetic algal cell in the thallus of a lichen ; a similar asexual reproductive cell in some algae

gonif.explanation: (Yiddish) a thief or dishonest person or scoundrel (often used as a general term of abuse)

gonimic.explanation: gonimic tissue of Collema. Also gonimous .

gonimium.explanation: In lichenology , a gonidium that is not grass-green, but usually bluish-green.
One of the bluish-green granules that replace the more usual gonidia in certain lichens .

gonimoblast.explanation: The filament which arises from the fertilized cell of some of the red algæ. It bears the carpospores either directly or upon gonimolobes (which see).

gonimolobe.explanation: The terminal lobe intowhich the gonimoblast of certain red algæ is divided.

gonimous.explanation: Pertaining to, or containing, gonidia or gonimia, as that part of a lichen which contains the green or chlorophyll-bearing cells.
Pertaining to, or containing, gonidia or gonimia , as that part of a lichen which contains the green or chlorophyll -bearing cells .

goniometer.explanation: An optical instrument for measuring crystal angles, as between crystal faces.
A radio receiver and directional antenna used as a system to determine the angular direction of incoming radio signals.
An instrument for measuring solid angles, or the inclination of planes, particularly the angles formed by the faces of crystals.
An instrument for measuring angles, especially the angles of crystals, or the inclination of planes.

a goniometer having two movable arms (ab, cd), between which (at ab) the faces of the crystals are placed. These arms turn about a fixed point, which is the center of the graduated circle or semicircle upon which the angle is read off.

an instrument for measuring the angles of crystals by determining through what angular space the crystal must be turned so that two rays reflected from two surfaces successively shall have the same direction; -- called also Wollaston's goniometer , from the inventor.
A device used to measure the angles of crystals .
An arthrometer (device for measuring the arc or range of mobility of a joint).
direction finder that determines the angular direction of incoming radio signals

goniometric.explanation: Pertaining to, or determined by means of, a goniometer; trigonometric.
of, relating to, or determined by a goniometer

goniometry.explanation: The art of measuring solid angles.
That branch of trigonometry which treats of circular functions in general, and of their relations.
The art of measuring angles; trigonometry.

gonion.explanation: The outer point on either side of the lower jaw at which the jawbone angles upward.
The angle of the lower jaw; the mandibular angle: chiefly used in eraniology. See craniometry .
An anthropometric landmark located at the most inferior , posterior , and lateral point on the external angle of the mandible .
the craniometric point on either side at the apex of the lower jaw

goniopholis.explanation: A genus of fossil crocodiles with amphicœlous vertebræ: so called from the angular scales. G. crassidens is the Swanage crocodile, found in the parish of Swanage in England.

goniostat.explanation: A device for cutting the facets of diamonds.

goniotheca.explanation: Selaginella and its allies, same as macrosporangium .

goniotropous.explanation: botany , quadrangular, with two of the angles anterior and posterior, and the others lateral, in distinction from pleurotropous , where the sides occupy corresponding positions: applied to the stems of Selaginella , etc.

gonitis.explanation: In pathology , inflammation of the knee-joint.

gonk.explanation: A small furry toy like an ersatz teddy bear , popularized in wartime when production of real teddies stops.

gonna.explanation: Eye dialect spelling of going to : used to express a future action.

gonnardite.explanation: A zeolitic mineral allied to mesolite.
A tetragonal-scalenohedral white mineral containing aluminum , calcium , hydrogen , oxygen , silicon , and sodium .

gonoblast.explanation: In biol , any cell which takes part in reproduction.

gonoblastidium.explanation: In Hydrozoa , an offshoot or a process which bears the reproductive receptacles or gonophores, and the bunch of gonophores so borne.

gonocalyx.explanation: In zoology , the swimming-bell in a medusiform gonophore which is not detached.
The bell of a sessile gonozooid.
The bell of a sessile gonozooid .

gonocheme.explanation: Allman's name of those medusæ of hydrozoans which produce genitalia, as distinguished from blastochemes, which produce buds.

gonochorism.explanation: Separation of the sexes in different individuals; -- opposed to hermaphroditism .
In ontogony, differentiation of male and female individuals from embryos having the same rudimentary sexual organs.
In phylogeny, the evolution of distinct sexes in species previously hermaphrodite or sexless.
The situation in which the individuals of a species are of one of two distinct sexes , and retain that sexuality throughout their lives

gonococcal.explanation: Of, or pertaining to, the gonococcus .

gonococcus.explanation: The bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea.
plural Micrococci which occur in pairs, flattened at their points of contact; the cause of gonorrheal inflammation of the mucous and serous membranes.
A cell (coccus) of the micrococcus found in and among the pus-cells of the gonorrheal discharge.
A vegetable microörganism of the genus Micrococcus, occurring in the secretion in gonorrhea. It is believed by some to constitute the cause of this disease.
A bacterium , taxonomic name Neisseria gonorrhoeae, that is responsible for gonorrhea .
the pus-producing bacterium that causes gonorrhea

gonocyte.explanation: The primordial reproductive cell in the embryo, which later develops into the oöcyte or the spermatocyte.
A long-lived germ cell responsible for spermatogenesis in males and oogenesis in females.

gonof.explanation: A thief or an amateur pick-pocket.

gonolobus.explanation: An asclepiadaceous genus of twining or trailing perennial herbs or woody plants, including about 70 species, all of tropical and northern America.

gonomere.explanation: Either the male or the female pronucleus considered as an autonomous and persisting portion of the cleavage nucleus and the nuclei of the cells which arise by division from the fertilized egg.

gonophore.explanation: A reproductive structure that forms on a hydrozoan polyp.
In botany , a prolongation of the axis of a flower, bearing the stamens and pistil above the perianth, as in Gynandropsis .
In zoology , one of the generative buds or receptacles of the reproductive elements in the hydrozoans or zoöphytes.

In physiology , any accessory organ of generation which serves to convey or detain the generative products of tho gonads or essential sexual organs of either sex. Oviducts and spermiducts of all kinds, as well as uteri, seminal vesicles, etc., are gonophores.

A sexual zooid produced as a medusoid bud upon a hydroid, sometimes becoming a free hydromedusa, sometimes remaining attached. See hydroidea , and Illusts . of athecata , campanularian , and gonosome .
A lengthened receptacle, bearing the stamens and carpels in a conspicuous manner.
An elongated receptacle above the corolla to elevate the stamens and carpels .
A medusoid bud on a hydroid .

gonoplasm.explanation: In Peronosporeæ , that portion of the protoplasm of the antheridium which passes through the fertilization-tube and fertilizes the oösphere.

gonopod.explanation: One of the basal abdominal feet of certain male crustaceans which are specialized as auxiliary reproductive organs, as one of the pair of penes of a crab.
A pleopod that is specialized for fertilisation in the males of some decapods .

gonopodium.explanation: The modified anal fin of the male of certain fishes, such as guppies, used to transfer sperm into the female.
A modified anal fin of certain types of fish that can be used for reproduction

gonopore.explanation: A reproductive aperture or pore, especially of certain insects and worms.
The reproductive orifice of the female, in nemathelminths.

gonorrhea.explanation: A sexually transmitted disease caused by gonococcal bacteria that affects the mucous membrane chiefly of the genital and urinary tracts and is characterized by an acute purulent discharge and painful or difficult urination, though women often have no symptoms.
In pathol., a. specific, contagious, muco-purulent inflammation of the male urethra or the female vagina and urethra. It may also be communicated to the conjunctival and rectal mucous membranes.
A contagious inflammatory disease of the genitourinary tract, affecting especially the urethra and vagina, and characterized by a mucopurulent discharge, pain in urination, and chordee; clap.
An STD caused by a species of bacteria (the gonococcus ) that affects the mucous membrane of the genital and urinary tracts .
a common venereal disease caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae; symptoms are painful urination and pain around the urethra

gonorrheal.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or afflicted with gonorrhoea

gonorrhoea.explanation: a common venereal disease caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae; symptoms are painful urination and pain around the urethra

gonorrhoeic.explanation: Related to gonorrhoea ; pertaining to gonorrhea .

gonosome.explanation: In zoöl., a collective term for the reproductive zoöids of a hydrozoan.
The reproductive zooids of a hydroid colony, collectively.
The reproductive zooids of a hydroid colony , collectively.

gonostyle.explanation: A blastostyle or reproductive zoöid of a hydroid or siphonophore colony.

gonotheca.explanation: The chitinous receptacle within which the gonophores of certain hydrozoans are produced: same as gonangium .

A capsule developed on certain hydroids ( Thecaphora ), inclosing the blastostyle upon which the medusoid buds or gonophores are developed; -- called also gonangium , and teleophore . See hydroidea , and Illust. of campanularian .
the protective covering of a gonangium

gonotome.explanation: In embryology , the portion of the segmented mesoderm which gives rise to the reproductive organs or gonads of the vertebrate embryo.

gonotyl.explanation: A sucker surrounding the genital opening and often intimately associated with the acetabulum of certain trematode worms .

gonozooid.explanation: One of the reproductive or sexual zoöids of an ascidian.
In Hydromedusæ , same as medusoid or gonophore.
A sexual zooid, or medusoid bud of a hydroid; a gonophore. See hydroidea , and Illust. of campanularian .
A sexual zooid , or medusoid bud of a hydroid ; a gonophore .

gony.explanation: A terminal element in some compounds of Greek origin, meaning ‘generation,’ ‘production,’ as in cosmogony, theogony , etc.
The young of the short-tailed albatross, Dutch brachyura .
Probably, some other very large dark pelagic bird, as the giant fulmar, Ossifraga gigantea: a name in use among sailors in the northern Pacific.

The name seems to have been applied originally to southern albatrosses of medium size, with white bodies and black wings, such as Diomedea chlororhyncha. It was thus used by ‘deep-water’ sailors about 1860, and its application to the black-footed albatross, D. nigripes , of the North Pacific is of later date.

gonyalgia.explanation: In pathology , pain in the knee. Also gonalgia .

gonydial.explanation: Pertaining to the gonys of a bird's beak.
Pertaining to the gonys of a bird 's beak .

gonyocele.explanation: In pathology , white swelling. See swelling .

gonyoncus.explanation: Swelling of tumor or the knee.

gonys.explanation: In ornith ., the keel or lower outline of the bill as far as the mandibular rami are united; the inferior margin of the symphysis of the lower jaw. See first cut under bill .
The keel or lower outline of a bird's bill, so far as the mandibular rami are united.
The keel or lower outline of a bird's bill, so far as the mandibular rami are united.

gonytheca.explanation: In entomology , the concavity at the apex of the femur which receives the base of the tibia.

conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual

pod of the peanut vine containing usually 2 nuts or seeds; `groundnut' and `monkey nut' are British terms

Passing between the uprights of the goal and therefore scoring, as a field goal in football.
Used to form exclamatory phrases expressing surprise or dismay.
A good, valuable, or useful part or aspect.

An act of parting or leave-taking.
farewell ; a formula used to another person or persons when the speaker or writer or person addressed is departing .
An utterance of goodbye, the wishing of farewell to someone.

a genus of shrubs and herbs that grow in Australia and New Guinea and Malaysia and southeast Asia

large in amount or extent or degree

superlative form of good : most good .

goodlihead.explanation: The character or nature of a goodly person; goodliness .

goodliness.explanation: Goodly quality or condition; beauty of form; pleasing grace; elegance.
Beauty of form; grace; elegance; comeliness.

goodly.explanation: Of pleasing appearance or character; comely; graceful
Quite large; considerable: a goodly sum.
In a goodly way; courteously , graciously .
large in amount or extent or degree

Used formerly as a courtesy title before the surname of a man not of noble birth.
The man of the house; master; husband; head of a family.
A familiar appellation of civility; a term of respect, frequently used to or of a person before his surname: nearly equivalent to Mr. or sometimes to gaffer. It was sometimes used ironically.
A familiar appellation of civility, equivalent to “My friend”, “Good sir”, “Mister;” -- sometimes used ironically.
A husband; the master of a house or family; -- often used in speaking familiarly.
A husband ; the master of a house or family.
United States clarinetist who in 1934 formed a big band (including black as well as white musicians) and introduced a kind of jazz known as swing (1909-1986)

The state or quality of being good, in any sense; excellence; purity; virtue; grace; benevolence.

that which is pleasing or valuable or useful

a disposition to kindness and compassion

genus of small orchids of the northern hemisphere with creeping rhizomes and stalked ovate leaves and small flowers

goosebeak.explanation: A dolphin: so called from the shape of the snout.

gooseberry.explanation: Any of several spiny shrubs of the genus Ribes, especially R. uva-crispa of Eurasia, having lobed leaves, greenish flowers, and edible greenish to yellow or red berries.
The fruit of any of these plants.
Any of several plants bearing similar fruit.
The farkleberry, Batodendron arboreum : doubtless so called from its somewhat similar fruit. See farkleberry .
The Coromandel goosebery (which see).
One of several species of Polycodium. See squaw-huckleberry .

The berry or fruit of a plant of the genus Ribes , or the plant itself; in botany , a general term for the species of the genus Ribes which belong to the section Grossularia , as the name currant is applied to those of the section Ribesia.
A silly person; a goosecap.
gooseberry wine.
Any thorny shrub of the genus Ribes; also, the edible berries of such shrub. There are several species, of which Ribes Grossularia is the one commonly cultivated.
A silly person; a goose cap.
a climbing prickly shrub ( Pereskia aculeata ) of the West Indies, which bears edible berries resembling gooseberries.
See Carambola .
See 1st Fool .
the larva of a small moth ( Dakruma convolutella ). It destroys the gooseberry by eating the interior.
A fruit closely related to the currant .
Any of several other unrelated fruits, such as the Chinese gooseberry ( kiwifruit ) and the Indian gooseberry ( amla ).
An additional person who is neither necessary nor wanted in a given situation.
currant-like berry used primarily in jams and jellies
spiny Eurasian shrub having greenish purple-tinged flowers and ovoid yellow-green or red-purple berries

goosebill.explanation: Nautical , an old-fashioned sail, in shape something like the bill of a goose or duck. It was used before the wind.

goosed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of goose .

goosefish.explanation: Any of several edible anglerfishes of the family Lophiidae, such as L. americanus of North American Atlantic waters, having a tapering body with a flattened head and a large mouth.
The fishing-frog or angler, Lophius piscatorius.
fishes having large mouths with a wormlike filament attached for luring prey

gooseflesh.explanation: A rough condition of the skin, resembling that of a plucked goose, caused by the contraction of the erector muscles of the superficial hairs (arrectores pilorum), and induced by cold, fear, and other exciting causes. Also called goose-skin (and in New Latin cutis anserina ). See horripilation .
A peculiar roughness of the skin produced by cold or fear, in which the hair follicles become erect and form bumps on the skin; -- called also goose skin , goose pimples , goose bumps .
reflex erection of hairs of the skin in response to cold or emotional stress or skin irritation

goosefoot.explanation: Any of various often weedy plants of the genus Chenopodium, having small greenish flowers.
A plant of some species of the genus Chenopodium : so called from the shape of the leaves.
The formation of the facial nerve in spreading into a leash of nerves in three principal divisions after its exit from the stylomastoid foramen: translating the technical term pes anserinus
A genus of herbs (Chenopodium) mostly annual weeds; pigweed.
Any of many flowering plants , of the subfamily Chenopodioideae , having small greenish flowers.
any of various weeds of the genus Chenopodium having small greenish flowers

goosegrass.explanation: Any of several plants used as food for geese or having a seedhead resembling a bird's foot, especially cleavers, silverweed, or the weedy grass Eleusine indica.
Any of various grasses , sometimes used as food for geese .

gooselike.explanation: Resembling or characteristic of a goose .

gooseneck.explanation: A slender curved object or part, such as the flexible shaft of a type of desk lamp.
A pivoting connector by which the boom is attached to the mast on many sailboats.
Nautical : A sort of iron hook fitted to the inner end of a yard or boom, for temporary attachment to a clamp of iron or an eye-bolt, A davit.
In machinery , a pipe shaped like the letter S; a flexible coupling.
A nozle with a universal joint used on a fire-engine stand-pipe
In lumbering : A wooden bar used to couple two logging-trucks. Also called rooster .
The point of draft on a logging-sled: it consists of a curved iron hook bolted to the roll. Also called draw-hook
A curved iron hook driven into the bottom of a slide to check the speed of descending logs.
Anything with a slender curved shape, resembling the neck of a goose , such as the shaft of some lamps.

The swivel connection on a sailboat located near the bottom of the mast that the boom attaches to. When a sailboat performs a tack or a jibe the gooseneck swings the boom from one side of the boat to the other.
something in a thin curved form (like the neck of a goose)

goosery.explanation: A place for the keeping of geese.
Silliness or stupidity like that attributed to the goose.
The characteristics or actions of a goose; silliness.
The characteristics or actions of a goose; silliness .

gooses.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of goose .

gooseskin.explanation: the skin of a goose , especially the removable skin of a the goose form of a narnauk who transforms back into a goose by putting the skin back on

goosewing.explanation: Nautical : The clue of a squaresail that is kept hauled out by its sheet when the other clue is hauled up to the yard and furled.
One of the clews or lower corners of a course or a topsail when the middle part or the rest of the sail is furled.
One of the clews or lower corners of a course or a topsail when the middle part or the rest of the sail is furled .

goosewinged.explanation: : Having, as a course or topsail, only one clue set, the middle of the sail and the other clue being securely furled.
Said of a fore-and-aft rigged vessel with foresail set on one side and mainsail on the other; wing and wing.
Having a goosewing ; said of a fore-and-aft rigged vessel with foresail set on one side and mainsail on the other.

goosy.explanation: Relating to or resembling a goose.

gopher.explanation: Any of various short-tailed, burrowing rodents of the family Geomyidae of North America, having fur-lined external cheek pouches.
Any of various ground squirrels of North American prairies.

mining , to begin or carry on mining operations at haphazard, or on a small scale; mine without any reference to the possibility of future permanent development. Such mine-openings are frequently called gopher-holes and coyote-holes.
One of the pouched rats or pocket-gophers, sundry species of the rodent family Geomyidœ and genera Geomys and Thomomys. See these words, and cut under Geomyidæ .
One of the spermophiles, burrowing squirrels, or ground-squirrels of the family Sciuridœ , subfamily Spermophilinœ , and genera Cynomys, Spermophilus , and Tamias.
The Testudo (or Xerobates ) carolina , a tortoise from 12 to 15 inches long, of gregarious nocturnal and fossorial habits, abundant in the southern Atlantic States.
A snake, Spilote scouperi. Also called gopher snake .
In some parts of the southern United States, a plow.
A kind of waffle. See gofer .
One of several North American burrowing rodents of the genera Geomys and Thomomys, of the family Geomyidæ ; -- called also pocket gopher and pouched rat . See pocket gopher , and tucan .

One of several western American species of the genus Spermophilus, of the family Sciuridæ ; as, the gray gopher ( Spermophilus Franklini ) and the striped gopher ( S. tridecemlineatus ); -- called also striped prairie squirrel , leopard marmot , and leopard spermophile . See Spermophile .
A large land tortoise ( Testudo Carilina ) of the Southern United States, which makes extensive burrows.
A large burrowing snake ( Spilotes Couperi ) of the Southern United States.
an irregular prospecting drift, following or seeking the ore without regard to regular grade or section.
A small burrowing rodent , especially in the family Geomyidae
The gopher tortoise
Alternative spelling of gofer .
burrowing edible land tortoise of southeastern North America
burrowing rodent of the family Geomyidae having large external cheek pouches; of Central America and southwestern North America
any of various terrestrial burrowing rodents of Old and New Worlds; often destroy crops
a native or resident of Minnesota
a zealously energetic person (especially a salesman)

gopherwood.explanation: A small handsome round-headed deciduous tree ( Cladrastis lutea ) having showy white flowers in terminal clusters and heavy hardwood yielding yellow dye; also called yellowwood .
small handsome roundheaded deciduous tree having showy white flowers in terminal clusters and heavy hardwood yielding yellow dye

gopura.explanation: In India, especially in the south, a pyramidal tower over the gateway of a temple. Also gopuram .
A monumental tower , usually ornate , at the entrance of a temple , especially in Southern India .

gora.explanation: A South African musical instrument, consisting of a bent piece of wood or bow with a single gut string attached, which is sounded by the player′ s breath directed through or against a quill that is fastened to one end of the bow. Sometimes a small gourd is attached to the bow as a resonator.

goracco.explanation: Tobacco prepared with aromatics in the form of paste, smoked in hookahs by the natives of western India.
A paste prepared from tobacco, and smoked in hookahs in Western India.
A paste prepared from tobacco and smoked in hookahs in western India .

goral.explanation: A kind of goat-antelope, Antilope or Nemorhœdus goral , inhabiting the Himalaya mountains.
An Indian goat antelope ( Nemorhedus goral ), resembling the chamois.
A type of Asian ungulate ruminant , now defined as any of several species of the genus Nemorhaedus .
small goat antelope with small conical horns; of southern Asian mountains

gorce.explanation: A pool of water to keep fish in; a weir.
A pool of water to keep fish in; a wear.
A pool of water to keep fish in; a weir .

gorcock.explanation: The Scotch moor-cock, red-grouse, or red-game, Lagopus scoticus. Also garcock .
The moor cock, or red grouse. See grouse .

gorcrow.explanation: The common carrion-crow, Corvus corone. Also garcrow .
The carrion crow; -- called also gercrow .

gordiacea.explanation: A division of nematoid worms, including the hairworms or hair eels (Gordius and Mermis). See gordius , and Illustration in Appendix.

gordiaceous.explanation: of, relating to, or being a member of the Nematomorpha

gordian.explanation: heraldry , a name sometimes given to the Navarre knot, or the figure of interlinked chains which forms the bearing of the kings of Navarre.
[ lowercase ] A complication; a Gordian knot.
[⟨ Gordius + - an. ] A hairworm; one of the Gordiidæ.
Pertaining to Gordius , king of Phrygia, or to a knot tied by him; hence, intricate; complicated; inextricable.

an intricate knot tied by Gordius in the thong which connected the pole of the chariot with the yoke. An oracle having declared that he who should untie it should be master of Asia, Alexander the Great averted the ill omen of his inability to loosen it by cutting it with his sword. Hence, a Gordian knot is an inextricable difficulty; and to cut the Gordian knot is to remove a difficulty by bold and energetic measures.
extremely intricate; usually in phrase `Gordian knot'

gordius.explanation: The typical genus of threadworms of the family Gordiidæ ; the hair-worms or hair-eels.
[ lowercase ; pl. gordii (-ī).] A species or an individual of the genus Gordius; a gordian.

A genus of long, slender, nematoid worms, parasitic in insects until near maturity, when they leave the insect, and live in water, in which they deposit their eggs; -- called also hair eel , hairworm , and hair snake , from the absurd, but common and widely diffused, notion that they are metamorphosed horsehairs.
legendary king of ancient Phrygia who was said to be responsible for the Gordian knot

gordonia.explanation: A ternstrœmiaceous genus, of two species, very ornamental evergreen shrubs or small trees of the southern United States, with large white flowers.

gore.explanation: To pierce or stab with a horn or tusk.
A triangular or tapering piece of cloth forming a part of something, as in a skirt or sail.
A small triangular piece of land.
To provide with a gore.
To cut into a gore.
Blood, especially coagulated blood from a wound.
Dirt; mud. [Prov. Eng.]
Blood that is shed or drawn from the body; thick or clotted blood.
A relatively long and narrow triangular strip or slip; a projecting point. Specifically
A triangular piece or tapering strip of land.
In Maine and Vermont, and formerly in Massachusetts, an unorganized and thinly settled subdivision of a county.

A triangular piece or strip of material inserted to make something, as a garment or a sail, wider in one part than in another; especially, in dressmaking , a long triangle introduced to make a skirt wider at the bottom or hem than at the waist. See goring .
A part of the dress; hence, the dress itself; a garment.
An angular plank used in fitting a vessel's skin to the frames.

In heraldry , a charge consisting of two curved lines, one from the sinister chief point, the other from the base middle point, meeting in an acute angle in the middle of the fesse-point. Also called gusset .
Dirt; mud.
Blood; especially, blood that after effusion has become thick or clotted.
To cut in a traingular form; to piece with a gore; to provide with a gore.
A wedgeshaped or triangular piece of cloth, canvas, etc., sewed into a garment, sail, etc., to give greater width at a particular part.
A small traingular piece of land.
One of the abatements. It is made of two curved lines, meeting in an acute angle in the fesse point.
To pierce or wound, as with a horn; to penetrate with a pointed instrument, as a spear; to stab.
Dirt , filth .
Blood , especially that from a wound when thickened due to exposure to the air.
Murder , bloodshed , violence .
To pierce with the horns .
A triangular piece of land where roads meet .
A triangular or rhomboid piece of fabric , especially one forming part of a three-dimensional surface such as a sail , skirt , hot-air balloon , etc.
An elastic gusset for providing a snug fit in a shoe .
A projecting point.
To cut in a triangular form.
To provide with a gore.
coagulated blood from a wound
wound by piercing with a sharp or penetrating object or instrument
the shedding of blood resulting in murder
cut into gores
a piece of cloth that is generally triangular or tapering; used in making garments or umbrellas or sails
Vice President of the United States under Bill Clinton (born in 1948)

gored.explanation: heraldry : Composed of convex curves larger than in invected.
goared, goré gory. — Fesse gored. Same as fesse arrondi. See fesse .
Simple past tense and past participle of gore .

gores.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gore .

gorge.explanation: A deep narrow passage with steep rocky sides; a ravine.
A narrow entrance into the outwork of a fortification.
The throat; the gullet.
The crop of a hawk.
An instance of gluttonous eating.
The contents of the stomach; something swallowed.
A mass obstructing a narrow passage.
The seam on the front of a coat or jacket where the lapel and the collar are joined.
To stuff with food; glut.
To devour greedily.
To eat gluttonously.
To glut; fill the throat or stomach of; satiate.
In angling , a bait intended to be swallowed by the fish to effect its capture: usually a minnow in which a double-barbed leaded fish-hook is embedded.
A fish-hook consisting of a straight or crescent-shaped piece of stone or bone sharpened at the ends and grooved or perforated in the center: used by primitive tribes.
The throat; the gullet.
Hence —2. That which is swallowed or is provided for swallowing; the material of a meal.
The act of gorging; inordinate eating; a heavy meal: as, to indulge in a gorge after long abstinence.
A jam; a mass which chokes up a passage: as, a gorge of logs in a river; an ice-gorge.
A feeling of disgust, indignation, resentment, or the like: from the sympathetic influence of such emotions, when extreme in degree, upon the muscles of the throat.

In architecture : The narrow part of the Tuscan and Roman Doric capitals, between the astragal above the shaft of the column and the echinus; the necking or hypophyge. It is found also in some provincial Greek Doric, as at Pæstum. See cut under column .
A cavetto or hollow molding.
A narrow passage between steep rocky walls; a ravine or defile with precipitous sides.
The entrance into a bastion or other outwork of a fort. See cut under bastion .
In masonry , a little channel or up-cut on the lower side of the coping, to keep the drip from reaching the wall; a throat.
The groove in the circumference of a pulley.
A pitcher of earthenware or stoneware. Also george .
Synonyms Ravine , Defile. See valley .
To eat greedily and to satiety.
To swallow; especially, to swallow with greediness, or in large mouthfuls or quantities.
To glut; to fill up to the throat; to satiate.
The throat; the gullet; the canal by which food passes to the stomach.
A narrow passage or entrance.
A defile between mountains.
The entrance into a bastion or other outwork of a fort; -- usually synonymous with rear . See Illust. of Bastion .
That which is gorged or swallowed, especially by a hawk or other fowl.
A filling or choking of a passage or channel by an obstruction.
A concave molding; a cavetto.
The groove of a pulley.

A primitive device used instead of a fishhook, consisting of an object easy to be swallowed but difficult to be ejected or loosened, as a piece of bone or stone pointed at each end and attached in the middle to a line.
the outline of the smallest cross section of a hyperboloid of revolution.
a minimum circle on a surface of revolution, cut out by a plane perpendicular to the axis.
trolling with a dead bait on a double hook which the fish is given time to swallow, or gorge.
two fishhooks, separated by a piece of lead.
Gorgeous .
A deep narrow passage with steep rocky sides; a ravine .
The throat or gullet .
To eat greedily and in large quantities.
overeat or eat immodestly; make a pig of oneself

gorged.explanation: heraldry , bearing something around its neck; especially and more accurately, having a crown or coronet round its neck: as, a swan ducally gorged. Also collared .
Bearing a coronet or ring about the neck.
With a stomach stuffed full of food .
With the neck collared or encircled by an object.
Simple past tense and past participle of gorge .

gorgelet.explanation: A small gorget, as of a humming bird.
A small gorget , as of a hummingbird .

gorgeous.explanation: Characterized by magnificence or virtuosic brilliance.
Imposing through splendid or various colors; showy; fine; magnificent.

gorgeousness.explanation: The condition or quality of being gorgeous; splendor of dress, adornment, or decoration; magnificence.
The characteristic or quality of being gorgeous

gorger.explanation: One who or that which gorges; specifically ( nautical ), a big haul or heavy deck of fish.
someone who eats food rapidly and greedily

gorgerin.explanation: In architecture , the neck of a capital, or more commonly a feature forming the junction between the shaft and the capital; a necking.
A name for the gorget, plastron, or hausse-col—that is, for any piece of armor covering the throat; especially, a second thickness bolted upon the cuirass of tilting-armor at the throat.

In some columns, that part of the capital between the termination of the shaft and the annulet of the echinus, or the space between two neck moldings; -- called also neck of the capital , and hypotrachelium . See Illust. of column .
In some columns , that part of the capital between the termination of the shaft and the annulet of the echinus , or the space between two neck moldings; the hypotrachelium .
the molding at the top of a column

gorges.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gorge .

gorget.explanation: A piece of armor protecting the throat.
An ornamental collar.
The scarflike part of a wimple covering the neck and shoulders.
A band or patch of distinctive color on the throat of an animal, especially an area of brightly colored feathers on the throat of a bird.
In archaeology , an object of stone or shell, flat, or convex on one side and concave on the other, and sometimes provided with perforations.
A piece of armor protecting the throat and sometimes the upper part of the breast.
A variety of wimple in use in the fourteenth century. It was worn very tight and close.
An ornamental neck-band having a considerable breadth, especially in front.
In ornithology , a throat-patch in any way distinguished by the color or texture of the feathers. Also gorgelet .
In surgery , a grooved instrument used in operations for anal fistula and in lithotomy. It serves as a guide, and in some instances is furnished with a blade for cutting. Also gorgeret .
A piece of armor, whether of chain mail or of plate, defending the throat and upper part of the breast, and forming a part of the double breastplate of the 14th century.
A piece of plate armor covering the same parts and worn over the buff coat in the 17th century, and without other steel armor.
A small ornamental plate, usually crescent-shaped, and of gilded copper, formerly hung around the neck of officers in full uniform in some modern armies.
A ruff worn by women.
A cutting instrument used in lithotomy.
A grooved instrunent used in performing various operations; -- called also blunt gorget .
A crescent-shaped, colored patch on the neck of a bird or mammal.
a humming bird of the genus Trochilus. See Rubythroat .
A piece of armour for the throat .
A type of women's clothing covering the neck and breast ; a wimple .
An ornament for the neck ; a necklace , ornamental collar , torque etc.
armor plate that protects the neck

gorgio.explanation: One who is not a Gipsy; an outsider.

gorgoneion.explanation: A mask of the Gorgon; the head of Medusa; in classical mythology , such a mask or head as an attribute of Pallas, who bore it on her breast in the midst of her ægis, and also on her shield. See cut under ægis .
A mask carved in imitation of a Gorgon's head.
A mask carved in imitation of a Gorgon's head .

gorgonia.explanation: Gorgoniidæ; the sea-fans with arborescent sclerobase. See cut under coral .
gnu . Also Gorgon. J. E. Gray .

A genus of Gorgoniacea, formerly very extensive, but now restricted to such species as the West Indian sea fan ( Gorgonia flabellum ), sea plume ( G. setosa ), and other allied species having a flexible, horny axis.

gorgoniacea.explanation: One of the principal divisions of Alcyonaria, including those forms which have a firm and usually branched axis, covered with a porous crust, or cœnenchyma, in which the polyp cells are situated.

gorgoniacean.explanation: Any member of the Gorgoniaceæ , as a gorgoniid.

gorgonian.explanation: Any of various colonial corals of the order Gorgonacea (or Alcyonacea), having a usually branched skeleton of horny material and polyps with eight tentacles, and including the sea fans, sea feathers, and red corals.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a Gorgon; terrifying into stone; terrific.
Any coral of the order Gorgonacea.
Of or relating to the Gorgons.
Of or relating to any coral of the order Gorgonacea.
corals having a horny or calcareous branching skeleton

gorgonin.explanation: A dark-brown, horn-like, albuminoid compound comprising the axial skeleton of the coral Gorgonia Cavolinii.
A complex protein frequently containing appreciable quantities of iodine and bromine that makes up the horny skeleton of typical gorgonians .

gorgonize.explanation: To have a paralyzing or stupefying effect on.
To have the effect of a Gorgon upon; to turn into stone; to petrify.

gorgonized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gorgonize .

gorgonzola.explanation: A blue-veined Italian cheese , made from cow 's milk.

gorier.explanation: comparative form of gory : more gory

goriest.explanation: superlative form of gory : most gory .

gorilla.explanation: Either of two large apes (Gorilla gorilla or G. beringei) native to the forests of equatorial Africa, having a stocky body and coarse dark brown or black hair.
A powerfully built, aggressive, and often crude man.

The largest known anthropoid ape, Troglodytes gorilla , of the family Simiidæ , suborder Anthropoidea , and order Primates , most closely resembling man, especially in the form of the pelvis and in the proportion of the molar teeth to the incisors.
[ capitalized ] A genus of Simiidæ , having the gorilla, Gorilla gina or G. savagei , as type and only species.

A large, arboreal, anthropoid ape of West Africa. It is larger than a man, and is remarkable for its massive skeleton and powerful muscles, which give it enormous strength. In some respects its anatomy, more than that of any other ape, except the chimpanzee, resembles that of man.
The largest of the apes , native to the forests of central Africa , and known for its trait of knuckle-walking
A big and brutish man or a thug ; a goon or ruffian .
largest anthropoid ape; terrestrial and vegetarian; of forests of central west Africa

gorillian.explanation: of, relating to, or resembling a gorilla

goring.explanation: A piece of textile material cut diagonally so as to increase the width of the part to which it is applied, or in a sail to give the required sweep. Also called goring-cloth .
A piece of canvas cut obliquely to widen a sail at the foot.
German politician in Nazi Germany who founded the Gestapo and mobilized Germany for war (1893-1946)

gormand.explanation: A dainty feeder; an epicure; a gourmet.
A greedy or ravenous eater; a luxurious feeder ; a gourmand .

gormandise.explanation: overeat or eat immodestly; make a pig of oneself

gormandize.explanation: To eat greedily; to swallow voraciously; to feed ravenously or like a glutton; to make a pig of oneself.
overeat or eat immodestly; make a pig of oneself

gormandized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gormandize .

gormandizer.explanation: A young, upright branch or sucker growing from the main stem or from an old branch of a cultivated free: so called from the rapidity of its growth. See sucker , 5 . Also called chupon .
A greedy, voracious eater; a gormand; a glutton.
A person who gormandizes ; a glutton or gourmand

gormandizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gormandize .

gormless.explanation: Lacking intelligence or vitality; stupid or dull.
Lacking intelligence , sense or discernment , often implying lack of capacity of will to remedy the condition .
Inexperienced , naïve , innocent to the point of foolishness .

gorse.explanation: Any of several spiny evergreen shrubs of the genus Ulex of the pea family, especially U. europaeus, native to Europe and naturalized elsewhere, having fragrant yellow flowers and black pods.
The common furze or whin, Ulex Europæus.
the European linnet; -- called also gorse hatcher .
the corncrake; -- called also grass drake , land drake , and corn drake .
evergreen shrub , of the genus Ulex, having spiny leaves and yellow flowers.
very spiny and dense evergreen shrub with fragrant golden-yellow flowers; common throughout western Europe

gorsedd.explanation: A community of bards , usually Welsh, but can also refer to the Breton and Cornish communities.

gorst.explanation: A dialectal and the earlier form of gorse .

gortonian.explanation: One of a sect, followers of Samuel Gorton, a religious fanatic in New England, who died in 1677. He held various mystical doctrines, and rejected ecclesiastical forms.

gory.explanation: Covered or stained with gore; bloody.
Full of or characterized by bloodshed and violence.
Covered with gore or clotted blood.

gos.explanation: A Middle English form of goose .

gosain.explanation: A Hindu priest, devotee, monk, or religious mendicant.

gosh.explanation: Used to express mild surprise or delight.
A mild expression of surprise or enthusiasm as to be put in place of “God”, particularly in fear of saying the Lord’s name in vain.

goshawk.explanation: Any of several large, powerful accipiters, especially the northern goshawk (Accipiter gentilis), having broad rounded wings and a long tail.
A large noble hawk, Astur palumbarius , of the subfamily Accipitrinæ and family Falconidæ; the goose-hawk.

Any large hawk of the genus Astur, of which many species and varieties are known. The European ( Astur palumbarius ) and the American ( A. atricapillus ) are the best known species. They are noted for their powerful flight, activity, and courage. The Australian goshawk ( A. Novæ-Hollandiæ ) is pure white.
Any of several birds of prey , principally in the genus , Accipiter .
large hawk of Eurasia and North America used in falconry

goshenite.explanation: A variety of beryl found at Goshen in Massachusetts.

goslarite.explanation: Native hydrous sulphate of zinc, or zinc vitriol, found in the mines near Goslar in the Harz. Also called white copperas .
An orthorhombic-disphenoidal mineral containing hydrogen , oxygen , sulfur , and zinc .

goslet.explanation: A very small goose of the genus Nettapus , about as large as a teal, of which there are several species in India, South Africa, Australia, etc.
One of several species of pygmy geese, of the genus Nettepus. They are about the size of a teal, and inhabit Africa, India, and Australia.
A pygmy goose of the genus Nettepus.

gosling.explanation: A naive or inexperienced young person.
A young goose; a goose before it has attained its full plumage.
The catkin of the willow: so called from its yellow color and fluffy texture.
The American pasque-flower, Pulsatilla hirsutissima : so called from its dense, soft hairs.
A catkin on nut trees and pines.
A callow (immature, inexperienced) / foolish , naive, young person.
A catkin on nut trees and pines .

gosmore.explanation: A plant of the genus Hypochœris , especially H. radicata , now naturalized in New Jersey and California. See cat's-ear and Hypochœis.

gout.explanation: A disturbance of uric-acid metabolism occurring chiefly in males, characterized by painful inflammation of the joints, especially of the feet and hands, and arthritic attacks resulting from elevated levels of uric acid in the blood and the deposition of urate crystals around the joints. The condition can become chronic and result in deformity.
A drop; a clot; a coagulation.
In falconry , a spot on a hawk.

A disorder characterized by uricemia, by very painful acute or chronic inflammations in the joints, chiefly the smaller joints, and especially in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe, and by the deposition of crystals of sodium urate in the inflamed joint-tissues, in nodules in the pinna of the ear, under the skin in the hands and feet, and elsewhere.
A gateway bridge over a watercourse.
A sluice in embankments against the sea, for letting out the land-waters when the tide is out, and preventing the ingress of salt water. Also written go-out .
A drop; a clot or coagulation.

A constitutional disease, occurring by paroxysms. It consists in an inflammation of the fibrous and ligamentous parts of the joints, and almost always attacks first the great toe, next the smaller joints, after which it may attack the greater articulations. It is attended with various sympathetic phenomena, particularly in the digestive organs. It may also attack internal organs, as the stomach, the intestines, etc. It is an inherited disease of purine metaboism, which causes an increased level of uric acid in the blood, and leads to deposition of crystals of sodium urate in cartilage within joints and in connective tissue. It can be alleviated by a diet low in purines, and is treated by drugs which block formation of uric acid.
A disease of cornstalks. See Corn fly, under Corn .

An extremely painful inflammation of joints, especially of the big toe, caused by a metabolic defect resulting in the accumulation of uric acid in the blood and the deposition of urates around the joints.
a painful inflammation of the big toe and foot caused by defects in uric acid metabolism resulting in deposits of the acid and its salts in the blood and joints

music , to add grace-notes, cadenzas, etc., to: as, to grace a melody.

That element or quality of form, manner, movement, carriage, deportment, language, etc., which renders it pleasing or agreeable; elegance or beauty of form, outline, manner, motion, or act; pleasing harmony or appropriateness; that quality in a thing or an act which charms or delights: as, to move with easy grace.

plural [ capitalized ] In classical mythology , the goddesses of the beauty, brightness, and joy in nature and humanity. The Graces are the Charites of the Greeks, variously described as daughters of Helios (the Sun) and Aigle (heavenly brightness), or of Zeus (Jupiter) and Eurynome (daughter of Ocean —the Aurora). They were also variously named, but their most familiar names are Aglaϊa(the brilliant), Euphrosyne(cheerfulness), and Thalia (the bloom of life). They had in their gift grace, loveliness, and favor, and were attendants in the train of Aphrodite.
Amenity of disposition or manner; sweetness or amiability; graciousness; politeness; courtesy; civility: as, to yield with good grace.

plural A kind of play or game designed to exhibit or develop easy gracefulness in motion. One player, by means of two sticks held one in each hand. throws a small hoop to another, who endeavors to catch it on two similar sticks, and then to throw it back in the same way.
A pleasing and attractive quality or endowment; beauty; adornment; embellishment.

In music , an embellishment, whether vocal or instrumental, not essential to the harmony or melody of a piece, such as an appoggiatura, a trill, a turn, etc. Such embellishments were much more common in music for the harpsichord and the viol than they are for modern instruments; their exact form and even the place of their introduction were often left in the eighteenth century to the taste of the performer.
Favor; good will; friendship; favorable disposition to another; favorable regard: as, to be in one′ s good graces; to reign by the grace of God.
An act of kindness or favor accorded to or bestowed on another; a good turn or service freely rendered.

A faculty, license, or dispensation bestowed by legal authority, the granting of which rests in discretion or favor, and is not to be asked as of right; a privilege; also, in English law , a general and free pardon by act of Parliament. Also called act of grace .

In Scrip , and theology : The free, unmerited love and favor of God: as, the doctrine of grace (that is, the doctrine that all things, including salvation, are received from God as a free gift, and not merited or earned by man).
The enjoyment of the favor of God.

Benefit, especially inward spiritual gifts, conferred by God through Christ Jesus; specifically, power or disposition to yield obedience to the divine laws, to practise the Christian virtues, and to bear trouble or affliction with patience and resignation: as, grace to perform a duty, or to bear up under an affliction.
Virtue; power; efficacy.
Share of favor allotted to one; lot; fortune; luck.
Mercy; pardon.
Indulgence; forbearance; allowance of time: as, three days′ grace for the payment of a note.
In English universities, an act, vote, or decree of the government of the institution: as, a grace was approved by the Senate at Cambridge for founding a Chinese professorship.
Thanks; thanksgiving.

A formula of words expressing thanks and craving a blessing on or with a meal or refreshment; a short prayer before or after meals, in which a blessing is asked or thanks are rendered: as, to say grace; grace before meat.
A title of honor formerly borne by the sovereigns of England, but now used only as a ceremonious title in speaking to or of a duke, a duchess, or an archbishop: as, his Grace the Duke of Wellington.

The period.beyond the fixed day for payment allowed by law or custom for paying a note or bill of exchange. In Great Britain and the united States, at common law, three days are allowed; but if the last day of grace falls on Sunday, or any day on which business is not legally carried on, the bill or note is payable on the day preceding. Modern statutes have made some changes in these rules, particularly as regards legal holidays immediately preceding or following Sunday. Bankers′ checks are payable on demand without days of grace, and the same rule applies to bills or notes payable on demand.

tongue grafting, the same as splice grafting, except that a cleft or slit is made in the end of both scion and stock, in the direction of the grain and in the middle of the sloping surface, forming a kind of tongue, so that when put together, the tongue of each is inserted in the slit of the other.

In the quantitative system of classification (1902), it is proposed to apply the term granite for field purposes to all phanerocrystalline rocks composed of quartz and feldspar of any kind, with mica, hornblende, or other ferromagnesian mineral, if present in subordinate amounts. See rock .

A rock composed of orthoclase-feldspar, mica, and quartz, and having a thoroughly crystalline-granular texture.
A kind of rough-grained water-ice or sherbet. Also called rock-punch and rock ice-cream. See the extract.

A crystalline, granular rock, consisting of quartz, feldspar, and mica, and usually of a whitish, grayish, or flesh-red color. It differs from gneiss in not having the mica in planes, and therefore in being destitute of a schistose structure.

A group of igneous and plutonic rocks composed primarily of feldspar and quartz . Usually contains one or more dark minerals , which may be mica , pyroxene , or amphibole . Granite is quarried for building stone, road gravel, decorative stone, and tombstones . Common colors are gray, white, pink, and yellow-brown.

granitization.explanation: In geology , an extreme phase of metamorphism leading to the transformation of sediments into rock which resembles igneous granite.

granivore.explanation: Any animal, but more particularly a bird, that feeds upon grain.

granivorous.explanation: Eating grain; feeding or subsisting on seeds.

granjeno.explanation: In the southwestern United States and in northern Mexico, a shrub, Momisia pallida , of the elm family, which bears small orange-colored or red berries having an acid pulp. The plant is suitable for hedges, and the fruit is edible, though not much esteemed by the natives.

grannie.explanation: A less common variant spelling of granny .

grannom.explanation: A British anglers' name for a caddis-fly, Brachycentrus subnubilis , or an imitation of it.

granny.explanation: A duck, the south-southerly or old-wife. More fully, old granny.

typically or stereotypically old-fashioned, especially in clothing and accessories worn by or associated with elderly women.

grano.explanation: A money of account in. Malta, equal to about one twelfth of an English penny.

granoblastic.explanation: Containing equidimensional grains of metamorphic rock formed by recrystallization

granodiorite.explanation: A coarse-grained igneous rock consisting primarily of quartz, plagioclase feldspar, and potassium feldspar, and also containing biotite, hornblende, or pyroxene.
A phanerocrystalline rock intermediate in composition between granite and quartz-diorite: nearly the same as quartz-monzonite.
an intrusive igneous rock similar to granite , but containing more plagioclase than potassium feldspar .

granola.explanation: Rolled oats mixed with various ingredients, such as dried fruit, brown sugar or honey, and nuts, and then baked. Granola is used especially as a breakfast cereal.
A breakfast and snack food consisting of loose , crispy pellets made of nuts, rolled oats , honey and other natural ingredients .
cereal made of especially rolled oats with dried fruits and nuts and honey or brown sugar

granolite.explanation: An evenly granular igneous rock, in distinction from a porphyritic rock.

granolith.explanation: A paving stone of crushed granite and cement.

granolithic.explanation: A kind of hard artificial stone, used for pavements.

granophyre.explanation: A fine-grained granite porphyry having a groundmass with irregular intergrowths of quartz and feldspar.
In lithology , the ground-mass of the porphyritic rocks when this is made up either entirely or almost, entirely of a crystalline mixture of the component minerals.

granose.explanation: entomology , having the form of a string of grains or beads; moniliform, as the antennæ of many insects.

granospherite.explanation: In petrography , a spherulite composed of grains arranged radially or concentrically.

One of the essential constituents of the starch-grain, which gives a characteristic blue color with iodine, and is converted into sugar by the ferment of saliva. It is distinguished from the other constituent, cellulose, by these two characteristics.

The main constituent of the starch grain or granule, in distinction from the framework of cellulose. Unlike cellulose, it is colored blue by iodine, and is converted into dextrin and sugar by boiling acids and amylolytic ferments.

The main constituent of the starch grain or granule , in distinction from the framework of cellulose . It is coloured blue by iodine , and is converted into dextrin and sugar by boiling acids and amylolytic ferments .

A citrus tree ( Citrus paradisi ) bearing large round edible fruit having a thick yellow rind and juicy somewhat acid pulp.

A cluster, usually nine in number, of small iron balls, put together by means of cast-iron circular plates at top and bottom, with two rings, and a central connecting rod, in order to be used as a charge for a cannon. Formerly grapeshot were inclosed in canvas bags.

graph.explanation: The spelling of a word.

A written character that represents a vowel, consonant, syllable, word, or other expression and that cannot be further analyzed.
A diagram that exhibits a relationship, often functional, between two sets of numbers as a set of points having coordinates determined by the relationship.

To plot (a function) on a graph.

A terminal element in compounds of Greek origin, denoting that which writes, marks, or describes something, as in chronograph, telegraph, seismograph , etc., or, passively, that which is written, as in autograph, electrograph , etc. In the passive use the stricter form is - grammar

A diagrammatic representation of a system of connections by means of a number of spots, which may be all distinguished from one another, some pairs of these spots being connected by lines all of which are of one kind.
Any apparatus for duplicating drawings or writings by printing from a gelatinous surface.
A curve as representing an equation or function.
A line drawn through a series of points whose position has been already determined.
A representation by points on or in a lattice.
The point of a link-motion which describes any curve.
A curve or surface, the locus of a point whose coördinates are the variables in the equation of the locus.

A diagram symbolizing a system of interrelations of variable quantities using points represented by spots, or by lines to represent the relations of continuous variables. More than one set of interrelations may be presented on one graph, in which case the spots or lines are typically distinguishable from each other, as by color, shape, thickness, continuity, etc. A diagram in which relationships between variables are represented by other visual means is sometimes called a graph, as in a bar graph , but may also be called a chart .

A diagram displaying data; in particular one showing the relationship between two or more quantities , measurements or indicative numbers that may or may not have a specific mathematical formula relating them to each other.
A diagram displaying data, in particular one showing the relationship between two or more variables ; specifically, for a function , the set of all tuples .

An ordered pair , where is a set of elements called vertices (or nodes ) and is a set of pairs of elements of , called edges ; informally, a set of vertices together with a set edges that join these vertices.

a visual representation of the relations between certain quantities plotted with reference to a set of axes

graphis.explanation: A genus of lichens found chiefly on the bark of trees. See Graphidei .

graphite.explanation: A soft crystalline allotrope of carbon, composed of graphene layers, having a steel-gray to black metallic luster and a greasy feel, used in lead pencils, lubricants, paints and coatings, and fabricated into a variety of forms such as molds, bricks, electrodes, crucibles, and rocket nozzles.
Same as graffito . See the extract.
One of the forms under which carbon occurs in nature (see carbon ), also known as plumbago and black-lead.

Native carbon in hexagonal crystals, also foliated or granular massive, of black color and metallic luster, and so soft as to leave a trace on paper. It is used for pencils (improperly called lead pencils ), for crucibles, and as a lubricator, etc. Often called plumbago or black lead .
a voltaic battery consisting of zinc and carbon in sulphuric acid, or other exciting liquid.
An allotrope of carbon consisting of planes of carbon atoms arranged in hexagonal arrays with the planes stacked loosely that is used as a dry lubricant and in "lead" pencils .
Short for graphite-reinforced plastic , a composite plastic made with graphite fibers noted for light weight strength and stiffness.
used as a lubricant and as a moderator in nuclear reactors

of, relating to, resembling, or having the structure of graphite

graphitizable.explanation: Able to be converted to graphite

graphium.explanation: A style for writing; a stylus.

A genus of hyphomycetous fungi having the fertile hyphæ closely united into an elongate stipe-like fascicle and bearing at the summit simple hyaline conidia. Over 60 species have been described, occurring mostly on decaying vegetable matter.

grapholite.explanation: A kind of slate suitable for writing on.

graphology.explanation: The study of handwriting, especially when employed as a means of analyzing character.

the study of handwriting , especially as a means of analyzing character

graphomania.explanation: A morbid impulse to write or compose.

Used as part of the name of various surrealist techniques, e.g., a method in which dots are made at the sites of impurities in a blank sheet of paper, and lines are then made between the dots, see "w:Entoptic graphomania".

graphomaniac.explanation: One who is constantly writing, either letters to friends or to the newspapers, or stories and works of fiction, driven thereto either by an exaggerated idea of the importance of what he writes or by an insane impulse.

graphometer.explanation: A mathematical instrument for measuring angles in surveying; a semicircle.

graphophone.explanation: An instrument for recording and reproducing sounds, based on the principle of the phonograph invented by Edison, but of a different mechanical construction. More fully called phonograph-graphophone .
An improvement on the phonograph , using a floating stylus to cut grooves into a wax -coated cardboard cylinder .

graphoscope.explanation: A device for viewing pictures or photographs through a lens.
An optical instrument for magnifying engravings, photographs, etc., usually having one large lens and two smaller ones.
An optical device for showing (or photographing) an image when projected upon the atmosphere as a screen.

graphospasm.explanation: Writers' cramp; scriveners' cramp (which see, under scrivener ).

graphotype.explanation: A process of making blocks for use in surface-printing.
A type-writer for embossing letters upon thin sheets of metal to form type for use in an addressing-machine.
A form of type-casting and -setting machine.

A process for producing a design upon a surface in relief so that it can be printed from. Prepared chalk or oxide of zinc is pressed upon a smooth plate by a hydraulic press, and the design is drawn upon this in a peculiar ink which hardens the surface wherever it is applied. The surface is then carefully rubbed or brushed, leaving the lines in relief.

A process for producing a design upon a surface in relief so that it can be printed from. Prepared chalk or zinc oxide is pressed upon a smooth plate by a hydraulic press , and the design is drawn upon this in a peculiar ink which hardens the surface wherever it is applied. The surface is then carefully rubbed or brushed, leaving the lines in relief.

grapnel.explanation: A small anchor with three or more flukes, especially one used for anchoring a small vessel.
