A boat's anchor having from three to six flukes placed at equal distances about the end of the shank. Also grapline .
A kind of heavy tongs used for hauling logs, stones, etc.

A device for grasping or taking hold of something not otherwise manageable or accessible, as for gripping and recovering tools in a bored well, for raising the core left by a diamond drill, for seizing a submarine telegraph-cable which needs repairs, etc.

Any jumping, orthopterous insect, of the families Acrididæ and Locustidæ , having large hind legs adapted for leaping, and chewing mouth parts. The species and genera are very numerous and some are very destructive to crops. The former family includes the Western grasshopper or locust ( Caloptenus spretus ), noted for the great extent of its ravages in the region beyond the Mississippi. In the Eastern United States the red-legged ( Caloptenus femurrubrum and C. atlanis ) are closely related species, but their ravages are less important. They are closely related to the migratory locusts of the Old World. See locust .

grateful.explanation: Grateful, Thankful , beholden. Grateful is preferred when we speak of the general character of a person's mind: as, a man of a grateful disposition; an ungrateful wretch. Grateful often expresses the feeling, and the readiness to manifest the feeling by acts, even a long time after the rendering of the favor; thankful refers rather to the immediate acknowledgment of the favor by words. The same distinction is found in the negative forms, ungrateful, unthankful, thankless. Thankful is often loosely used for relieved or glad , where the thanks, if rendered, would be given to a merciful or helping Providence: as, I am thankful for my escape.
Having a due sense of benefits received; kindly disposed toward one from whom a favor has been received; willing to acknowledge and repay, or give thanks for, benefits.

Gratify, Indulge, Humor. To gratify is a more positive act than to indulge or to humor. Gratify is most often used in a good sense; indulge , most often in a bad one. an order in the subclass Telosporidia

botany , growing in open clusters, not matted together.
social species, which dominate the whole ground.

In music , a melody written in one of the church modes; a piece of plainsong.

plain song, or canto fermo , a kind of unisonous music, according to the eight celebrated church modes, as arranged and prescribed by Pope Gregory I. (called “the Great”) in the 6th century.
the musical scales ordained by Pope Gregory the Great, and named after the ancient Greek scales, as Dorian, Lydian, etc.

a form of reflecting telescope, named from Prof. James Gregory, of Edinburgh, who perfected it in 1663. A small concave mirror in the axis of this telescope, having its focus coincident with that of the large reflector, transmits the light received from the latter back through a hole in its center to the eyepiece placed behind it.

the year as now reckoned according to the Gregorian calendar. Thus, every year, of the current reckoning, which is divisible by 4, except those divisible by 100 and not by 400, has 366 days; all other years have 365 days. See Bissextile , and Note under Style , n., 7.
of or relating to Pope Gregory I or to the plainsong chants of the Roman Catholic Church
of or relating to Pope Gregory XIII or the calendar he introduced in 1582

the gridiron .

gridlock.explanation: A traffic jam in which no vehicular movement is possible, especially one caused by the blockage of key intersections within a grid of streets.

On a smaller scale: the situation in which cars enter a signal -controlled intersection too late during the green light cycle, and are unable to clear the intersection (due to congestion in the next block ) when the light turns red , thus blocking the cross traffic when it's their turn to go. Repeated at enough intersections, this phenomenon can lead to citywide gridlock.
Figuratively and by extension, any paralysis of a complex system due to severe congestion, conflict, or deadlock .
a traffic jam so bad that no movement is possible

groop .

Specifically— In zoology , any assemblage or classificatory division of animals below the kingdom and above the species: generally said of intermediate or not regularly recognized divisions, or by way of non-committal to the exact taxonomic value of the division thus indicated.
In geology , a division in the geological sequence or classification of the stratified fossiliferous rocks inferior in value to a system or series. See system .

In mathematics , a set of substitutions (or other operations) such that every product of operations of the set itself belongs to the set; a system of conjugate substitutions; a set of permutations resulting from performing all the substitutions of a conjugate system upon a series of elements; a set of functions produced by the n operations of a group of operations from n independent functions, called the fundamental system of the group.
A group of infinitely many but discrete operations, among which infinitely small transformations occur.
in mathematics , a group whose elements have each k indices, or are arranged in a matrix of k dimensions.

In Capelli's extended sense, groups which can be separated each into the same number of subgroups, so that a substitution of a subgroup in the one can be so coordinated to one of the other that products shall correspond to products.

In the recommendations of the International Geological Congress this term is applied, in geological classification, to stratigraphic divisions of the highest order comprising several terrains. Its equivalent term in the time scale is era.
In combinatorial analysis , one of the classes into which the objects are distributed when the order of the objects in a particular class is material.
In group-theory , a set of definite operations containing the operation compounded of any two of the set, and also the inverse of every operation of the set.

In crystallography , a class of crystals characterized by the same degree of symmetry. Each crystalline system embraces several such groups or classes. See symmetry , where the names commonly employed in designating the more important of these groups are given.
In ethnology , a number of people united together by common habits and usages.

three or more columns placed upon the same pedestal.

Among the various fishes of the genus Hæmulon and family Hæmulidæ , so named, are the following:
To make a deep, short noise, as a hog; to utter a short groan or a deep guttural sound.
the yak.
A deep, guttural sound, as of a hog.

Any one of several species of American food fishes, of the genus Hæmulon, allied to the snappers, as, the black grunt ( A. Plumieri ), and the redmouth grunt ( H. aurolineatus ), of the Southern United States; -- also applied to allied species of the genera Pomadasys, Orthopristis, and Pristopoma. Called also pigfish , squirrel fish , and grunter ; -- so called from the noise it makes when taken.
A U. S. infantryman; -- used especially of those fighting in the war in Vietnam.
A short, snorting sound , often to show disapproval, or used as a reply when one is reluctant to speak.
The snorting cry of a pig .
A family of Perciformes fish of the family Haemulidae

grunt.category: Army and United States Marine Corps slang
grunt.explanation: An infantry soldier . (From the sound he presumably makes when shouldering a pack before starting a road march.)
Of a person: To make a grunt or grunts.
Of a pig: To make a grunt or grunts.
medium-sized tropical marine food fishes that utter grunting sounds when caught
an unskilled or low-ranking soldier or other worker
the short low gruff noise of the kind made by hogs
issue a grunting, low, animal-like noise

grunted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of grunt .

grunter.explanation: A horse which has the habit of emitting a sound during expiration, when suddenly moved or startled.
A fish of the family Triglidæ and genus Prionotus : so called along parts of the eastern coast of the United States. See grumbler , 2.
An iron rod with a hook at the end, used by founders.
One who, or that which, grunts; specifically, a hog.
One of several American marine fishes. See Sea robin , and Grunt , n., 2.
A hook used in lifting a crucible.
A group of fish of the family Terapontidae, which make a grunting sound when caught.
A hook used in lifting a crucible .

gruntle.explanation: To humour; to induce the opposite effect of causing a person to become disgruntled .
cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of

grunts.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of grunt .

gruppetto.explanation: A group of cyclists that is separated from the main group of cyclists in a race.

gruppo.explanation: In music : A group or division.
A trill or shake; a relish.

gry.explanation: A measure equal to one tenth of a line of a philosophical foot. It was never in general use.
Anything very small or of little value.
A measure equal to one tenth of a line.
Anything very small, or of little value.
An hundredth of an inch in the decimal system of measurement devised by Locke.

grylle.explanation: A name of the Greenland sea-dove or black guillemot, Uria or Cephus grylle : made by Brandt in 1836 a generic name of the same.

gryllid.explanation: A member of the family Gryllidæ.

gryllotalpa.explanation: A genus of Gryllidæ; the mole-crickets.

gryllus.explanation: A genus of crickets, as G. abreviatus , giving name to the family Gryllidæ : same as Acheta . See cut under Gryllidæ .
A genus of insects including the common crickets.

grypanian.explanation: ornithology , bent at the end, and there more or less hooked or toothed, or both, as the beak of some birds. The ordinary dentirostral beak, as of a thrush, shrike, or flycatcher, is grypanian.

gryphaea.explanation: Any of the genus Gryphaea of extinct gryphaeid oysters .

gryphite.explanation: A fossil oyster of the genus Gryphœa.
A shell of the genus Gryphea.
A shell of the genus Gryphea.

gryphon.explanation: An obsolete or archaic spelling of griffin .
winged monster with the head of an eagle and the body of a lion

gryposis.explanation: In medicine , a curvature, especially of the nails. See onychogryposis .

grypotherium.explanation: A genus of extinct ground-sloths, related to and closely resembling Mylodon and Megatherium. Some

grysbok.explanation: A South African antelope, Calotragus or Neotragus melanotis , of small stature and reddish-brown color flecked with white. It is easily captured, and furnishes excellent venison.
A small South African antelope ( Neotragus melanotis ). It is speckled with gray and chestnut, above; the under parts are reddish fawn.
A small antelope of genus Raphicerus from South Africa

gt.explanation: Contractions used in medical prescriptions for gutta (a drop) or guttæ (drops).

guacamole.explanation: A thick paste of mashed avocado, often combined with citrus juice, onion, and seasonings and usually served as a dip.
An avocado -based greenish dip with onions , tomato , and spices . Common to Mexican cuisine, it is often served with tortilla chips.
a dip made of mashed avocado mixed with chopped onions and other seasonings

guachamaca.explanation: A very poisonous plant of Caracas, belonging to the Apocynaceæ , and probably Malouetia nitida. The poison appears to be a simple narcotic, very similar to curari in its action.

guacharo.explanation: A nightjar (Steatornis caripensis) of northern South America that roosts in caves and eats fruit. The young birds were formerly collected for their fat, which was used for cooking oil.
The oil-bird, Steatornis caripensis , a large goatsucker of the family Caprimulgidæ or placed in Steatornithidæ.
A nocturnal bird of South America and Trinidad ( Steatornis Caripensis , or S. steatornis ); -- called also oilbird .
A nocturnal bird of South America and Trinidad (Steatornis caripensis, or S. steatornis); the oilbird .
nocturnal fruit-eating bird of South America that has fatty young yielding an oil that is used instead of butter

guacho.explanation: One of the mixed-blood (Spanish-Indian) inhabitants of the pampas of South America; a mestizo.
An Indian who serves as a messenger.

guacin.explanation: An amorphous bitter principle obtained from the leaves of guaco.

guaco.explanation: The Mikania Guaco , a climbing composite of tropical America; also, a medicinal substance consisting of, or an aromatic bitter obtained from, the leaves of this plant.
The Aristolochia maxima of tropical America, employed as a remedy for the bites of serpents.
A plant ( Aristolochia anguicida ) of Carthagena, used as an antidote to serpent bites.
The Mikania Guaco , of Brazil, used for the same purpose.
Any of various vine -like climbing plants of Central and South America and the West Indies, including Mikania and Aristolochia species, reputed to have curative powers.

guadalcazarite.explanation: Sulphid of mercury (metacinnabarite) containing a small amount of zinc.

guaguanche.explanation: A small barracuda, Sphyræna guachancho , found in the waters of Cuba.

guaiac.explanation: A paper treated with alpha-guaiaconic acid, used in tests to detect blood in the faeces .
hard greenish-brown wood of the lignum vitae tree and other trees of the genus Guaiacum

guaiacol.explanation: A yellowish oily aromatic substance, C 7 H 8 O 2 , derived from guaiacum or wood creosote and used chiefly as an expectorant, antiseptic, and local anesthetic.

A colorless liquid, C7H8O2, with a peculiar odor. It is the methyl ether of pyrocatechin, and is obtained by distilling guaiacum from wood-tar creosote, and in other ways. It has been used in the past for treating pulmonary tuberculosis.
A naturally occurring aromatic organic compound with the chemical formula C6H4(OH)(OCH3), having certain medicinal applications.

guaiacum.explanation: Any of several tropical American trees of the genus Guaiacum; a lignum vitae.
A greenish-brown resin obtained from this tree, used medicinally and in varnishes.
Any of a number of species of tree of the genus Guaiacum, native to the West Indies and parts of the Americas.
The wood or resin of this tree.

guaiasanol.explanation: Diethyl-glycocoll-guaiacol hydrochlorid. It is soluble in water, and is used in the same way as guaiacol.

guajillo.explanation: A variety of the tropical pepper Capsicum annuum having a deep reddish-orange fruit that is mildly to moderately hot.

guajira.explanation: A style of rural Cuban music .

guama.explanation: A tree of the mimosa family, Inga laurina , extensively used in the West Indies and in Venezuela and Colombia as a coffee shade-tree. It bears broad, bean-like pods, with an edible, sweet, fluffy pulp.
A tropical tree of Central America and the West Indies and Puerto Rico ( Inga laurina ) having spikes of white flowers; it is used as shade for coffee plantations.
tropical tree of Central America and West Indies and Puerto Rico having spikes of white flowers; used as shade for coffee plantations

guamuchil.explanation: A tree, Pithecolobium dulce , which bears abruptly pinnate leaves and pods which contain a sweet edible aril surrounding the seeds. See kamachiles .

guan.explanation: Any of several large game birds of the family Cracidae, native to tropical forests of Central and South America and resembling the curassows.
An American bird of the family Cracidæ and subfamily Penelopinæ , related to the hoccos and curassows.
Any one of many species of large gallinaceous birds of Central and South America, belonging to Penelope, Pipile, Ortalis, and allied genera. Several of the species are often domesticated.
Any (member) of several species of birds in the genera Aburria, Chamaepetes, Oreophasis, Penelope, Penelopina, and Pipile, of the family Cracidae , limited to the Americas .
any of several large turkey-like game birds of the family Cracidae; native to jungles of tropical America; resembling the curassows and valued as food

guana.explanation: The name in Cuba for the lace-like inner bark of the blue or mountain mahoe, Pariti elatum , a malvaceous tree 50 to 60 feet high.
The tuberculated lizard, I guana tuberculata : same as iguana .
The great New Zealand lizard, Hatteria punctata.
A contraction of iguana (the lizard) made in British colonial America. (Reference: The Dinkum Dictionary : The Origins of Australian Words, Susan Butler, Text Publishing, 2001, ISBN 187648585X .)

guanabana.explanation: large spiny tropical fruit with tart pulp related to custard apples

guanajuatite.explanation: A selenide of bismuth occurring in masses with fibrous structure, resembling stibnite, found at Guanajuato in Mexico. Also called frenzelite .
An orthorhombic-dipyramidal mineral containing bismuth and selenium .

guanase.explanation: An autolytic ferment which causes the transformation of guanine to xanthin.

guanethidine.explanation: An antihypertensive drug that reduces the release of catecholamines .

guango.explanation: The Pithecolobium Saman , a leguminous tree of tropical America, the pods of which are used for feeding cattle.

guanidin.explanation: A strong crystallizable base, CH 5 N 3 , which results on oxidation from guanine. In combination with ornithin, as arginin, it represents one of the most constant decomposition-products of the albuminous molecule.

guanidine.explanation: A strongly alkaline crystalline compound, NHC(NH 2 ) 2 , formed by the oxidation of guanine and found in the urine as a normal product of protein metabolism. It is commonly used in the organic synthesis of plastics, resins, and explosives.

A strongly alkaline base, NH2.CNH.NH2, formed by the oxidation of guanin, and also obtained combined with methyl in the decomposition of creatin. Boiled with dilute sulphuric acid, it yields urea and ammonia.
A strong base HN=C(NH2)2 obtained by the oxidation of guanine

guanin.explanation: A crystalline substance (C5H5N5O) contained in guano. It is also a constituent of the liver, pancreas, and other glands in mammals.

guanine.explanation: A purine base, C 5 H 5 ON 5 , that is an essential constituent of both RNA and DNA.
A substance (C 5 H 5 N 5 O) contained in guano.
A substance first obtained from guano ; it is a nucleic base and pairs with cytosine in DNA and RNA .
a purine base found in DNA and RNA; pairs with cytosine

guano.explanation: A substance composed chiefly of the dung of seabirds or bats, accumulated along certain coastal areas or in caves and used as fertilizer.
Any of various similar substances, such as a fertilizer prepared from ground fish parts.
A fertilizing excrement found on many small islands in the Southern Ocean and on the western coast of Africa, but chiefly on islands lying near the Peruvian coast.
A fertilizer made from fishes. See fish-manure .

A substance found in great abundance on some coasts or islands frequented by sea fowls, and composed chiefly of their excrement. It is rich in phosphates and ammonia, and is used as a powerful fertilizer.
Dung from a sea bird or from a bat.
the excrement of sea birds; used as fertilizer

guanosine.explanation: A nucleoside, C 10 H 13 N 5 O 5 , consisting of guanine and ribose.
A nucleoside derived from guanine and ribose .
a nucleoside component of DNA; composed of guanine and deoxyribose

guanylic.explanation: 44 H 66 N 20 P 4 O 34 , obtained from the pancreas.

guao.explanation: A West Indian tree of the cashew family, Comocladia dentata. Its edible fruit is known as maiden-plum (which see).

guapinol.explanation: The courbaril, Hymenæa Courbaril. See Hymenæa .

guar.explanation: An annual plant (Cyamopsis tetragonolobus) in the pea family, cultivated chiefly in semiarid regions of South Asia as a forage crop and especially for its seeds, from which guar gum is obtained.
An annual legume , used as a food for cattle and humans .
drought-tolerant herb grown for forage and for its seed which yield a gum used as a thickening agent or sizing material

guara.explanation: The scarlet ibis, I bis rubra or Eudocimus ruber : taken as a generic name of the scarlet and white ibises by Reichenbach, 1853.
In tropical America, several species of Cupania , trees of the family Sapindaceæ , having pinnate leaves and racemes or panicles of small flowers.
A large-maned wild dog of South America ( Canis jubatus ) -- named from its cry.
Canis jubatus, a large- maned wild dog of South America .

guarabu.explanation: A large tree of the family Cæsalpiniaceæ, Peltogyne confertiflora , which yields a useful wood and from the bark of which a fine red dye is obtained.
One of several species of Astronium , an anacardiaceous genus of large trees. The wood is fine-grained and suitable for building and other purposes.

guaracha.explanation: A kind of sandal used by the Mexicans and the Indians of Mexico.
A graceful Spanish dance, or the music for it.
A genre of Cuban popular music with rapid tempo and lyrics .
A piece performed in this style.

guaraguao.explanation: In Porto Rico, a name of several trees of the genera Trichilia and Samyda , of the mahogany family.

guarana.explanation: A shrub or woody vine (Paullinia cupana) of Amazonia whose seeds are high in caffeine and other alkaloids.
A preparation made from the seeds of this plant, used in beverages and as an herbal medicine for its stimulant and tonic properties.

A paste prepared from the pounded seeds of Paullinia sorbilis , a climbing sapindaceous shrub of Brazil, which in the form of rolls or cakes is extensively used in that country for both food and medicine (it contains caffein), and is employed especially in the preparation of a refreshing drink. Also called guarana-bread .
A preparation from the seeds of Paullinia sorbilis , a woody climber of Brazil, used in making an astringent drink, and also in the cure of headache.
A tree, scientific name Paullinia cupana, native to Venezuela and northern Brazil.

guaranin.explanation: A principle of guarana, similar to if not identical with caffein.

guaranine.explanation: An alkaloid extracted from guarana. Same as caffeine .

guarantee.explanation: Something that assures a particular outcome or condition.
A promise or assurance, especially one given in writing, that attests to the quality or durability of a product or service.
A pledge that something will be performed in a specified manner.
A guarantor.
A guaranty.
To assume responsibility for the debt, default, or miscarriage of.
To assume responsibility for the quality or performance of.
To undertake to do, accomplish, or ensure (something) for another.
To make certain.
To guaranty.
To furnish security for.
To express or declare with conviction.
A person to whom a guaranty is given: the correlative of guarantor.
One who binds himself to see the stipulations or obligations of another performed; in general, one who is responsible for the performance of some act, the truth of some statement, etc.
Same as guaranty .
law , to bind one's self that the obligation of another shall be performed, or that something affecting the right of the person in whose favor the guaranty is made shall be done or shall occur.
guarantee one against loss.

In law and common usage: to undertake or engage for the payment of (a debt) or the performance of (a duty) by another person; to undertake to secure (a possession, right, claim, etc.) to another against a specified contingency, or in all events; to give a guarantee concerning; to engage, assure, or secure as a thing that may be depended on; to warrant.

In law and common usage: A promise to answer for the payment of some debt, or the performance of some duty, in case of the failure of another person, who is, in the first instance, liable to such payment or performance; an engagement which secures or insures another against a contingency; a warranty; a security. Same as guaranty .
One who binds himself to see an undertaking of another performed; a guarantor.
The person to whom a guaranty is made; -- the correlative of guarantor.
Anything that assures a certain outcome .
A written declaration that a certain product will be fit for a purpose and work correctly.
A person who gives such a guarantee; a guarantor .
To assure that something will get done right.
To assume responsibility for a debt .
To make something certain.
give surety or assume responsibility
make certain of
a written assurance that some product or service will be provided or will meet certain specifications
promise to do or accomplish
a collateral agreement to answer for the debt of another in case that person defaults
an unconditional commitment that something will happen or that something is true
stand behind and guarantee the quality, accuracy, or condition of

guaranteed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of guarantee .

guarantees.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of guarantee .

guaranties.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of guaranty .

guarantor.explanation: One, such as a person or corporation, that makes or gives a promise, assurance, or pledge typically relating to quality, durability, or performance.
One who makes or gives a guaranty.
One who makes or gives a guaranty; a warrantor; a surety.
One who engages to secure another in any right or possession.
A person, or company, that gives a guarantee .
one who provides a warrant or guarantee to another

guaranty.explanation: A promise to be answerable for the debt or obligation of another in the event of nonpayment or nonperformance.
Something given as security for the execution, completion, or existence of something else.
The act of providing such security.
A guarantee, as for a product or service.
A guarantee to perform something in a specified way.
A guarantee serving to assure a particular outcome or condition.
A guarantor.
To provide a guaranty for.
To guarantee.
guarantee .
The act of warranting or securing; a warrant or surety.

Specifically, in law , a separate, independent contract by which the guarantor undertakes, in writing, for a valuable consideration, to be answerable for the payment of some particular debt, or future debts, or the performance of some duty, in case of the failure of another person primarily liable to pay or perform. Colebrooke , On Collateral Securities.
That which guarantees anything; a ground or basis of security: as, constitutional guaranties ; his character is guaranty for his assertions; what guaranty have I that you will keep your word?

In law and common usage: An undertaking to answer for the payment of some debt, or the performance of some contract or duty, of another, in case of the failure of such other to pay or perform; a guarantee; a warranty; a security.

In law and common usage: To undertake or engage that another person shall perform (what he has stipulated); to undertake to be answerable for (the debt or default of another); to engage to answer for the performance of (some promise or duty by another) in case of a failure by the latter to perform; to undertake to secure (something) to another, as in the case of a contingency. See guarantee , v. t.
An undertaking to answer for the payment of some debt , or the performance of some contract or duty , of another, in case of the failure of such other to pay or perform ; a warranty ; a security .
Something serving as a security for such an undertaking .
An assurance or guarantee .
Obsolete spelling of guarantee .
a collateral agreement to answer for the debt of another in case that person defaults

guarapo.explanation: A drink made by fermenting the juice of the sugar-cane, or the refuse of the sugar-cane steeped in water.

guard.explanation: To watch over to keep from being harmed or injured: synonym : defend .
To supervise the entry and exit through; keep watch at.
To watch over so as to prevent escape or violence.
To keep from risk or curtailment; ensure the safety or integrity of.
To keep (an opposing player) from scoring or playing effectively, usually by remaining close to the player to disrupt offensive play.
To maintain control over, as to prevent indiscretion.
To furnish (a device or object) with a part that protects people from harm or injury.
To escort as a guard.
To take precautions.
To serve as a guard.
One who protects, keeps watch, or acts as a sentinel.
One who supervises prisoners.
An honor guard.
A railway employee in charge of a train.
One of the two offensive linemen on either side of the center.
Either of the two players normally positioned in the backcourt who are responsible for bringing the ball to and initiating offensive plays from the frontcourt.
A defensive position or stance, as in boxing or fencing.
The act or duty of guarding.
Protection; watch.
Something that gives protection; a safeguard.
A device or attachment that prevents injury, damage, or loss, especially.
An attachment or covering put on a machine to protect the operator or a part of the machine.
A device on a foil, sword, or knife that protects the hand.
A padded covering worn to protect a body part from injury.
A small chain or band attached to a watch or bracelet to prevent loss.
A ring worn to prevent a more valuable ring from sliding off the finger.
A signal that prevents accidental activation of a device or ambiguous interpretation of data.
( off (one's) guard ) Not alert; unprepared.
( on (one's) guard ) Alert and watchful; cautious.
( stand guard ) To keep watch.
( stand guard ) To act as a sentinel.
To shield, shelter, watch.
In foot-ball, basket-ball , and similar games, a player occupying a certain position.
In fortification , the keep of a castle; the lodging of the main guard.
A state of readiness to oppose attack; a state of defense; in general, a state of protection against injury or impairment of any kind.

Specifically, a state of caution or vigilance; attentive observation designed to prevent surprise or attack; watch; heed: as, to keep guard; to be on one's guard; to keep a careful guard over the tongue.
One who or that which protects or keeps in safety; one who or that which secures against danger, attack, loss, or injury; one who keeps protecting watch.

Specifically— A man or body of men occupied in preserving a person or place from attack or injury, or in preventing an escape; he or they whose business it is to defend, or to prevent attack or surprise: as, a body- guard; a prison guard.
Anything that keeps off evil: as, modesty is the guard of innocence.
That which secures against hostile criticism or censure; a protection against malevolent or ignorant attacks upon one's reputation, opinions, etc.
In fencing or boxing , a posture of passive defense; the arms or weapon in such a posture: as, to beat down one's guard.
In the game of cricket, the position of the bat for most effectually defending the wicket.

guardable.explanation: Capable of being guarded or protected.

guardant.explanation: Positioned so that the head is turned toward the viewer. Used of an animal depicted so that its body is viewed from the side.
Positioned with the body viewed from the side, but with the head turned toward the viewer

guarded.explanation: heraldry , trimmed or lined, as with a fur: said of a mantle or cap of maintenance when the edge is turned up or thrown back so as to show the lining.
Cautious; wary; circumspect; ; framed or uttered with caution.
Simple past tense and past participle of guard .

guardedness.explanation: The state or quality of being guarded; caution; circumspection.
The state or condition of being guarded .

guardee.explanation: Any protein (involved in an immune system) that when modified by a pathogen becomes bound by a guard protein, precipitating the immune response

guarder.explanation: One who or that which guards.
A person who guards ; a guard.

guardhouse.explanation: A building that accommodates a military guard.
A jail for the detention of military personnel guilty of minor offenses or awaiting court-martial.
A building in which a military guard is stationed for the care of prisoners confined in it and for the relief of sentries.
A place for the temporary detention of civil prisoners under guard.
A building which is occupied by the guard, and in which soldiers are confined for misconduct; hence, a lock-up.
A small security station, often at the entrance to a facility or a city.
a military facility that serves as the headquarters for military police and in which military prisoners can be detained

guardian.explanation: One that guards, watches over, or protects.
One who is legally responsible for the care and management of the person or property of an incompetent or minor.
A superior in a Franciscan monastery.
A warden; one who guards, preserves, or secures; one to whom some person or thing is committed for preservation from injury; one who has the charge or custody of a person or thing.

Specifically In law , one to whom the law intrusts the care of the person or property, or both, of another. The word is used chiefly in reference to the control of infants; one charged with similar care of an adult idiot or lunatic is now specifically called a committee , though by the civil law termed guardian. A guardian of the property is a trustee , his trust extending to all the property the infant has or may acquire, or all that he or she has or may acquire within the jurisdiction.

Guardians at common law were: Guardian in chivalry , a lord who, when a tenant by knight-service died and left an infant heir to inherit the tenure, was entitled by the feudal law to take the profits of the estate, and make what he could by negotiating a marriage for the heir, under certain restrictions, being bound to maintain the ward meanwhile.
Guardian in socage. See socage .

Guardian by nature , the father, with respect to his guardianship of the person of his heir apparent or heiress presumptive. This guardianship of the person was allowed as an exception to or reservation out of the powers of a guardian in chivalry, so long as the father of the ward lived. (See below.)
Guardian for nurture , in English law, the father, and after his death the mother, as having guardianship of the persons of all their children up to the age of fourteen years.
Guardian by election , a guardian chosen by an infant who would otherwise have none. The choice is not effectual except as it procures appointment by a competent court.

Guardian by custom , an officer or municipality, or the appointee of a lord of the manor, having by local custom, as in London and Kent, England, a legal right to exercise a guardianship. The practical distinctions now are: Judicially appointed guardian , a guardian designated by a court, the judicial power in this respect being now generally regulated by statute; statutory guardian , a guardian appointed by a parent by deed or will, under authority of a statute; testamentary guardian , a guardian appointed by a parent by will, pursuant to the statute; guardian by nature , the father, or, if he be dead, the mother, exercising the common-law custody of the person, and, by statute, in some jurisdictions, the commonlaw power of a guardian in socage in respect to land, if no guardian is expressly appointed.
The superior of a Franciscan convent.
Performing, or appropriate to, the office of a protector.
a church festival instituted by Pope Paul V., and celebrated on October 2d.
Hence, a protector or defender in general.
in the belief of many pagan nations, a spirit, often of a deceased relative or friend, that presides over the interests of a household, a city, or a region.
One who guards, preserves, or secures; one to whom any person or thing is committed for protection, security, or preservation from injury; a warden.
One who has, or is entitled to, the custody of the person or property of an infant, a minor without living parents, or a person incapable of managing his own affairs.
a guardian appointed by a court of justice to conduct a particular suit.
the members of a board appointed or elected to care for the relief of the poor within a township, or district.
Someone who guards , watches over , or protects .
A person legally responsible for a minor ( in loco parentis ).
A person legally responsible for an incompetent person.
A superior in a Franciscan monastery .
A major or final enemy; boss .
a person who cares for persons or property

guardianship.explanation: The office of a guardian; protection; care; watch.
The office, duty, or care, of a guardian; protection; care; watch.
The office or position of one acting as a guardian or conservator , especially in a legal capacity.
the responsibility of a guardian or keeper
attention and management implying responsibility for safety

guardless.explanation: Without a guard or defense; unguarded.

guardlike.explanation: Resembling a guard or some aspect of one.

guardrail.explanation: A protective railing, as on a staircase or along a highway.

On a railway-track, an additional rail placed beside the rail in service, either with the object of receiving the wheel in case it should leave the track or of preventing the wheel from leaving the track.

Nautical , a fore-and-aft timber bolted on the outside of the covering-board or plank-sheer on steam-vessels navigating harbors, lakes, and rivers, to act as a fender when lying alongside of other vessels, or when made fast to a dock. Sometimes a second guardrail is carried along the sides just above the water, and is then called a bilge guard-rail.
a railing placed alongside a stairway or road for safety.
A rail placed alongside a dangerous place in order to improve safety .
a railing placed alongside a stairway or road for safety

guardroom.explanation: A room used by guards on duty.
A room in which military prisoners are confined.
A room for the accommodation of guards.
A room where military delinquents are confined.
The room occupied by the guard during its term of duty; also, a room where prisoners are confined.
A room used by soldiers when on guard
A cell in which military prisoners are kept

guess is used for think, believe , or suppose , even where the meaning is not at all conjectural, but positive, and it is then logically superfluous, serving merely to make the assertion less abrupt: as, I guess I will go now (that is, I am going now); I guess I know what I'm about (that is, I know what I am doing). In most instances this use probably arises from a desire to avoid positive assertion, or from some feeling of hesitation or uncertainty.] Synonyms Imagine, Presume , etc. See conjecture .

and

manage, control, pilot, steer. Guide implies that the person guiding accompanies or precedes, while direct need not mean more than that he gives instructions, which may be from a distance. The figurative uses of these words are not far from the same meanings. Direct may imply that we must reflect and exercise judgment, guide that we trustingly follow where we are led; but direct also means to exercise absolute authority: as, he directed all the movements of the army by telegraph from the seat of government. Sway in this connection is used of some influence, often bad and always strong, which turns us aside from what otherwise might have been our course, and in this sense is nearly equal to bias. (See comparison under authority. ) We are guided or directed by principle or reason, or by a real friend, and swayed by our passions or feelings, or by unwise or unworthy associates.
plural In an engine, the rods on which, or the surfaces between which, the cross-head of the piston slides: usually called cross-head guides .

guild.explanation: An association of persons of the same trade or pursuits, formed to protect mutual interests and maintain standards.

A group of species in a community that use similar environmental resources in a similar way, such as a group of songbirds that all glean insects from leaves.

An association of men belonging to the same class, or engaged in kindred pursuits, formed for mutual aid and protection; a business fraternity or corporation. They were originally licensed by the government, and endowed with special privileges and authority.
A religious association or society, organized for charitable purposes or for assistance in parish work.
A group of tradespeople made up of merchants , craftspeople , or artisans , particularly in the Middle Ages
A group of diverse species that share common characteristics or habits
a formal association of people with similar interests

guilder.explanation: The primary unit of currency in the Netherlands before the adoption of the euro.
A gold coin formerly current in the Netherlands and in Germany.
Now, a Dutch silver coin of the value of 1 s. 8 d. English, or about 40 cents. Also called gulden and florin.
A Dutch silver coin worth about forty cents; -- called also florin and gulden .
The former currency unit in the Netherlands , divided into 100 cents .
The former currency unit in Suriname , divided into 100 cents .
The current currency unit in the islands in the former Netherlands Antilles , divided into 100 cents .
the basic unit of money in Suriname; equal to 100 cents
formerly the basic unit of money in the Netherlands; equal to 100 cents

guildhall.explanation: The meeting hall of a guild.
The hall where a guild or corporation usually assembles; a townhall.
A hall where a guild or corporation usually assembles .
the hall of a guild or corporation

guildite.explanation: A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing copper , hydrogen , iron , oxygen , and sulfur .

guile.explanation: The fermented wort used by vinegar-makers.
Disposition to deceive or cheat; insidious artifice; craft; cunning.
Craft; deceitful cunning; artifice; duplicity; wile; deceit; treachery.
To disguise or conceal; to deceive or delude.
astuteness often marked by a certain sense of cunning or artful deception .
the use of tricks to deceive someone (usually to extract money from them)
shrewdness as demonstrated by being skilled in deception

guiled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of guile .

guileful.explanation: Full of guile; deceitfully or treacherously cunning.
Full of guile; characterized by cunning, deceit, or treachery; guilty.

guilefulness.explanation: The state or quality of being guileful; deceitfulness.
The quality of being guileful ; cunning or deceit .

guileless.explanation: Free of guile; artless. synonym : naive .
Truthful, candid, unsophisticated, open, frank, ingenuous, straightforward.
Free from guile ; honest but naïve .

guilelessness.explanation: The state or quality of being guileless; freedom from deceit or dishonesty.
The characteristic of being guileless ; honesty .

guiler.explanation: One who betrays by deceit and art; a beguiler.
A deceiver; one who deludes, or uses guile.

guiles.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of guile .

guilfat.explanation: A wort-tub; the tub in which liquor ferments.

guillemet.explanation: Either of a pair of punctuation marks («) or (») used in some languages, such as French and Russian, to mark the beginning and end of a quotation.
Either of the punctuation marks « or » , used in several languages to indicate passages of speech . Similar to typical quotation marks used in the English language such as “ and ” .

guillemot.explanation: Any of several auks of the genus Cepphus of the northern Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, having black plumage with white markings.
A bird of the genus Uria of Brisson, or of either of the genera Uria and Lomvia of late authors; a murre.
One of several northern sea birds, allied to the auks. They have short legs, placed far back, and are expert divers and swimmers.
Any seabird belonging to the genera Uria and Cepphus of the auk family Alcidae . They have black and white bodies and are good at swimming and diving.
small black or brown speckled auks of northern seas

guilloche.explanation: An ornamental border formed of two or more curved bands that interlace to repeat a circular design.

An ornamental pattern composed of intersecting curved lines, as the usual decoration of watch-cases; in architecture , an ornament in the form of two or more bands or ribbons interlacing or braided or twisted over each other so as to repeat the same figure in a continued series of spirals. The term is applied, but improperly, to a fret.
An ornament in the form of two or more bands or strings twisted over each other in a continued series, leaving circular openings which are filled with round ornaments.
In ornamental art, any pattern made by interlacing curved lines.
A fine engraving pattern of spirals, intertwining bands, etc.; or the tool used to create such work.
an architectural decoration formed by two intersecting wavy bands

guillotine.explanation: A device consisting of a heavy blade held aloft between upright guides and dropped to behead a person condemned to die.
An instrument, such as a paper cutter, similar in action to a guillotine.
To cut with a guillotine or sharp blade.
A machine for breaking iron by means of a falling weight.

A machine used in France for beheading condemned persons by the action of a heavily weighted, oblique-edged knife falling between two grooved posts upon the neck of the victim, whose head protrudes through a circular hole in a divided plank.
One of several machines similar in principle to the above, much used for cutting paper, straw, etc. Also called guillotine cutter .
In surgery , an instrument for cutting the tonsils.
A machine for beheading a person by one stroke of a heavy ax or blade, which slides in vertical guides, is raised by a cord, and let fall upon the neck of the victim.
Any machine or instrument for cutting or shearing, resembling in its action a guillotine.
A machine used for the application of capital punishment by decapitation , consisting of a tall upright frame from which is suspended a heavy diagonal -edged blade .
A device used for cutting stacks of paper to straight edges, usually by means of a hinged blade attached to a flat platform .
A cloture ; a motion that debate be ended and a vote taken.
To execute, cut or cut short (a person, a stack of paper or a debate) by use of a guillotine.
closure imposed on the debate of specific sections of a bill
instrument of execution that consists of a weighted blade between two vertical poles; used for beheading people
kill by cutting the head off with a guillotine

guillotined.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of guillotine .

guillotinement.explanation: Decapitation by means of the guillotine.

guillotines.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of guillotine .

guilt.explanation: The fact of being responsible for the commission of an offense; moral culpability. synonym : blame .
The fact of having been found to have violated a criminal law; legal culpability.
Responsibility for a mistake or error.
Remorseful awareness of having done something wrong.
Self-reproach for supposed inadequacy or wrongdoing.
To make or try to make (someone) feel guilty.
gilt .
A fault; an offense; a guilty action; a crime.

That state of a moral agent which results from his commission of a crime or an offense wilfully or by consent; culpability arising from conscious violation of moral or penal law, either by positive act or by neglect of known duty; criminality; wickedness.
Technical or constructive criminality; exposure to forfeiture or other penalty.

The criminality and consequent exposure to punishment resulting from willful disobedience of law, or from morally wrong action; the state of one who has broken a moral or political law; crime; criminality; offense against right.
Exposure to any legal penalty or forfeiture.
A feeling of regret or remorse for having committed some improper act; a recognition of one's own responsibility for doing something wrong.
To commit offenses; act criminally.
To cause someone to feel guilt, particularly in order to influence their behaviour.
Responsibility for wrongdoing .
Awareness of having done wrong.
The fact of having done wrong.
The state of having been found guilty or admitted guilt in legal proceedings.
the state of having committed an offense
remorse caused by feeling responsible for some offense

guiltier.explanation: comparative form of guilty : more guilty

guiltiest.explanation: superlative form of guilty : most guilty .

guiltily.explanation: In a guilty manner; as if guilty
in the manner of someone who has committed an offense

guiltiness.explanation: The state or quality of being guilty; criminality; wickedness: as, the guiltiness of a purpose or an act.
The quality or state of being guilty.
The state of being guilty ; guilt .
the state of having committed an offense

guiltlessness.explanation: The state or quality of being guiltless; innocence.

guilts.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of guilt .

guilty.explanation: Responsible for a reprehensible act; culpable.
Found to have violated a criminal law by a jury or judge.
Deserving blame, as for an error.
Suffering from or prompted by a sense of guilt.
Suggesting or entailing guilt.
guilty deed; a guilty intent.
of.

Evincing or indicating guilt; involving guilt

Condemned to payment.
Responsible for a dishonest act .
Judged to have committed a crime .
Having a sense of guilt
Blameworthy .
A plea by a defendant who does not contest a charge .
A verdict of a judge or jury on a defendant judged to have committed a crime.
One who is declared guilty of a crime.

responsible for or chargeable with a reprehensible act

guimpe.explanation: A blouse worn under a jumper.
A yoke insert for a low-necked dress.
A starched cloth covering the neck and shoulders as part of a nun's habit.
A chemisette worn with a low or square-necked dress.
A kind of short blouse or chemisette, worn under a low-necked dress such as a jumper or pinafore.
a piece of starched cloth covering the shoulders of a nun's habit.
Gimp ; a narrow flat braid or reinforced cord of fabric used for ornamental trimming.
A kind of short, high-necked blouse with sleeves of the late Victorian era, designed to be worn under a low-cut dress, jumper , or pinafore dress.
A kind of short chemisette or yoke insert made of lace , embroidery , or the like, worn with a low-necked dress.
A wimple ; a wide, stiffly starched cloth that covers the neck and shoulders, as part of the habit of nuns of certain orders.
a piece of starched cloth covering the shoulders of a nun's habit
a short blouse with sleeves that is worn under a jumper or pinafore dress

guinea.explanation: A gold coin issued in England from 1663 to 1813 and worth one pound and one shilling.
The sum of one pound and one shilling.
Used as a disparaging term for a person of Italian birth or descent.
An Italian.
An English gold coin, of the value of 21 shillings, first issued by Charles II. in 1663, and by his successors till 1813, since which year it has not been coined.
A money of account, of the value of 21 shillings, still often used in English reckonings.
A guinea-fowl.
A district on the west coast of Africa (formerly noted for its export of gold and slaves) after which the Guinea fowl , Guinea grass , Guinea peach , etc., are named.
A gold coin of England current for twenty-one shillings sterling, or about five dollars, but not coined since the issue of sovereigns in 1817.
See Durra .
a current in the Atlantic Ocean setting southwardly into the Bay of Benin on the coast of Guinea.
one who cheats by dropping counterfeit guineas.

an African gallinaceous bird, of the genus Numida, allied to the pheasants. The common domesticated species ( Numida meleagris ), has a colored fleshy horn on each aide of the head, and is of a dark gray color, variegated with small white spots. The crested Guinea fowl ( Numida cristata ) is a finer species.
grains of Paradise, or amomum. See Amomum .
a tall strong forage grass ( Panicum jumentorum ) introduced. from Africa into the West Indies and Southern United States.
a liliaceous flower ( Fritillaria Meleagris ) with petals spotted like the feathers of the Guinea hen.
See under Peach .
the pods of the Xylopia aromatica , a tree of the order Anonaceæ, found in tropical West Africa. They are also sold under the name of Piper Æthiopicum .

the fruit of Parinarium excelsum , a large West African tree of the order Chrysobalaneæ, having a scarcely edible fruit somewhat resembling a plum, which is also called gray plum and rough-skin plum .
a long and slender African nematoid worm ( Filaria Medinensis ) of a white color. It lives in the cellular tissue of man, beneath the skin, and produces painful sores.
A person of Italian descent.

A gold coin originally worth twenty shillings and originally made from gold imported from Africa; later (from 1717 until the adoption of decimal currency ) standardised at a value of twenty-one shillings.
A ground- foraging bird of Africa, of the family Numididea. Domesticated strains include Pearl, White, Buff, Blue, Purple and Lavender. Also called guinea fowl .
(ethnic slur) offensive term for a person of Italian descent
a republic in western Africa on the Atlantic; formerly a French colony; achieved independence from France in 1958
a west African bird having dark plumage mottled with white; native to Africa but raised for food in many parts of the world
a former British gold coin worth 21 shillings

guineaman.explanation: ; pl. Guineamen (-men). A ship used in trading to the coast of Guinea.

guipure.explanation: A coarse large-patterned lace without a net background.
Originally, a lace made of cords of a certain stoutness, each composed of several threads laid side by side, or of a strip of stuff or of parchment (see cartisane ), and wound completely with thread.

A term used for lace of different kinds; most properly for a lace of large pattern and heavy material which has no ground or mesh, but has the pattern held together by connecting threads called bars or brides .

guiro.explanation: A Latin American percussion instrument made of a hollow gourd with a grooved or serrated surface, played by scraping with a stick or rod.
A musical instrument made of a hollow gourd with parallel notches cut in one side, and played by rubbing a stick or scraper (" pua ") along the notches to produce a ratchet-like sound.

guisarme.explanation: A long-handled weapon resembling the pole-ax, or in some cases more nearly resembling the halberd, but having a long edge for cutting and a straight sharp point in the line of the handle. By some authors it is confounded with the pole-ax.

guise.explanation: Way; manner; mode; fashion; practice; custom.
Manner of acting; mien; cast or behavior.
External appearance as determined by costume; dress; garb: as, the guise of a shepherd.
Hence Appearance or semblance in general; aspect or seeming.
Customary way of speaking or acting; custom; fashion; manner; behavior; mien; mode; practice; -- often used formerly in such phrases as: .
External appearance in manner or dress; appropriate indication or expression; garb; shape.
Customary way of speaking or acting; fashion , manner , practice (often used formerly in such phrases as "at his own guise"; that is, in his own fashion, to suit himself.)
External appearance in manner or dress; appropriate indication or expression; garb; shape.

guiser.explanation: One who goes from house to house whimsically disguised, and making diversion with songs and antics, usually at Christmas; a masker; a mummer.
A person in disguise; a masker; a mummer.

guitar.explanation: A musical instrument having a flat-backed rounded body that narrows in the middle, a long fretted neck, and usually six strings, played by strumming or plucking.

A musical instrument of the lute class, having usually six strings (three of catgut and three of silk wound with fine silver wire), stretched over a violin-shaped body, and a long neck and finger-board combined.
A stringed instrument of music resembling the lute or the violin, but larger, and having six strings, three of silk covered with silver wire, and three of catgut, -- played upon with the fingers.
A stringed musical instrument , usually with fretted fingerboard and 6 strings, played with the fingers or a plectrum (guitar pick).
a stringed instrument usually having six strings; played by strumming or plucking

guitarfish.explanation: Any of various marine cartilaginous fishes chiefly of the family Rhinobatidae, having a flattened guitar-shaped body, with the pectoral fins fused to the sides of the head.
A shark-like ray of the family Rhinobatidæ , inhabiting warm seas; specifically, Rhinobatus productus.
A primitive tropical bottom-dwelling ray of the family Rhinobatidae with a guitar-shaped body.
Any of the fish in the Rhinobatidae family of rays .
primitive tropical bottom-dwelling ray with a guitar-shaped body

guitarist.explanation: a musician who plays the guitar.
A person who plays or performs on the guitar .
a musician who plays the guitar

guitermanite.explanation: A sulphid of arsenic and lead occurring in masses of a bluish-gray color and metallic luster, found at the Zuñi mine near Silverton, Colorado.

guitguit.explanation: An American bird of the family Cærebidæ.
One of several species of small tropical American birds of the family Cœrebidæ , allied to the creepers; -- called also quit . See quit .
One of several species of small tropical American birds of the family Coerebidae , allied to the creepers .

gujerat.explanation: an industrialized state in western India that includes parts of Bombay

gul.explanation: A stylized octagonal motif in Oriental rugs.

gula.explanation: In architecture , a molding, more commonly called cyma reversa or ogee. See cyma , 1.

In ornithology , the upper part of the throat of a bird, between the mentum and the jugulum. See cut under bird .
The upper front of the neck, next to the chin; the upper throat.

gulden.explanation: One of several gold coins formerly current in Germany from the fourteenth century, and in the Low Countries from the fifteenth century: the name was afterward applied to silver coins of Germany and the Netherlands.

gules.explanation: The color red, indicated on a blazon by vertical lines.
In heraldry , the tincture red: in representations without color, as in drawing or engraving, it is indicated by vertical lines drawn close together.
The tincture red, indicated in seals and engraved figures of escutcheons by parallel vertical lines. Hence, used poetically for a red color or that which is red.
The blazoning term for red , e.g. on a coat of arms , typically represented in engraving by vertical parallel lines.
In blazon , of the colour red.

gulf.explanation: A large area of a sea or ocean partially enclosed by land, especially a long landlocked portion of sea opening through a strait.
A deep, wide chasm; an abyss.

gulgul.explanation: A sort of chunam or cement made of pounded sea-shells mixed with oil, which hardens like stone, and is used in India to cover ships' bottoms. It is impenetrable by worms even when unprotected by copper.

gum.explanation: Any of various viscous substances that are exuded by certain plants and trees and dry into water-soluble, noncrystalline, brittle solids.
A similar plant exudate, such as a resin.
Any of various adhesives made from such exudates or other sticky substance.
A substance resembling the viscous substance exuded by certain plants, as in stickiness.
Any of various trees, especially of the genera Eucalyptus and Liquidambar, that are sources of gum.
The wood of such a tree; gumwood.
Chewing gum.
To cover, smear, seal, fill, or fix in place with gum.
To exude or form gum.
To become sticky or clogged.
The firm connective tissue covered by mucous membrane that envelops the alveolar arches of the jaw and surrounds the bases of the teeth.
To chew (food) with toothless gums.
The sorrel-tree, Oxydendrum arboreum.
The cider-gum or cider-tree, Eucalyptus Gunnii.
The water-tupelo (which see).
The sweet gum, Liquidambar Styraciflua.
The black- or sour-gum, Nyssa syivatica.
gumming
gum up from disuse.

The soft tissues, consisting of a vascular mucous membrane, subjacent dense connective tissue, and periosteum, which cover the alveolar parts of the upper and lower jaws and envelop the necks of the teeth.

Hence The edge of the jaw; the part of one of the jaws in which the teeth are set, or over which the tissues close after the loss of teeth: generally used in the plural: as, the toothless gums of old age.
plural The grinders; molars.
Insolent talk; “jaw”; insolence.
Same as gummer .
A product of secretion obtained by desiccation from the sap of many plants.
A form of dextrine produced by roasting starch: specifically called artificial or British gum.
One of various species of trees, especially of the genera Eucalyptus , of Australia, and Nyssa , of the United States.
Same as gumming
A bubble; a pimple. Compare red-gum, white-gum.
plural India-rubber overshoes: more commonly called rubbers .
A section of a hollow log or tree (usually a gum-tree) used to form a small well-curb, or to make a beehive. —
To deepen and enlarge the spaces between the teeth of (a worn saw). See gummer .
The dense tissues which invest the teeth, and cover the adjacent parts of the jaws.
strophulus in a teething child; red gum.
a smooth hard substance for children to bite upon while teething.
To smear with gum; to close with gum; to unite or stiffen by gum or a gumlike substance; to make sticky with a gumlike substance.
To chew with the gums, rather than with the teeth.
to interfere with; to spoil.
To exude or form gum; to become gummy.
A vegetable secretion of many trees or plants that hardens when it exudes, but is soluble in water. Also, with less propriety, exudations that are not soluble in water.
See Gum tree , below .
A hive made of a section of a hollow gum tree; hence, any roughly made hive; also, a vessel or bin made of a hollow log.
A rubber overshoe.
See under Black , Blue , etc.

gumbo.explanation: A soup or stew thickened with okra pods.
A fine silty soil, common in the southern and western United States, that forms an unusually sticky mud when wet.

The pod of Hibiscus esculentus , also called okra .
A soup, usually of chicken, thickened with okra.
A dish made of young capsules of okra, seasoned with salt and pepper, and stewed and served with melted butter.
A patois spoken by West Indian and Louisianian creoles and negroes.

A type of soil in the southern and western United States which forms a tough, dark-colored mass in a high degree plastic and clay-like, yet sometimes consisting chiefly of silt or very fine sand. It is very sticky and difficult to till when wet, and when dry breaks into hard cuboidal lumps. See gumbo clay .
A soup thickened with the mucilaginous pods of the okra; okra soup.
The okra plant or its pods.
The okra plant or its pods.
A soup or stew made with okra .
A fine silty soil that when wet becomes very thick and heavy.
any of various fine-grained silty soils that become waxy and very sticky mud when saturated with water
long mucilaginous green pods; may be simmered or sauteed but used especially in soups and stews
a soup or stew thickened with okra pods

tall coarse annual of Old World tropics widely cultivated in southern United States and West Indies for its long mucilaginous green pods used as basis for soups and stews; sometimes placed in genus Hibiscus

gumboil.explanation: A small boil or abscess on the gum, often resulting from tooth decay.

A small suppurating inflamed spot on the gum .

gumby.explanation: A kind of drum used by the negroes of the West Indies, made of a piece of a hollow tree, about 6 feet long, over which a skin is stretched. It is carried by one man while another beats it with his open hands.

gumdrop.explanation: A small candy made of sweetened, colored, and flavored gum arabic or gelatin and often coated with sugar.

a jellied candy coated with sugar crystals

gumi.explanation: The Japanese name of Elæagnus longipes , a bush that is now cultivated in the United States, prized both for its ornamental character and for the edible cranberry-like fruits.

gumma.explanation: A small rubbery granuloma that has a necrotic center and is enclosed by an inflamed fibrous capsule. It is characteristic of an advanced stage of syphilis.

A kind of soft tumor, usually of syphilitic origin.
a soft, non-cancerous growth , a form of granuloma , resulting from the tertiary stage of syphilis .
a small rubbery granuloma that is characteristic of an advanced stage of syphilis

gummatous.explanation: pathology , of the nature of a gumma or soft tumor.

gummed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gum .

gummer.explanation: A tool or machine for gulleting saws, or for enlarging the spaces between the teeth of worn saws.

A punch-cutting tool, or machine for deepening and enlarging the spaces between the teeth of a worn saw.
A punch-cutting tool , or machine for deepening and enlarging the spaces between the teeth of a worn saw.
To bring the ball up the field in a lacrosse game as a defensemen and either get an assist or score a goal.

gummers.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gummer .

gummier.explanation: comparative form of gummy : more gummy

gummite.explanation: An orange-red to grayish yellow mixture of several uranium oxides, silicates, and salts occurring naturally in the oxidation and hydration of uraninite.

a gummy orange mixture of uranium oxides and silicates occurring naturally in the hydration and oxidation of pitchblende

gummose.explanation: An unfermentable reducing sugar, produced by the hydrolysis of mucin.

gummosis.explanation: The pathological exudation of gum by a plant, such as a fruit tree, resulting from bacterial or fungal infection, insect infestation, or mechanical injury.
In botany , the formation of gum in the older organs of plants by the transformation of large groups of tissue, as in the production of cherry-gum and gum tragacanth.
An abnormal production and flow of gum from cracks or wounds of trees.
The formation of patches of a gummy substance on the surface of certain plants, particularly fruit trees , caused by sap oozing from wounds or cankers .
pathological production of gummy exudates in citrus and various stone-fruit trees
disease of citrus trees caused by the fungus Phytophthora citrophthora

gummosity.explanation: Gumminess; the nature of gum; a viscous or adhesive quality.
Gumminess; a viscous or adhesive quality or nature.
The quality of being gummy ; a viscous or adhesive quality.

gummous.explanation: Gumlike, or composed of gum; gummy.

gum -like, or composed of gum; gummy
Of or pertaining to a gumma .

gummy.explanation: Covered or clogged with or as if with gum.
Having the texture or properties of gum; sticky and viscid.
pathology , pertaining to or having the nature of a gumma; gummatous.

gumweed.explanation: Any of various plants of the genus Grindelia in the composite family, native to the Americas, having yellow, rayed flower heads and sticky leaves, stems, and bracts.
The gum-plant. Grindelia (which see; also Grindelia ).
A weed of the Great Plains, Lygodesmia juncea , of the Cichoriaceæ. It is a rigid, branching, skeleton-like plant with most of the leaves very small or reduced to scales.
any of various Western American plants of the genus Grindelia having resinous leaves and stems formerly used medicinally; often poisonous to livestock.
any of various western American plants of the genus Grindelia having resinous leaves and stems formerly used medicinally; often poisonous to livestock

gumwood.explanation: The wood of a gum tree, especially of a sweet gum.

wood or lumber from any of various gum trees especially the sweet gum.
wood or lumber from any of various gum trees especially the sweet gum

gun.explanation: A weapon consisting of a metal tube from which a projectile is fired at high velocity into a relatively flat trajectory, especially.
A portable firearm, such as a rifle or revolver.
A cannon with a long barrel and a relatively low angle of fire.
A device resembling a firearm or cannon, as in its ability to project something, such as grease or paint, under pressure or at great speed.
A discharge of a firearm or cannon as a signal or salute.
One who is armed with or skilled in the use of a gun.
The throttle of an engine, as of an automobile.
The biceps muscles of the arms.
To shoot (a person).
To open the throttle of (an engine) so as to accelerate.
To hunt with a gun.
( go great guns ) To proceed or perform with great speed, skill, or success.
( hold a gun to (someone's) head ) To put pressure on someone.
( under the gun ) Under great pressure or under threat.
gin .
forestry , to aim (a tree) in felling it.
A professional criminal; a thief; a pickpocket.
A military engine of the mangonel or catapult kind, used for throwing stones.

A metallic tube or tubular barrel, with its stock or carriage and attachments, from which missiles are thrown, as by the explosive force of gunpowder or other explosive placed behind them at the closed end of the tube, and ignited through a small hole or vent; in general, any firearm except the pistol and the mortar.
Specifically, a comparatively long cannon used for obtaining high velocities with low trajectories, as distinguished from a howitzer or a mortar.
In hunting , one who carries a gun; a member of a shooting-party.
A tall cylindrical jug in use in the north of England.
In plate glass manufacturing , a device for fixing the breadth of the plate.

Its principal peculiarities are the unbroken smoothness of its surface and the relation of its thickness at all points (determined by experiment) to the pressure in firing. Of all large smooth-bore guns, it is, not excepting the 15-inch Rodman gun, the most easily handled. The Dahlgren and Rodman 15-inch guns are equal as to accuracy and efficiency.
A person of distinction or importance: more commonly called a big gun.
A single-loading small-arm, caliber 0”.408, used in the Italian army.
A magazine bolt-gun used in the Italian and Swiss armies.
To practice fowling or hunting small game; -- chiefly in participial form.

A weapon which throws or propels a missile to a distance; any firearm or instrument for throwing projectiles, consisting of a tube or barrel closed at one end, in which the projectile is placed, with an explosive charge (such as guncotton or gunpowder) behind, which is ignited by various means. Pistols, rifles, carbines, muskets, and fowling pieces are smaller guns, for hand use, and are called small arms . Larger guns are called cannon , ordnance , fieldpieces , carronades , howitzers , etc. See these terms in the Vocabulary.
A piece of heavy ordnance; in a restricted sense, a cannon.
Violent blasts of wind.
a wrought iron breech-loading cannon named after its English inventor, Sir William Armstrong .
a person superior in any way.
the barrel or tube of a gun.
the carriage on which a gun is mounted or moved.

a general name for a series of explosive nitric ethers of cellulose, obtained by steeping cotton in nitric and sulphuric acids. Although there are formed substances containing nitric acid radicals, yet the results exactly resemble ordinary cotton in appearance. It burns without ash, with explosion if confined, but quietly and harmlessly if free and open, and in small quantity. Specifically, the lower nitrates of cellulose which are insoluble in ether and alcohol in distinction from the highest ( pyroxylin ) which is soluble. See Pyroxylin , and cf. Xyloidin . The gun cottons are used for blasting and somewhat in gunnery: for making celluloid when compounded with camphor; and the soluble variety ( pyroxylin ) for making collodion. See Celluloid , and Collodion . Gun cotton is frequenty but improperly called nitrocellulose . It is not a nitro compound, but an ester of nitric acid.
See under Deck .
the time at which the morning or the evening gun is fired.
a bronze, ordinarily composed of nine parts of copper and one of tin, used for cannon, etc. The name is also given to certain strong mixtures of cast iron.
an opening in a ship through which a cannon's muzzle is run out for firing.
the blocks and pulleys affixed to the side of a ship, by which a gun carriage is run to and from the gun port.
a tackle composed of two single blocks and a fall.
a wrought steel breech-loading cannon, named after its German inventor, Herr Krupp.

a breech-loading gun or a group of such guns, mounted on a carriage or other holder, and having a reservoir containing cartridges which are loaded into the gun or guns and fired in rapid succession. In earlier models, such as the Gatling gun , the cartridges were loaded by machinery operated by turning a crank. In modern versions the loading of cartidges is accomplished by levers operated by the recoil of the explosion driving the bullet, or by the pressure of gas within the barrel. Several hundred shots can be fired in a minute by such weapons, with accurate aim. The Gatling gun , Gardner gun , Hotchkiss gun , and Nordenfelt gun , named for their inventors, and the French mitrailleuse , are machine guns .
to blow a gale. See Gun , n., 3.
A verb used to express future action.

guna.explanation: In the Sankhya philos. of India, one of the three constituents of the primal matter out of which the world is evolved. See the extract.

In Skt. gram. , the changing of i and ī to ē, u and ū to ō, ri and rī to ar , by compounding them with a prefixed â —that is, â + i = ē , and so on. The term is also sometimes used in regard to similar changes in other languages.
In Sanskrit grammar, a lengthening of the simple vowels a, i, e, by prefixing an a element. The term is sometimes used to denote the same vowel change in other languages.
A lengthening of the simple vowels a, i, e, by prefixing an a element , mainly in Sanskrit .

gunate.explanation: philology , to subject to the change known as guna.

gunation.explanation: In philology , the act of gunating, or the state of being gunated.

gunbearer.explanation: A servant who carries a hunter 's gun .

gunboat.explanation: A boat or small vessel fitted to carry one or more guns of large caliber, and from its light draft capable of running close inshore or up rivers; also, any small vessel carrying guns.

A vessel of light draught, carrying one or more guns, used for operations in shallow waters.

Any of various types of small armed vessel
a small shallow-draft boat carrying mounted guns; used by costal patrols

a nitric acid ester; used in lacquers and explosives

gunning.explanation: The art or practice of shooting with guns; especially, the sport or pursuit of shooting game.

Synonyms Gunning, Hunting, Shooting. In the United States these terms are loosely used as interchangeable; more strictly, gunning and shooting are confined to the pursuit of feathered and small game, and hunting to the pursuit of larger game. In England hunting means chasing foxes or stags with horse and hounds, or hares with beagles.

C. olitorius and C. capsularis ), of India. The fiber is also used in the manufacture of cordage.
crocus sack , croker sack , towsack , and grass sack .

gunpowder.explanation: Any of various explosive powders used to propel projectiles from guns, especially a black mixture of potassium nitrate, charcoal, and sulfur.
Picric-acid powders (these are not generally stable);

nitroglycerin and guncotton powders. The first two classes have practically been abandoned. Smokeless powders are designated from their appearance, the name of the inventor, or arbitrarily, as cordite, Peyton, poudre B. , etc.
An explosive mixture of saltpeter, sulphur, and charcoal, reduced to fine powder, and thoroughly incorporated with each other, then granulated, cleaned or dusted, glazed or polished, and dried.
A black, granular, explosive substance, consisting of an intimate mechanical mixture of saltpeter, charcoal, and sulphur. It is used in gunnery and blasting.
a pile driver, the hammer of which is thrown up by the explosion of gunpowder.

a plot to destroy the King, Lords, and Commons, in revenge for the penal laws against Catholics. As Guy Fawkes, the agent of the conspirators, was about to fire the mine, which was placed under the House of Lords, he was seized, Nov. 5, 1605. Hence, Nov. 5 is known in England as Guy Fawkes Day .
a species of fine green tea, each leaf of which is rolled into a small ball or pellet.

a mixture of potassium nitrate, charcoal, and sulfur in a 75:15:10 ratio which is used in gunnery, time fuses, and fireworks

gunreach.explanation: Gunshot; the distance a gun will carry.

Living quarters for junior officers and midshipmen on a warship (hence gunroom officers). In the past it was usually set in the forecastle .

Made by the shot of a gun: as. a gunshot wound.

the act of shooting a gun
