A man or young man; a fellow; -- usually contrasted with gals or girls .
A member of a group of either sex, usually a friend or comrade; -- usually used in the pl..
A guide; a leader or conductor.

A support rope or cable used to guide, steady or secure something which is being hoisted or lowered. Also a support to secure or steady something prone to shift its position or be carried away, e.g. the mast of a ship or a suspension-bridge.
To equip with a support cable.
An effigy of a man burned on a bonfire on the anniversary of the Gunpowder Plot (5th November).
A male
people
thing , creature
thing , unit
Buster , Mack , fella
To exhibit an effigy of Guy Fawkes around the 5th November.
To make fun of , to ridicule with wit or innuendo.
an informal term for a youth or man
subject to laughter or ridicule
steady or support with a guy wire or cable
an effigy of Guy Fawkes that is burned on a bonfire on Guy Fawkes Day
a cable, wire, or rope that is used to brace something (especially a tent)

guyed.explanation: Fitted with or attached to a guy .
Fitted to serve as a guy.

guyline.explanation: A rope or cable (a line ) used to restrain the motion of something. As a cable used to prevent a mast from falling over.

guyot.explanation: a seamount of volcanic origin (especially in the Pacific Ocean)

guys.explanation: A form of address for a group of male persons or a group of mixed male and female persons.

guz.explanation: A measure of length used in Hindustan and Arabia, equal to about 27 inches in Bombay, to 33 inches in Madras, to 36 inches in Bengal, to 38 inches in Mysore, to 25 inches at Mocha, and to 31.6 inches at Bagdad.

guze.explanation: In heraldry , a roundel, murrey or sanguine.
A roundlet of tincture sanguine , which is blazoned without mention of the tincture.
A roundlet of the sanguine tincture , which is blazoned without mention of the tincture.

guzzle.explanation: To drink, especially alcoholic beverages, greedily or habitually.
A drain or ditch; sometimes, a small stream. Also called a guzzen. Halliwell.
To swallow much or often; to swallow with immoderate gust; to drink greedily or continually.
To swallow liquor greedily; to drink much or frequently.
To drink (or, sometimes, eat) quickly , voraciously , or to excess ; to gulp down ; to swallow greedily , continually , or with gust .
To consume alcoholic beverages, especially frequently or habitually .
To consume anything quickly, greedily, or to excess, as if with insatiable thirst.
A drain or ditch ; a gutter ; sometimes, a small stream . Also called guzzen.
drink greedily or as if with great thirst

guzzler.explanation: One who guzzles; an immoderate drinker.
a drinker who swallows large amounts greedily
someone who drinks heavily (especially alcoholic beverages)

guzzles.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of guzzle .

guzzling.explanation: the drinking of large mouthfuls rapidly

gwiniad.explanation: A fish ( Coregonus ferus ) of North Wales and Northern Europe, allied to the lake whitefish; -- called also powan , and schelly .

gwyniad.explanation: The Coregonus pennanti , a kind of whitefish abundant in some of the Welsh lakes, in Ullswater, England, and in many lakes in Europe. It is gregarious, and may be taken in great numbers at a draft. Also guiniad . See whitefish and Coregonus.
A freshwater fish native to Bala Lake in Wales .

gyascutus.explanation: An imaginary animal, said to be of tremendous size, and to have both legs on one side of the body much shorter than those on the other, so as to be able to keep its balance in feeding on the side of a very steep mountain.
A genus of buprestid beetles, of western North America, having the mentum rounded in front and the first joint of the hind tarsi elongated. J. L. Le Conte , 1859. See cut on preceding page.

gybe.explanation: To shift from one side of a vessel to the other; -- said of the boom of a fore-and-aft sail when the vessel is steered off the wind until the sail fills on the opposite side.
To change tack with the wind crossing behind the boat. (Mostly used of boats and other small sailing craft — the corresponding manoeuver in a sailing ship is to wear .)
To shift a fore-and-aft sail suddenly and forcefully from one side to the other, while sailing before the wind. (also jibe .)
gybe at: to hesitate, vacillate, or balk when faced with a proposal, plan, or course of action. (Obsolete)
A sudden shift of a sail's angle, or a sudden change in the direction that a boat is sailing.
A sudden change in direction or approach; vacillation .
shift from one side of the ship to the other

gygis.explanation: A notable genus of small terns, of the subfamily Sterninæ.

gyle.explanation: Fermented wort used for making vinegar.
a large vat in which wort ferments.
Fermented wort used for making vinegar .

gym.explanation: A metal frame supporting equipment used in outdoor play.
A sports facility specialized for lifting weights and exercise .
athletic facility equipped for sports or physical training

gymkhana.explanation: Any of various meets at which contests are held to test the skill of the competitors, as in equestrianship, gymnastics, or sports car racing.
The place where such an event is held.
A competition where riders and horses display a range of skills and aptitudes .
a meet at which riders and horses display a range of skills and aptitudes

gymnadenia.explanation: small genus of terrestrial orchids of North America and temperate Eurasia

gymnadeniopsis.explanation: A genus of North American terrestrial orchids usually included in the genus Habenaria.
genus of North American terrestrial orchids usually included in genus Habenaria

gymnanthous.explanation: botany , having naked flowers, from which both calyx and corolla are wanting.

gymnarchus.explanation: A Cuvierian genus of fishes, the type of the family Gymnarchidæ. G. niloticus , the only species, inhabits tropical African rivers, attaining a length of 6 feet.

gymnasial.explanation: gymnasial teachers; a gymnasial plan of study.
Of or pertaining to an academic gymnasium .

gymnasiarch.explanation: In Greek history , a magistrate who superintended the gymnasia and certain public games.
An Athenian officer who superintended the gymnasia, and provided the oil and other necessaries at his own expense.
An Athenian officer who superintended the gymnasia and paid for the oil and other necessities.

gymnasiast.explanation: One who studies or has been educated at a gymnasium or classical school, as opposed to one who has attended a technical school.

gymnasium.explanation: A room or building equipped for indoor sports.
An academic high school in some central European countries, especially Germany, that prepares students for the university.
In Greek antiquity , a public place for instruction in and the practice of athletic exercises: a feature of all Greek communities.
Hence In modern use, a place where or a building in which athletic exercises are taught and performed.
A school or seminary for the higher branches of literature and science; a school preparatory to the universities, especially in Germany; a classical as opposed to a technical school.
A place or building where athletic exercises are performed; a school for gymnastics.
A school for the higher branches of literature and science; a preparatory school for the university; -- used esp. of German schools of this kind.
A large room or building for indoor sports .
A type of secondary school in some European countries which typically prepares students for university .
athletic facility equipped for sports or physical training
a school for students intermediate between elementary school and college; usually grades 9 to 12

gymnast.explanation: A person who is trained and skilled in gymnastics, especially one who engages in competition.
One who is skilled in athletic exercises; one who is expert in or is a teacher of gymnastics.
One who teaches or practices gymnastic exercises; the manager of a gymnasium; an athlete.
an athlete who is skilled in gymnastics

gymnastic.explanation: Disciplinary exercise for the intellect or character.
A teacher of gymnastics; a gymnast.

Pertaining to athletic exercises intended for health, defense, or diversion; -- originally said of games or exercises, as running, leaping, wrestling, throwing the discus, the javelin, etc.; in modern times more specifically applied to athletic exercises demonstrating balance and agility, such as tumbling, somersaulting, and bodily maneuvers performed on special equipment such as parallel bars or a balance beam
pertaining to disciplinary exercises for the intellect.
Pertaining to the gymnasia (ancient Greek schools).
of or relating to or used in exercises intended to develop strength and agility

gymnastics.explanation: Physical exercises designed to develop and display strength, balance, and agility, especially those performed on or with specialized apparatus.
The art or practice of such exercises.
Athletic or disciplinary exercises; the art of performing gymnastic exercises.
Disciplinary exercises for the intellect or character.
Feats demonstrating a quick mental agility.
A sport involving the performance of sequences of movements requiring physical strength , flexibility , and kinesthetic awareness .
Complex intellectual or artistic exercises or feats of physical agility .
a sport that involves exercises intended to display strength and balance and agility

gymnite.explanation: A mineral consisting of a hydrous silicate of magnesium: same as deweylite .

gymnoblastea.explanation: Anthomedusæ of Haeckel's later system, and commonly known as tubularian hydroids (in distinction from both campanularian and sertularian hydroids, which are calypto blastic).
The Athecata; -- so called because the medusoid buds are not inclosed in a capsule.

gymnoblastic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Gymnoblastea.
Of or pertaining to the Gymnoblastea.

gymnocalycium.explanation: large genus of low-growing globular South American cacti with spiny ribs covered with many tubercles

gymnocarpous.explanation: botany , having a naked fruit; especially, of lichens, having the apothecia expanded, saucer- or cup-shaped: applied to a large group of genera in which the apothecium is open and attached to the surface of the thallus.
Naked-fruited, the fruit either smooth or not adherent to the perianth.
Having fruit that is either smooth or not adherent to the perianth .

gymnocerata.explanation: Geocorisæ of Latreille: contrasted with Cryptocerata.

gymnoceratous.explanation: entomology , having prominent antennæ; specifically, having the characters of the Gymnocerata.

gymnocidium.explanation: In botany , the swelling occasionally found at the base of the spore-case in urn-mosses.

gymnocladus.explanation: A genus of leguminous trees, closely allied to the honeylocust ( Gleditschia ), and indigenous throughout the Ohio valley.
A genus of leguminous plants; the Kentucky coffee tree. The leaves are cathartic, and the seeds a substitute for coffee.
small genus of deciduous trees of China and United States having paniculate flowers and thick pulpy pods

gymnodont.explanation: A gymnodont fish; one of the Gymnodontidæ.

One of a group of plectognath fishes (Gymnodontes), having the teeth and jaws consolidated into one or two bony plates, on each jaw, as the diodonts and tetradonts. See bur fish , globefish , diodon .
One of a group of plectognath fishes (Gymnodontes), having the teeth and jaws consolidated into one or two bony plates on each jaw.

gymnogen.explanation: One of a class of plants, so called by Lindley, because the ovules are fertilized by direct contact of the pollen. Same as gymnosperm .

gymnogene.explanation: A book-name of an African hawk, Polyboroides typicus or P. capensis.

gymnogenous.explanation: ornithology , naked when hatched, as most altricial birds; psilopædic: opposed to hesthogenous or ptilopædic.

gymnoglossa.explanation: A division of gastropods in which the odontophore is without teeth.

gymnoglossate.explanation: Any gastropod of the group Gymnoglossa.

gymnolaema.explanation: An order of Bryozoa, having no epistome.

gymnonoti.explanation: The order of fishes which includes the Gymnotus or electrical eel. The dorsal fin is wanting.

gymnopaedic.explanation: Having young that are naked when hatched; psilopædic; -- said of certain birds.
Having young that are naked when hatched ; psilopaedic .

gymnophiona.explanation: Amphibia , having a serpentiform body, no limbs, the tail obsolete in the adult, the anus terminal, and numerous minute dermal scutes in the integument of the body. The division includes only the family Cæciliidæ , and the term is a synonym of Ophiomorpha.
An order of Amphibia, having a long, annulated, snakelike body. See ophiomorpha .
an order of amphibians including caecilians

gymnophobia.explanation: political or religious organizations or viewpoints that are concerned with discouraging nudity.

gymnoplast.explanation: A naked protoplasmic mass, that is, one without an inclosing wall or membrane.
A cell or mass of protoplasm devoid of an envelope, as a white blood corpuscle.
A cell or mass of protoplasm devoid of an envelope , such as a white blood corpuscle .

gymnorhinal.explanation: ornithology , having naked nostrils: having the nostrils un-feathered: an epithet of sundry birds, especially of certain jays and auks, which are distinguished by this circumstance in their respective families, in which the nostrils are usually feathered.
Having unfeathered nostrils, as certain birds.

gymnosophist.explanation: One of an ancient sect of Hindu ascetics who wore little or no clothing and were devoted to mystical contemplation.

One of a sect of ancient Hindu philosophers who lived solitarily in the woods, wore little clothing, ate no flesh, renounced all bodily pleasures, and addicted themselves to mystical contemplation: so called by Greek writers.

One of a sect of philosophers, said to have been found in India by Alexander the Great, who went almost naked, denied themselves the use of flesh, renounced bodily pleasures, and employed themselves in the contemplation of nature.
One of a school of ancient Indian ascetic philosophers , reported in antiquity, who wore little clothing; a mystic .
member of a Hindu sect practicing gymnosophy (especially nudism)

gymnosophy.explanation: The doctrines and practices of the Gymnosophists.
The wisdom or accumulated knowledge and experience of the lifestyle of being nude . It encompasses naturism and nudism .
the doctrine of a sect of Hindu philosophers who practiced nudity and asceticism and meditation

gymnosperm.explanation: A vascular plant, such as a cycad or conifer, whose seeds are not enclosed within an ovary.
A plant belonging to the Gymnospermæ , characterized by naked seeds. Compare angiosperm . Also called gymnogen .
A plant that bears naked seeds (i. e., seeds not inclosed in an ovary), as the common pine and hemlock. Cf. angiosperm .
Any plant such as a conifer whose seeds are not enclosed in an ovary .
plants of the class Gymnospermae having seeds not enclosed in an ovary

gymnospermae.explanation: plants having naked seeds not enclosed in an ovary; in some systems considered a class (Gymnospermae) and in others a division (Gymnospermophyta); comprises three subdivisions (or classes): Cycadophytina (class Cycadopsida) and Gnetophytina (class Gnetopsida) and Coniferophytina (class Coniferopsida); in some classifications the Coniferophytina are divided into three groups: Pinophytina (class Pinopsida) and Ginkgophytina (class Ginkgopsida) and Taxophytina (class Taxopsida)

gymnospermous.explanation: botany , of, pertaining to, or resembling the Gymnospermæ; having naked seeds: opposed to angiospermous. Also gymnogenous .
Having naked seeds, or seeds not inclosed in a capsule or other vessel.
Belonging to the class of plants consisting of gymnosperms.
Having seeds that are not protected in a capsule
Of or pertaining to a gymnosperm
relating to or characteristic of plants of the class Gymnospermae

gymnospermy.explanation: In botany , the state or character of being gymnospermous.

gymnosporangium.explanation: A genus of fungi, of the order Uredineæ , having mostly two-celled (sometimes one- to six-celled) yellow or orange spores borne on slender pedicels, and embedded in jelly, which when moistened swells into columnar or irregularly expanded masses.
genus of fungi that produce galls on cedars and other conifers of genera Juniperus and Libocedrus and causes rust spots on apples and pears and other plants of family Rosaceae

gymnospore.explanation: A naked spore; a spore without a protecting investment: opposed to chlamydospore.
Specifically, in botany , a spore that is naked in the sense of not being produced in a sporangium.

In the classification of Le Maout and Decaisne, a cellular cryptogamic plant in which the spores, by absorption of the mother-cell, become free in a common cavity. Their group Gymnospores is coextensive with the Bryophyta. No longer used.
A type of spore that does not have a protective envelope , especially one not produced in a sporangium

gymnostomata.explanation: Ciliata in which the mouth is usually closed except during the inception of food, and is without an undulating membrane.

gymnostomous.explanation: botany , having no peristome: applied to the capsule of mosses.

gymnothorax.explanation: A genus of morays or eels, of the family Murænidæ , comprising many of the largest and most ferocious members of the group.

gymnotid.explanation: A fish of the family Gymnotidæ.

gymnotus.explanation: A fish of the genus Gymnotus.
In entomology , a genus of curculios, based on the Brazilian G. geometricus , the Cholus geometricus of Germar.
A genus of South American fresh-water fishes, including the Gymnotus electricus , or electric eel. It has a greenish, eel-like body, and is possessed of electric power.
Any of the genus Gymnotus of electric knifefishes.

gymnura.explanation: A genus of insectivorous mammals, typical of the subfamily Gymnurinæ.

gymnure.explanation: An animal of the genus Gymnura.
A type of carnivorous mammal, related to the moles and resembling large rats , which inhabits various parts of south-east Asia.

gymslip.explanation: A sleeveless tunic with a pleated skirt most commonly seen as part of a girl's school uniform .
a sleeveless tunic worn by English girls as part of a school uniform

gynaecea.explanation: Plural form of gynaeceum .. Alternative form of gynæcea .

gynaeceum.explanation: In some countries, that part of a Christian church which is reserved for the women of the congregation.

Among the ancients, the part of a dwelling of the better class devoted to the use of women—generally the remotest part, lying beyond an interior court; hence, in occasional use, a similar division of any house or establishment where the sexes are separated, as a Mohammedan harem. Also gyneconitis .
A manufactory or establishment in ancient Rome for making clothes and furniture for the emperor's family, the managers of which were women.
That part of a large house, among the ancients, exclusively appropriated to women.

gynaecological.explanation: Of or pertaining to gynecology; same as gynecological .
of or relating to or practicing gynecology

gynaecologist.explanation: A physician who specialises in diseases of the female reproductive system .

gynaecology.explanation: The branch of medicine that deals with the diseases and hygiene of women; same as gynecology .
the branch of medicine that deals with the diseases and hygiene of women

gynaecomastia.explanation: Excessive development of breasts in males , resembling the breast development in women.

gynaecomasty.explanation: The condition of a man developing breasts of a size and functionality of a woman's.

gynander.explanation: A plant belonging to the class Gynandria.
A plant having the stamens inserted in the pistil.
A plant having the stamens inserted in the pistil .

gynandria.explanation: A class of plants in the Linnæan system, whose stamens grow out of, or are united with, the pistil.

gynandrian.explanation: Having stamens inserted in the pistil; belonging to the class Gynandria.
gynandrous ; belonging to the class Gynandria

gynandrism.explanation: The state of being monoecious or hermaphrodite.

gynandromorph.explanation: An organism having both male and female characteristics, especially an insect exhibiting a mixture of male and female tissues or sex organs.
In biology , an animal of a unisexual species but exhibiting the anomaly of having part of the body male and part female. Gynandromorphs are most frequently found among insects.
An insect or crustacean literally having physical characteristics of both genders , usually displaying a bilateral difference.
A person having certain physical characteristics of both genders .
one having both male and female sexual characteristics and organs; at birth an unambiguous assignment of male or female cannot be made

gynandromorphic.explanation: having both male and female morphological characteristics

gynandromorphism.explanation: In entomology , a variation or monstrosity in which the peculiar characters of the male and female are found in the same individual.
An abnormal condition of certain animals, in which one side has the external characters of the male, and the other those of the female.
The condition of being a gynandromorph .

gynandromorphous.explanation: entomology , having both male and female characters: applied to certain rare individuals among insects which by their forms and markings are apparently female in one part of the body and male in another.
having both male and female morphological characteristics

gynandrophore.explanation: A gynophore which bears the stamens as well as the pistil, as in some Capparidaceæ. See cut under gynophore .

gynandrosporous.explanation: Œdogonieæ , among algæ, provided with male individuals which attach themselves to or near the oögonium.

gynandrous.explanation: botany , having the stamens adnate to and apparently borne upon the pistil, as in Asclepias, Aristolochia , and all orchids.
Having stamens and pistils together in a column.
Exhibiting characteristics of both feminine and masculine . Both denotational synonym and connotational antonym of androgynous.

gynantherous.explanation: botany , having stamens converted into pistils.
Pertaining to an abnormal condition of the flower, in which the stamens are converted into pistils.
Pertaining to an abnormal condition of the flower , in which the stamens are converted into pistils .

gynarchy.explanation: Government by a woman or by women; the rule of women. Formerly also written gunarchy .
A government ruled by a woman or women.
a political system governed by a woman

gyne.explanation: A female social insect that is or has the potential to become a reproductive queen, in contrast to a sterile worker.
The primary reproductive female caste of social insects (especially ants , wasps , and bees ), those destined to become queens .

gynecic.explanation: medicine and surgery , pertaining to diseases peculiar to women.

gynecocracy.explanation: Government by a woman or by women; female power or rule.
Government by a woman, female power; gyneocracy.
a political system governed by a woman

gynecocrat.explanation: One who favors or upholds female government.

gynecologic.explanation: of or relating to or practicing gynecology

gynecological.explanation: of or relating to or practicing gynecology

gynecologist.explanation: One versed in, or engaged in the study and practice of, gynecology.
A physician specializing in diseases of the female reproductive system .

gynecology.explanation: The branch of medicine dealing with health care for women, especially the diagnosis and treatment of disorders affecting the female reproductive system.
In medicine and surgery , the science of the diseases peculiar to women.
The science which treats of the structure and diseases of women.
The study of, or the branch of medicine specializing in, the medical problems of women , especially disorders or the reproductive organs .
the branch of medicine that deals with the diseases and hygiene of women

gynecomastia.explanation: Abnormal enlargement of the breasts in a male.
Excessive development of breasts in males , resembling the breast development in women.
excessive development of the breasts in males; usually the result of hormonal imbalance or treatment with certain drugs (including some antihypertensives)

gynecomasty.explanation: In physiology , the condition of a man having breasts as large as those of a woman, and functionally active.
The condition of a man developing breasts of a size and functionality of a woman's.

gynecomorphous.explanation: biology , having the form, attributes, or appearance of a female.
Resembling a female in shape, attributes or appearance.

gyneconitis.explanation: In the early ch. and in the Gr. Ch. , the part of the church occupied by women.

gynecopathy.explanation: Any of various diseases specific to women.

gynecophore.explanation: A receptacle in the body of the male of some animals, as the diœcious trematodes, in which the female is contained; the gynecophoric canal, or canalis gynæcophorus.

gynecophoric.explanation: zoology , pertaining to or of the nature of a gynecophore: applied to the canal of the male in certain Entozoa , as Bilharzia , in which the female lodges during copulation.

gynecophorous.explanation: gynecophorous worm; a gynecophorous canal. See gynecophore .

gyneolatry.explanation: Extravagant devotion to or worship of woman.
The adoration or worship of woman.
The adoration or worship of women .

gynephobia.explanation: Hatred of women; repugnance to the society of women.

gynerium.explanation: A small genus of tall perennial reedy grasses, of tropical and subtropical America, with very long leaves and large, dense, plume-like panicles. G. argenteum , the pampas-grass, is highly ornamental and frequently cultivated.

gynetype.explanation: In zoology , a female specimen taken as the type of a species.

gyniatrics.explanation: The treatment of diseases peculiar to women.

gynobase.explanation: In botany , a short conical or flat elevation of the receptacle of a flower, bearing the gynœcium
A dilated base or receptacle, supporting a multilocular ovary.
A dilated base or receptacle , supporting a multilocular ovary .
the enlarged receptacle in which the pistil is borne

gynobasic.explanation: botany , pertaining to or having a gynobase.—
Pertaining to, or having, a gynobase.
Pertaining to, or having, a gynobase .

gynodioecious.explanation: botany , having perfect and female flowers upon separate plants. See diœcious , 2.
Diœcious, but having some hermaphrodite or perfect flowers on an individual plant which bears mostly pistillate flowers.
dioecious , but having some hermaphrodite or perfect flowers on an individual plant which bears mostly pistillate flowers

gynoecium.explanation: The female reproductive organs of a flower; the pistil or pistils considered as a group.
The pistil or collective pistils of a flower; the female portion of a flower as a whole: correlative to andrœcium. Also gynœcium, gynœceum.
The pistils of a flower, taken collectively. See Illust. of carpophore .
The pistils of a flower considered as a group

gynogenesis.explanation: Parthenogenesis in which the egg is activated by sperm, but without fusion of the egg and sperm nuclei.
female parthenogenesis in which the embryo contains only maternal chromosomes due to the failure of the sperm to fuse with the egg nucleus
female parthenogenesis in which the embryo contains only maternal chromosomes due to the failure of the sperm to fuse with the egg nucleus

gynophore.explanation: A stalk that supports the pistil in certain plants.
In botany , an elongation or internode of the receptacle of a flower, bearing the gynœcium , as the stipe of a pod in some Cruciferæ and Capparidaceæ.

In Hydrozoa , the branch of a gonoblastidium which bears female gonophores, or those reproductive receptacles or generative buds which contain ova only, as distinguished from male gonophores or androphores. See cut under gonoblastidium .
The pedicel raising the pistil or ovary above the stamens, as in the passion flower.
One of the branches bearing the female gonophores, in certain Siphonophora.
the stalk of a pistil that raises it above the receptacle

gynostegium.explanation: In botany , a sheath or covering of the gynœcium, of whatever nature.
the crown of the stamen in plants of the genus Asclepias

gynostemium.explanation: The column of an orchid, consisting of the united style and stamens.

gynura.explanation: An untenable name for Crassocephalum , a genus of plants of the family Asteraceæ. See Crassocephalum .
genus of Old World tropical herbs: velvet plants

gyp.explanation: To deprive (another) of something by fraud; cheat or swindle.
A male servant who attends to college rooms. Also gip .
A swindler, especially a swindling horse-dealer; a cheat.
A college servant; -- so called in Cambridge, England; at Oxford called a scout .
A cheat or swindle ; a rip-off .
To cheat or swindle someone of something inappropriately .
a swindle in which you cheat at gambling or persuade a person to buy worthless property

gypaetus.explanation: in some classifications the type genus of the family Aegypiidae

gype.explanation: fool ; clumsy , awkward person; long-legged person; silly girl

gypped.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gyp .

gyps.explanation: The largest genus of old-world vultures, containing the several species known as griffins or griffin-vultures, having the nostrils oval and perpendicular, and the rectrices 14.

gypseous.explanation: Of, relating to, or containing gypsum.
Resembling or containing gypsum; partaking of the qualities of gypsum.

gypsine.explanation: The trade-name for a fire-proof material, for use in building, consisting of plastic hydraulic lime mixed with coke or sand and asbestos and pressed into blocks like bricks.
A dusting-powder containing arseniate of lead, applied to plants as an insecticide.

gypsiologist.explanation: One who studies the life and culture of gypsies .

gypsite.explanation: Gypsum in a finely granular form: a local name in Kansas and Texas, where this variety occurs.

gypsography.explanation: The art or practice of engraving, as inscriptions, upon natural gypsum in some one of its forms, as alabaster.
The art or practice of engraving on casts of plaster of Paris.
The act or art of engraving on gypsum.
The art or process of engraving on gypsum .

gypsophila.explanation: Any of various plants of the genus Gypsophila in the pink family, having small white or pink flowers and including baby's breath.
A genus of Caryophyllaceæ , allied to the pinks ( Dianthus ), of about 50 species, chiefly of the Mediterranean region.
Any of many flowering plants , of the genus Gypsophila , that have a profusion of small pink or white flowers
Mediterranean herbs having small white or pink flowers

gypsoplast.explanation: A cast taken in plaster of Paris, or in white lime.
A cast taken in plaster of Paris , or in white lime.

gypster.explanation: trickster , swindler , crook , racketeer , con (wo)man, impostor , fiddler , fraud , double-crosser

gypsum.explanation: A widespread colorless, white, or yellowish mineral, CaSO 4 · 2H 2 O, used in the manufacture of plaster of Paris, various plaster products, and fertilizers.
Native hydrous sulphate of calcium, a mineral usually of a white color, but also gray, yellow, red, and when impure brown or black.
A mineral consisting of the hydrous sulphate of lime (calcium). When calcined, it forms plaster of Paris. Selenite is a transparent, crystalline variety; alabaster , a fine, white, massive variety.
A mineral consisting of the hydrated calcium sulphate . When calcined , it forms plaster of Paris .
a common white or colorless mineral (hydrated calcium sulphate) used to make cements and plasters (especially plaster of Paris)

gypsy.explanation: Alternative form of Gypsy : a member of the Romani people.
An itinerant person or any person suspected of making a living from dishonest practices or theft; a member of a nomadic people , not necessarily Romani ; a carny .
Alternative form of Gypsy : of or belonging to the Romani people or one of it sub-groups ( Roma , Sinti , Romanichel, etc).
Of or having the qualities of an itinerant person or group with qualities traditionally ascribed to Romani people; making a living from dishonest practices or theft etc.
To roam around the country like a gypsy.

gypsyism.explanation: The arts and practices or habits of gypsies; deception; cheating; flattery.
The state of being a gypsy .
The practices or habits ascribed to gypsies, such as deception , cheating , and flattery .

gypsylike.explanation: Resembling or characteristic of a gypsy .

gypsyweed.explanation: A common hairy European perennial ( Veronica officinalis ) with pale blue or lilac flowers in axillary racemes.
common hairy European perennial with pale blue or lilac flowers in axillary racemes

gypsywort.explanation: A labiate plant (the Lycopus Europæus ). Gypsies are said to stain their skin with its juice.
hairy Eurasian herb with two-lipped white flowers

gyracanthus.explanation: A genus of fossil fishes, found in Devonian and carboniferous strata; -- so named from their round, sculptured spines.

gyral.explanation: Moving in a circle or spiral; gyratory.
Of or relating to a gyrus.
anatomy , pertaining to a gyrus or to the gyri of the brain.
Moving in a circular path or way; whirling; gyratory.
Pertaining to a gyrus, or convolution.
Of or pertaining to a gyrus
Moving circularly or spirally ; gyratory ; whirling .
relating to or associated with or comprising a convolution of the brain

gyrate.explanation: To revolve around a fixed point or axis.
To move in a spiral or spirallike course. synonym : turn .
To oscillate or vary, especially in a repetitious pattern.
botany , curved inward like a crozier; circinate.
zoology , having convolutions like the gyri of the brain; meandrine, as a coral. See cut under brain-coral .
Winding or coiled round; curved into a circle; taking a circular course.
To revolve round a central point; to move spirally about an axis, as a tornado; to revolve.
To revolve round a central point; to move spirally about an axis, as a tornado; to revolve.
revolve quickly and repeatedly around one's own axis
to wind or move in a spiral course

gyrated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gyrate .

gyrates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of gyrate .

gyration.explanation: An oscillation or varying between states.
A wheeling; whirling; revolution; a wheeling motion, like that of the moon round the earth.
Tn univalve shells, one of the whorls of the spire.
Any system of gyri or convolutions in the brain.
The act of turning or whirling, as around a fixed center; a circular or spiral motion; motion about an axis; rotation; revolution.
One of the whorls of a spiral univalve shell.
the distance between the axis of a rotating body and its center of gyration.
The act of turning or whirling , as around a fixed center; a circular or spiral motion; motion about an axis ; rotation ; revolution .
One of the whorls of a spiral univalve shell .
the act of rotating in a circle or spiral
a single complete turn (axial or orbital)

gyrational.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or caused by gyration

gyrator.explanation: An electric circuit that introduces a phase shift of 180° in one direction, but none in the opposite direction

gyratory.explanation: Having a circular or spiral motion.
Moving in a circle, or spirally; revolving; whirling around.
Moving in a circle , or spirally ; revolving; whirling around.
A large traffic roundabout with non-standard lane markings or priorities , or with buildings on the central island .

gyre.explanation: A circular or spiral motion or form, especially a circular ocean current.
A circle or ring; a revolution of a moving body; a circular or spiral turn.
In anatomy , a gyrus: as, a cerebral gyre.
A circular motion, or a circle described by a moving body; a turn or revolution; a circuit.
a circular current , especially a large-scale ocean current
a round shape formed by a series of concentric circles (as formed by leaves or flower petals)

gyred.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gyre .

gyrencephala.explanation: Cetacea, Sirenia, Hyracoidea, Proboscidea, Ungulata, Carnivora , and Quadrumana , having more or less numerous cerebral gyri, and the hemispheres of the cerebrum extending more or less over the cerebellum and olfactory lobes of the brain: distinguished from Archencephala, Lissencephala , and Lyencephala.
The higher orders of Mammalia, in which the cerebrum is convoluted.

gyrene.explanation: A member of the US Marine Corps.
A member of the United States Marine Corps.

gyrfalcon.explanation: A large black, gray, or white falcon (Falco rusticolus) that breeds in Arctic and subarctic regions and sometimes migrates to northern North America and Eurasia. It is highly valued in falconry.

One of several species and varieties of large Arctic falcons, esp. Falco rusticolus and the white species Falco Islandicus , both of which are circumpolar. The black and the gray are varieties of the former. See Illust. of accipiter .
Any large falcon , especially as used to fly at herons .
A large bird of prey that breeds on Arctic coasts and islands of North America , Europe and Asia .
large and rare Arctic falcon having white and dark color phases

gyrinus.explanation: A genus of water-beetles, typical of the family Gyrinidæ , having the scutellum distinct.

gyro.explanation: A style of Greek sandwich commonly filled with grilled meat , tomato , onions , and tzatziki sauce.

gyroceracone.explanation: A shell of a nautiloid cephalopod which is curved in a loose spiral like that of Gyroceras , the volutions being sometimes in contact but with no impressed zone.

gyroceras.explanation: The typical genus of Gyroceratidæ. Goldfuss. Also Gyroceratites, Gyrocerus.

gyrocompass.explanation: A compass with a motorized gyroscope whose angular momentum interacts with the force produced by the earth's rotation to maintain a north-south orientation of the gyroscopic spin axis, thereby providing a stable directional reference.
A north - seeking form of gyroscope used as a directional reference in navigation .
a compass that does not depend on magnetism but uses a gyroscope instead

gyrodactylus.explanation: The typical genus of trematode worms of the family Gyrodactylidæ. G. elegans is found in the gills of fishes.
An individual or a species of this genus.

gyrofrequency.explanation: The frequency of the circular motion of a charged particle in the presence of a uniform magnetic field .

gyrogonite.explanation: A petrified spiral seed-vessel of plants of the genus Chara , found in fresh-water deposits, and formerly supposed to be a shell.
The petrified fruit of the Chara hispida , a species of stonewort. See stonewort .
The petrified fruit of Chara hispida, a species of stonewort .

gyrograph.explanation: An instrument for registering the revolutions of a mechanism, such as a wheel.

gyroidal.explanation: Having the planes arranged spirally, so that they incline all to the right (or left) of a vertical line; -- said of certain hemihedral forms.
Turning the plane of polarization circularly or spirally to the right or left.
Having the planes arranged spirally, so that they all incline to the right (or left) of a vertical line; said of certain hemihedral forms.
Turning the plane of polarization circularly or spirally to the right or left.

gyrolite.explanation: A hydrous silicate of calcium occurring in white spherical forms with a radiated structure.
A hexagonal-pyramidal mineral containing aluminum , calcium , hydrogen , oxygen , silicon , and sodium .

gyroma.explanation: In botany , the shield of lichens.
A large, convoluted mass in the ovary , similar to an endothelioma .

gyromagnetic.explanation: Of, relating to, or resulting from the magnetic properties of an electrically charged particle or substance that is spinning.
of, relating to, or resulting from the properties of a spinning magnet , or a spinning electric charge ; magnetogyric

gyromancy.explanation: A kind of divination said to have been practised by walking round in a circle or ring until the performer fell from dizziness, the manner of his fall being interpreted with reference to characters or signs previously placed about the ring, or in some such way.
A kind of divination performed by drawing a ring or circle, and walking in or around it.
Divination where people walk on a circle of letters until dizzy , the letters they fall on are significant. Similar to Dervishing .
Divination by whirling a coin on a circle of letters.

gyromele.explanation: A device consisting of a sponge on the end of a long rotating bougie, used for swabbing out the stomach.

gyrometer.explanation: An instrument for indicating continuously the number of revolutions of a rotating axis.

gyromitra.explanation: A genus of ascomycetous fungi of the family Helvellaceæ , having large fleshy stipitate fruiting bodies (ascomata) with the surface irregularly depressed and folded.
any fungus of the genus Gyromitra

gyron.explanation: In heraldry , a bearing consisting of two straight lines drawn from any given part of the field and meeting in an acute angle in the fesse-point.

A subordinary of triangular form having one of its angles at the fess point and the opposite side at the edge of the escutcheon. When there is only one gyron on the shield it is bounded by two lines drawn from the fess point, one horizontally to the dexter side, and one to the dexter chief corner.
A triangular form having an angle at the fess point and the opposite side at the edge of the escutcheon .

gyronny.explanation: heraldry , divided into a number of triangular parts of two different tinctures.
Covered with gyrons, or divided so as to form several gyrons; -- said of an escutcheon.
Covered with gyrons , or divided into several gyrons.

gyrophora.explanation: A genus of lichens, one of which is the tripe-de-roche.

gyroplane.explanation: An aircraft, such as a helicopter or autogyro, equipped with wings that rotate about an approximately vertical axis.
A type of flying-machine. See the extract.
Any aircraft that obtains lift from rotating blades ; an autogyro
an aircraft that is supported in flight by unpowered rotating horizontal wings (or blades); forward propulsion is provided by a conventional propeller

gyroscope.explanation: A device consisting of a spinning mass, typically a disk or wheel, mounted on a base so that its axis can turn freely in one or more directions and thereby maintain its orientation regardless of any movement of the base.
An instrument consisting of a fly-wheel, the axis of which can turn freely in any direction, designed to illustrate the dynamics of rotating bodies.

A rotating wheel, mounted in a ring or rings, for illustrating the dynamics of rotating bodies, the composition of rotations, etc. It was devised by Professor W. R. Johnson, in 1832, by whom it was called the rotascope .

A form of the above apparatus, invented by M. Foucault, mounted so delicately as to render visible the rotation of the earth, through the tendency of the rotating wheel to preserve a constant plane of rotation, independently of the earth's motion.

an apparatus composed of a wheel which spins inside of a frame ( gimbal ) and causes the balancing of the frame in any direction or position. In the form of a gyroscopic stabilizer , used to help keep aircraft and ships steady.
rotating mechanism in the form of a universally mounted spinning wheel that offers resistance to turns in any direction

gyroscopic.explanation: Pertaining to the gyroscope; resembling the motion of the gyroscope.
Pertaining to, by means of, or in the manner of a gyroscope .
having the characteristics of a gyroscope

gyrose.explanation: botany , turned round like a crook; bent to and fro; folded and waved or marked with wavy lines: applied to the peculiar and complicated flexuosities of the margin of the apothecium in the genus Umbilicaria.
Turned round like a crook, or bent to and fro.
Turned round like a crook , or bent to and fro.

gyrostabilized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of gyrostabilize .

gyrostabilizer.explanation: An instrument having a heavy gyroscope whose axis spins in a vertical plane to reduce the side-to-side rolling of a ship or aircraft.
A device for stabilizing using a gyroscope .
a stabilizer consisting of a heavy gyroscope that spins on a vertical axis; reduces side-to-side rolling of a ship or plane

gyrostat.explanation: A gyroscope consisting of a rotating wheel in a rigid case.

An instrument for illustrating the dynamics of rotation, composed of a box or case having a sharp bearing-edge in the form of a regular polygon, and containing a fly-wheel having its center and its direction of rotation in the plane of the bearing-edge.

A modification of the gyroscope, consisting essentially of a fly wheel fixed inside a rigid case to which is attached a thin flange of metal for supporting the instrument. It is used in studying the dynamics of rotating bodies.
A gyroscope fixed within a rigid case

gyrostatic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the gyrostat or to gyrostatics.
Of, pertaining to, or containing a gyrostat

gyrostatics.explanation: That branch of the science of kinetics which deals with the laws of rotating solids.
The doctrine or theory of the gyrostat, or of the phenomena of rotating bodies.

gyrovague.explanation: a wandering monk having no fixed monastery , as exemplified in the Rule of St. Benedict.

gyrus.explanation: A rounded ridge, as on the surfaces of the cerebral hemispheres.
In anatomy , one of the rounded ridges into which the surface of the cerebral hemisphere is divided by the fissures or sulci; a convolution; a gyre.
The gyrus which arches over the extremity of the fissure of Sylvius. See sulcus .
A convoluted ridge between grooves; a convolution. See brain .
A ridge or fold on the cerebral cortex .
a convex fold or elevation in the surface of the brain

gyte.explanation: A first year's pupil in the High School of Edinburgh.

gyttja.explanation: A dark mud that is rich in organic nutrients and oxygen and has accumulated at the bottom of a marsh or lake.

gyve.explanation: A shackle or fetter, especially for the leg.
To fetter; to shackle; to chain.
A shackle; especially, one to confine the legs; a fetter.
A shackle or fetter , especially for the leg.

gyves.explanation: Manacle, Fetter , etc. See shackle , n.
